PAGE: 1
HEADING: SALDANHA

Saldanha da Gama, José de (1839-1905), Brazilian botanist; Dr. Sci. Rio de Janeiro
1860; at the Rio de Janeiro "Central School", later called "Polytechnic School" from
1861 as teacher ("repetitor"), professor of botany and director successively; sometime
consul general for Brazil in Belgium; Brazilian representative at the World Exhibits of
1867, 1873 and 1876; collected in Rio de Janeiro province 1866-1884.
(<em>Saldanha</em>).
f
<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: R. – The small collection which was at B is no longer extant;
some material from Brazil, 1883 sent to Cogniaux, is at BR.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 202 (b. 7 Aug 1839, d. 8 Jan 1905); BM 4:
1791; Bossert p. 346; CSP 5: 377, 8: 817, 11: 263, 18: 412; Herder p. 386; IH 2: (files);
Jackson p. 49, 373; Kew 4: 573; Morren ed. 2, p. 34, ed. 10, p. 139; PR 100, 7997-7999;
Rehder 1: 72, 343, 5: 754-755; Tucker 1: 620; Urban-Berl. p. 390; Zander ed. 10, p. 710,
ed. 11, p. 811.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Brit. Mus. gen. cat. print. books 211: 690-691. 1964; Cat. gén. livr. Bibl.
	natl. 161: 499-500. 1941.
Sabin, J., Dict, books America 7: 146. 1875, 18: 332-333. 1889, 32: 432. 1931-1932.
Saldanha da Gama, J. de, Énumération des travaux jusqu'à l'année 1867. Paris 1868. 8
	p. (bibl., <em>copy</em>: G).
Urban, I., Fl. bras. 1(1): 99. 1906 (biogr. sketch, itin.).
Verdoorn, F., ed., Chron. bot. 5: 303. 1939.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Saldanhaea</em> Bureau (1868). <em>Note</em>: <em>Saldanha</em> Vellozo (1825) was named for
Martin Lopez Lobo Saldanha, Brazilian politician.

10.105. <em>Configuração e descripção de todas os orgãos fundamentaes das principaes madeiras</em> de cerne

Salisbury, Edward James (1886-1978), English botanist; Dr. phil. Univ. College,
London; senior lecturer at Queen Mary College, Univ. London; with Univ. College,
London 1918-1943, ultimately as Quain professor of botany; director Royal Botanic
Gardens Kew 1943-1956; knighted 1946. (<em>E. Salisb.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: K.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 202; BFM no. 2159; BJI 2: 151; BL 2: 227,
245, 246, 256, 260, 712; BM 8: 1131; Bossert p. 346, (b. 16 Apr 1886); LS suppl. 23927;
NI 3: 6; Plesch p. 395; TL-2/3006, 3218.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Allen, D.E., The naturalist in Britain 241. 1976.
Anon., BSBI Abstracts 9: 6. 1979 (d.); Brit. Mus. gen. cat. print. books 211: 830-831.
	1964; Country-side 23: 473. 1979 (n.v.); Daily Telegr. 14 Nov 1978; Flora males.
	Bull. 13: 552. 1957 (retirement); J. Kew Guild 9: 714-716. 1978 (1979) (obit., from
	The Times, 14 Nov 1978); Modern men science 412-413. 1966; Nature 178: 454-455.
	1956 (retirement); New Scientist 5(134): 1294-1295. 1959 (biogr. sketch, portr.);
	Quart. Bull. Alp. Gard. Soc. 47(1): 86. 1979 (d.); The Times 14 Nov 1978; Who's
	who (London) 1929-1970; World Biogr. L-Z: 4167. 1948.

Dick, W.E., Discovery 4: 330-331. 1943.

	191-263. 1932.
<em>Ref</em>.: Rendle, A.B., J. Bot. 71: 140-141. Mai 1933 (rev.).

Salisbury, Richard Anthony (né Markham) (1761-1829), British botanist, gardener
and botanical artist; educated at Edinburgh Univ.; had a garden at Chapel Allerton,
Yorkshire; later owner of P. Collinson's garden at Mill Hill, London; secretary Hort.
Soc. London 1805-1816. (<em>Salisb</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Some material (from the garden at Chapel Allerton) at BM
(through J. Banks); no material at K (see D. Meikle in <em>Note</em> 2, below). Several manu-
scripts and drawings (9 vols.) at BM (for letters to J. Banks see Dawson p. 729-730);
some of Salisbury's notes and drawings of ericaceous plants may be at K (Woodward
1904; R.D. Meikle in lit.).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: (1) Son of Richard Markham; assumed the name Salisbury as a condition of a
legacy (see e.g. Dawson p. 729-730).
(2) "It is true that the Burchell herbarium is incorporated in the general collections at
Kew, but there is no evidence that it includes, or ever included, any Salisbury speci-
mens, nor has anyone here ever seen a Salisbury specimen in our collections. Thanks to
the kindness of H.M. Burdet (Conserv. et Jard. Bot., Genève), I have been able to trace
the source of A.DC.'s statement. In 1877 De Candolle sent Sir W.J. Hooker a manu-
script list of British authors, asking if he could say where their herbaria were located.
Bentham returned the list in June 1878, and against Salisbury's name noted "la plupart
(ou la totalité?) dans l'herbier de Burchell à Kew". The grounds for Bentham's an-
notation are obscure, perhaps he was misled by J.E. Gray's comment (in the preface to
R.A. Salisbury, Genera of Plants, v; 1866) "... on the death of Mr. Salisbury, in 1829,
the son (Dr. W.J. Burchell) inherited part of his property, and with some (I doubt if all)
of his Mss. ... Dr. Burchell died in 1864 ... The botanical collections were then given by
his surviving sister to Sir William Hooker for the Kew Herbarium". Had Bentham read
further, however, he would have seen that Burchell's sister deliberately excluded the
Salisbury collections from the gift to Kew; moreover from what J.E. Gray says it is clear
that the Salisbury <em>reliquiae</em> consisted only of manuscripts, letters, published papers and
"a cabinet of seeds and fragments of plants". Part of this collection, including the speci-
mens, was given by Gray to the British Museum, where it still remains. There is no
evidence that Salisbury left a herbarium to Burchell, nor indeed is there any evidence
that Salisbury ever possessed one. According to J.E. Gray (letter to A. De Candolle,
dating 21st April, 1873, comm. Burdet) "R.A. Salisbury ... cultivated and studied
living plants. He had upwards of 2000 species in pots, in his little yard in Edgware Road
after he had left his large garden at Mill Hill near London". If Salisbury had a her-
barium, Gray makes no mention of it, though he was evidently very interested in Salis-
bury and his collections. It is safe to say that there are no Salisbury specimens at Kew,
and if only to save others from fruitless enquiry, I think A. DC.'s statement should be
corrected." [D. Meikle, in lit. 30 Jun 1977].
(3) For generic names published by Salisbury in his reviews of Robert Brown's work see
Mabberley (1980).

PAGE: 4
HEADING: SALISBURY, R.A.

(4) For Salisbury's part in J. Knight, <em>Cult. Prot.</em> 1809, see TL-2/3759.

[index], 3: nos. 1297-1299; Herder p. 151, 294, 308, 313, 324, 345; Hortus 3: 1203; IF p.

HEADING: SALISBURY, R.A.

10.118. <em>Icones stirpium rariorum</em> descriptionibus illustratae, auctore Ricardo Antonio Salis-
bury, ... Londini [London] (typis Gul. Bulmer) 1791. Fol. (<em>Icon. stirp. rar.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1791 (p. [v]: Jan 1791), p. [i-v], 1-20, <em>pl. 1-10</em> (col. copp.). <em>Copies</em>: BM (incompl.),
	HH, NY (incompl.), Teyler.
<em>Ref</em>.: Usteri, P., Neue Ann. Bot. 11: 150-158. 1796.

10.119. <em>Prodromus stirpium in horto ad Chapel Allerton vigentium</em> ... Londini 1796. Oct. (<em>Prodr. stirp. Chap. Allerton</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Nov-Dec 1796 (p. viii: Nov 1796), p. [i]-viii, [1]-422. <em>Copies</em>: BM, E (inf. J.
	Edmondson), G, HH, K, MO, NY; IDC 2322. – See Britten (1926) for taxa and
	collectors.
<em>Ref</em>.: Britten, J., J. Bot. 54: 57-65. 1926 ("the plants of Salisbury's "Prodromus" (1796)).

10.120. <em>The paradisus londinensis</em>: or coloured figures of plants cultivated in the vicinity of
the metropolis. By William Hooker, pupil of Francis Bauer, Esq. ... vol. i ... London
(printed by D.N. Shury, ... and published by William Hooker, ...) 1805 [-1808]. 2 vols.
Qu. (<em>Parad. lond.</em>).

<em>1</em>(<em>1</em>): 1 Jun 1805-1 Mai 1906 (dates on plates), p. [i, t.p. as above, dated 1805], [iii, t.p.
	1(1), dated 1806, mentioning Salisbury], [v, preface], <em>pl. 1-35</em> with text, [1, index sex.;
	2, err.]. – Second t.p.: <em>The paradisus londinensis</em>: containing plants cultivated in the
	vicinity of the metropolis. The descriptions by Richard Anthony Salisbury, ... the
	figures by William Hooker, pupil of Francis Bauer esq. ... vol. i, part i. London
	(printed by D.N. Shury, ... and published by William Hooker, ...) 1806. – Plates
	col. copper engr. by W. Hooker, with possibly, assistance by R.A. Salisbury for nos. 1-
	70. <em>Plate 14</em> large size (three times as large as the others) or cut in two as 14 and
	[14bis]. All plates with accompanying, unpaginated text (1-2 p.; <em>pl. 14</em>: 3 p.).
<em>1</em>(<em>2</em>): 1 Jun 1806-1 Mai 1807 (dates on plates), p. [i, t.p. 1(2)], <em>pl. 36-56, 57</em> ("<em>67</em>"), <em>58-60,
	61</em> ("<em>62</em>"), <em>62</em> ("<em>61</em>"), <em>63-70</em>, [1, index sex. ii, index nom.]. – <em>Pl 67</em> large size (as <em>14</em>) or
	cut in two as 67 and [67bis].
<em>2</em>(<em>1</em>): 1 Jun 1807-1 Mai 1808 (dates on plates), p. [i, t.p. 2(1)], <em>pl. 71-86, 87</em> ("<em>88</em>"), <em>88</em>
	("<em>87</em>"), <em>89-106</em> [1, index sex.; 2, ind. nom., err.].
<em>2</em>(<em>2</em>): 1 Jun 1808-1 Sep 1808 (dates on plates), p. [i, t.p., 2(2)], <em>pl. 107-109, 110</em> ("<em>112</em>"),
	<em>111-117</em>, four lvs text for <em>71, 72, 73, 74</em> (cancellantia; main change: <em>Bartonia</em> changed to
	<em>Hibbertia</em> on <em>73</em>), <em>pl. 84, 93</em> and <em>111</em> double (analysis based on <em>copy</em> Teyler); other copies
	have also text for <em>pl. 118-122</em> (plates themselves never issued).
<em>Copies</em>: E, FI (incompl.), G, H-UB (incompl.), HH, NY, PH (incompl.), Teyler, USDA
	(<em>pl. 115-117</em> missing); IDC 629. – Part 1 of vol. 1 was apparently first issued with the
	above cited 1805 t.p. (copies: E, Teyler, USDA). In 1806 this part was reissued with a
	title-page stating that the descriptions were by R.A. Salisbury. On the 1805 title-page
	William Hooker's name is mentioned as "by William Hooker" which is the reason
	that he is often cited as the author. It is clear, however, that Hooker made the
	drawings and that Salisbury was reponsible for the descriptions and names. The
	plates are all dated; in general such dates were intended as dates of publication. These
	dates must be regarded as correct until there is evidence that actual publication took
	place at a later date. The book seems to have been issued in 40 parts from 1805 to
	1808 (1809 according to Pritzel, but latest date on plates is 1 Sep 1808).
	The originals for the plates <em>1-70</em> (which make up vol. 1, parts 1 and 2) were perhaps
the joint work of William Hooker and Salisbury; they are at BM together with the
manuscripts of the descriptions. Volume 2 consists of the plates <em>71-117</em> whereas the de-
scriptions run to <em>t. 122.</em> G.S. Bunyard states (see TL-2/2: 283), that some copies have two
versions of the text belonging to plate <em>64</em>, one entitled <em>Anneslia falcifolia</em>, the other <em>Anneslia
grandiflora</em>. John Collins (Sotheby 670) mentions also a cancelled (<em>Burtonia grossu-
lariaefolia</em>) for a cancellans (<em>Hibbertia grossulariaefolia</em> of the text to <em>p. 73.</em> The artist William
Hooker (1779-1832) was a pupil of Bauer; not to be confused with William Jackson Hooker
(1785-1865).
<em>Ref</em>.: Britten, J., J. Bot. 24: 52, 296-300. 1886.
	Junk, W., Rara 13, 116. 1900-1913.

10.121. <em>The generic characters in the English botany</em>, collated with those of Linné ... London
(printed by W. Bulmer and Co. ...) 1806. Oct. (in fours). (<em>Gen. char. Engl. bot.</em>).

PAGE: 6
HEADING: SALISBURY, W.

<em>Publ</em>.: 1806 (p. iv: 1 Feb 1806), p. [i]-iv, [1]-34. <em>Copies</em>: E, G.

10.122. <em>The genera of plants</em> ... a fragment containing part of Liriogamae. London (John

<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., J. Bot. 4: 179-183. Jun 1866 (rev.).

Salisbury, William (x-1823), British nurseryman in London; gardener to J. Symmons
at Paddington 1797, also associated with William Curtis' garden at Fulham Road which
he continued after the latter's death in 1799; later owner of a garden at Cadogan Place,
Sloane Street; founded the London Botanic Garden, 1807. (<em>W. Salisb.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown. – We have seen no copy of the exsiccatae <em>Hortus siccus
gramineus</em> (1802-1806) (see Henrey 3: 110).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 203; BB p. 267; BM 4: 1792; Bret. p. 210;
Desmond p. 538; DNB 50: 201 (17: 690) (by G.S. Boulger); Henrey 2: 298, 308-309,
643, 3: 31, 110-111, 140; Jackson p. 233, 409, 415; Kew 4: 577; PR 8005-8006, ed. 1:
8963-8964; Rehder 5: 755; SO 806; TL-1/1145; Tucker 1: 620.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Allen, D.E., The naturalist in Britain 106, 107. 1976.
Allibone, S.A., Crit. dict. Engl. lit. 2: 1917. 1878.
Anon., Brit. Mus. gen. cat. print. books 211: 836. 1964.
Bridson, G.D.D. et al., Nat. hist. mss. res. Brit. Isles 334.77. 1980.
Fussell, G.E., Gard. Chron. 1949(2): 172.
Harvey, J.H., Trans. London Middlesex Archeol. Soc. 24: 186. 1973 (continued Curtis's
	garden in Fulham Road after the latter's death in 1799; new garden in Sloane street
	in process of establishment by 1807).
Roberts, W., Gard. Chron., 1900(1): 65-66 (on S. and the London Botanic Garden).
Trimen, H. and W.T., Thiselton Dyer, W.T., Fl. Middlesex 395. 1869.

Sallent y Gotés, Angel (1857-1934), Catalonian philologist and botanist; collaborator
of Cadeval y Diars. (<em>Sallent</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

see 1514; BL 2: 495, 498, 712; TL-2/940.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Chron. bot. 1: 251. 1935 (d.).

HEADING: SALM-DYCK

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: With Juan Cadeval y Diars, <em>Fl. Catalunya</em> vols. 1-3, 1913-1923, see

10.125. <em>Flora del Pla del Bages</em> ... Barcelona (Tipografia de Augusto Ponsy Pon ...) 1904.
Qu. (<em>Fl. Pla del Bages</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1904, p. [1]-80. <em>Copy</em>: G.

Salm-Reifferscheid-Dyck, Joseph Maria Franz Anton Hubert Ignaz, Fürst und
Altgraf zu (1773-1861), German (Prussian) botanist, botanical artist and horticultur-
ist; closely associated with the French botanists and botanical artists of the Napoleonic
period, subsequently building up a rich collection of succulent plants on his estate Dyck
nr. Düsseldorf through his close connections with most of Europe's established botanical
gardens and botanists; died at Nice. (<em>Salm-Dyck</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown. – Salm-Dyck's collection of living succulent plants at
Schloss Dyck (near Neuss, Düsseldorf) was unrivalled at the time. Kümmel (1981) states
that the collection of living plants survived until 1914, where as herbarium specimens
were discarded shortly after Salm-Dyck's death. Clokie mentions "one or two speci-
mens" presented to Haworth at OXF. – <em>Letters</em> to M. van Marum at Teyler, F.A.W.
Miquel at U, to D.F.L. von Schlechtendal at HAL, and to other botanists ca. 1810-1860
in various other European herbaria.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 30: 255-257 (E. Wunschmann); AG 2(2): 402;
Backer p. 507; Barnhart 3: 203 (b. 4 Sep 1773, d. 21 Mar 1861); BM 4: 1792; Bossert p.
346; Clokie p. 236; CSP 6: 752; Frank 3(Anh.): 88; GF 75; Herder p. 159, 283, 286, 330;
Hortus 3: 1203; Jackson p. 122, 425, 426; Kew 4: 444, 577; Langman p. 667; Maiwald
p. 213, 216, 218; NI 1720; Plesch p. 396; PR 8008-8016, ed. 1: 2235, 8965-8974; Rehder
5: 755; SK 4: ccxi; Sotheby 672; TL-1/1146-1148a; Tucker 1: 620; Zander ed. 10, p.
710, ed. 11, p. 810.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bonplandia 1: 18, 21, 118. 1853, 3: 34. 1855, 4: 354. 1856, 6: 51, 219,
	244. 1858, 9: 92, 331. 1861 (d.), 10: 218. 1862 (cogn. Leop. Xeuxis/Zeuxis); Bot. Zeit.
	10: 923. 1852 (sketch of activities); Gartenflora 10(10): 370. 1861 (obit.); III. hortic. 8:
	27. 1861 (obit.); Österr. bot. Z. 11: 171. 1861 (d.); Revue hortic. 1861: 224-225
	(obit.).
Candolle, A.P. de, Mém. souvenirs 384, 575. 1862.
Forbes, R.J., Martinus van Marum 1: 334, 335, 412 [index]. 1969, 2: 11. 1970.
Hermes, A., Deut. Gärtn. Zeit. 4(7): 76-78. 1880 (Die Gärtenanlagen zu Dyck).
Koch, K., ed., Wochenschr. Ver. Beförd. Gartenbau. Preuss., Gärtn. Pflanzenk.
	1861(19): 145-148. 9 Mai 1861 (obit.).
Kümmel, F., Kakteen Sukkulenten (Dresden) 16(2): 22-30. 1981 (general evaluation;
	fate collections; portr., letter to Schlechtendal of 6 Apr 1850).
Kuijlen, J. et al., Paradisus batavus 30, 36, 72. 1983.
Lefebvre, E. &amp; J.G. de Bruyn, Martinus van Marum 6: 307-321 [letters], 434 [index].
1976 (portr., opp. p. 85).
Leuenberger, E.L., Zandera 2(3/4): 29-40. 1983.
Lindberg, G.A., Monatschr. Kakteenk. 1(12): 153-156. 1892 (biogr., portr.).
Nelmes, E. &amp; W. Cuthbertson, Curtis's Bot. Mag. dedic. 1827-1927, p. 66-68. 1932.
Reynolds, G.W., Aloes S. Afr. 94-95. 1950.
Schlechtendal, D.F.L. von, Bot. Zeit. 19: 62. 1861 (obit.).
Seemann, B. &amp; W.E.G., eds., Bonplandia 9: 331-334. 1861 (obit.) (based on an account
	by "Funke").
Stearn, W.T., <em>in</em> H. Herre, Gen. Mesembryanth. 43-45. 1971 (biogr. sketch, portr.).
Steenis-Kruseman, M.J. van, <em>in</em> R.J. Forbes, ed., Martinus van Marum 3: 385 [index].
1971.
White, A. &amp; B.L. Sloane, Stapelieae ed. 2. 98, 695, 775. 1937 (portr.).
Wittrock, V.B., Acta Horti Berg. 3(2): 141. 1903.

<sm>HANDWRITING</sm>: Lefebvre, E. &amp; J.G. de Bruyn, Martinus van Marum 6: <em>pl</em>. facing p. 309.
1976.

PAGE: 8
HEADING: SALM-DYCK

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Dyckia</em> J.H. Schuhes ex J.A. Schuhes et J.H. Schuhes (1830); <em>Reiffenscheidia</em>
Steudel (1841, <em>orth. var.</em>); <em>Reifferscheidia</em> K.B. Presi (1835); <em>Salmea</em> A.P. de Candolle (1813,
<em>nom. cons.</em>); <em>Salmeopsis</em> Bentham (1873); <em>Salmia</em> Cavanilles (1795, <em>nom. rej.</em>); <em>Salmia</em> Willde-
now (1811); <em>Salmia</em> Post et O. Kuntze (1903, <em>orth. var.</em> of <em>Salmea</em> A.P. de Candolle).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Salm-Dyck's second wife, Constance Marie, princesse de Salm-Dyck, née Theis,
1767-1845, was a well-known literary author and essayist who wrote e.g. the lyrical
tragedy Sappho (1794). Through his marriage with her S. remained in close contact
with Paris, spending the winters in his Paris home for many years.

10.126. <em>Verzeichniss der verschiedenen Arten und Abarten des Geschlechts Aloe</em>, welche von den
Herren von Willdenow, Haworth, de Candolle und Freiherrn von Jacquin beschrieben
worden sind, oder noch unbeschrieben in den Gärten Deutschlands, Frankreichs und
der Niederlande sich befinden [Dyck nr. Düsseldorf, 1817]. Oct. (in fours). (<em>Verz. Art.
Aloe</em>).

Salmon, Charles Edgar (1872-1930), British botanist and practicing architect at
Reigate (Surrey); active amateur local historian and student of the flora of Surrey, esp.
<em>Limonium</em>. (<em>Statice</em>). (<em>Salmon</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BM; duplicates at B (not extant), C, CGE, CYN, DBN, E, K, L,
MANCH, OXF, RTE. – Salmon's herbarium, numbering ca. 100.000 specimens, con-
tained e.g. the herbarium of Alfred William Bennett (1833-1902).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 203; BL 2: 712-713 [index]; BM 8: 1131;
Bossert p. 346; Clokie p. 236; CSP 18: 417; Desmond p. 538 (b. 22 Nov 1872, d. 1 Jan
1930); De Toni 4: xlix; Hortus 3: 1203; Kew 4: 257, 579; Lenley p. 358; Tucker 1: 620,
3: 266; Urban-Berl. p. 390; Zander ed. 10, p. 710, ed. 11, p. 810.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., J. Bot. 58: 183. 1920 (announcement of Fl. Surrey, publ., posthumously,
	in 1931; J- Bot. 68: 31. 1930 (d.).
Baker, E.G., J. Bot. 68: 50-53. 1930 (obit., bibl.); Proc. Linn. Soc. London 142: 218-221.
	1931 (obit.).
Barton, W.C., Rep. Bot. Soc. Exch. Cl. Brit. Isl. 9(1): 96-98. 1930 (obit.).

Salmon, Ernst Stanley (1872-1959), British mycologist; at Jodrell Laboratory, Kew,
1899-1906; mycologist S.E.Agric. Coll., Wye 1906-1937; reader in mycology, London
Univ. 1912; professor ib. 1925; specialist on hop diseases and Erysiphaceae; amateur
bryologist. (<em>E.S. Salmon</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: K; further material at B (partly destr.), DBN, E, OXF. – 13
letters to V.F. Brotherus at Helsinki Univ. Libr.; 12 letters to W.G. Farlow at FH; other
letters at NY.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Ainsworth p. 233, 323; Andrews p. 324; Barnhart 3: 203;
BJI 2: 151; BL 2: 268; Clokie p. 236; CSP 18: 418; Desmond p. 538 (d. 12 Oct 1959); De
Toni 4: xlix; Hawksworth p. 185; Kelly p. 205; Lenley p. 358; LS 23550-23594a, 38714-
38756, 41693-41695 (bibl.); LS suppl. 1: 1532, 2061, 9787, 9788, 23933-23997; MW p.
424; SBC p. 131; Stevenson p. 1256; Urban-Berl. p. 281.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Amos, A.J., Inst. Brewing 66: 11. 1960 (obit., work with hops).
Anon., J. Mycol. 13: pl. facing p. I. 1907 (portr.); The Times 18 Oct 1959 (portr.).

Salmon, John Drew (ca. 1802-1859), British botanist and ornithologist; manager of
the Wenham Lake Ice Company; at Thetford 1835-1843; later at Godalming. (<em>J.D.
Salmon</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: NWH (2000); further material in GOD, OXF and RTE. Diaries
at NWH.

Salomon, Carl (1829-1899), German botanist, royal Bavarian gardener at Würzburg;
popular author on botany. (<em>Salomon</em>).

Salt, Henry (1780-1827), English traveller and Egyptologist; secretary to Lord
Valentia in India and Africa 1802-1805; in Abyssinia 1805 and 1809-1810; in
Moçambique 1809; consul-general for Gr. Britain in Egypt 1815-1827. (<em>Salt</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Abyssinian plants at BM (worked up by R. Brown). Other
material at G and MO. Letters to J. Banks at BM.

140; SO add. 8021; TL-1/1149; Tucker 1: 621.

	as a pioneer Egyptologist).

10.146. <em>A voyage to Abyssinia</em>, and travels into the interior of that country, executed under
the orders of the British Government, in the years 1809 and 1810; in which are included,
an account of the Portuguese settlements on the East Coast of Africa, visited in the
course of the voyage; a concise narrative of late events in Arabia felix; and some part-
iculars respecting the aboriginal African tribes, extending from Mosambique to the
borders of Egypt; together with vocabularies of their respective languages. Illustrated
with a map of Abyssinia, numerous engravings, and charts ... London (printed for F.C.
and J. Rivington, ...) 1814. Qu. (<em>Voy. Abyss.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Sep 1814 (preface: 9 Jul 1814; P &amp; W p. 512, RS), p. [i]-xi, [xiii-xvi], [1]-506, i-
	lxxv (appendix), 37 pl., charts, maps. <em>Copies</em>: F, HH, PH. – Part of Appendix 4 by
	Robert Brown: on p. lxiii-lxv, "<em>List of new and rare plants, collected in Abyssinia</em> ..." The
	new names are almost exclusively <em>nomina nuda</em>. The list is reproduced in Flora 4(1),
	Beil. 2: 61-64. Jan-Jun 1821.
<em>German transl</em>.: 1815 (p [i]-xvi, [1]-480, map. <em>Copy</em>: NSUB (inf. G. Wagenitz). – <em>Neue Reise
	nach Abyssinien</em> in den Jahren 1809 und 1810. Aus dem Englischen übersetzt und mit
	einigen Anmerkungen begleitet, von Friedrich Rühs. Weimar (im Verlage des
	Landes-Industrie-Comptoirs) 1815. Oct., p. [i]-xvi, [1]-480, map. – On p. 474-478:
	list of new and rare plants (by R. Brown). – See also E. de Berg, Add. ad Thes. lit.
	bot. 31. 1859.
<em>French</em> "<em>version</em>": 1812, 2 vols., <em>Voyage en Abyssinie</em>, par Mr. Salt, traduit de l'Anglais et
	extrait des voyages de bord Valentia ... À Paris (chez J.J. Paschoud, ...) et à Genève
	(chez le même Imprimeur-Libraire) 1812, 2 vols. (<em>Voy. Abyss.</em>). <em>Copy</em>: H.
	<em>1</em>: 1812, p. [1]-304.
	<em>2</em>: 1812, p. [1]-272, <em>pl. 1-9.</em>
<em>Note</em>: This is not an earlier version of Salt's <em>Voy. Abyss.</em> of 1814 but rather the French
	version of its predecessor: Voyages and travels to India ... Abyssinia, and Egypt ...
	by George Viscount Valentia [G. Annesly, Earl of Mountnorris], which contains in
	vols. 2 and 3, 1809, H. Salt's <em>Narrative of an Expedition to Abyssinia</em>, London 1809. Qu.

Salter, John Henry (1862-1942), English botanist and ornithologist; Bsc. London;
with Strasburger 1896; teacher at various schools 1881-1888; professor of botany Univ.
Coll. Aberystwyth 1891-1908; in the Canary Isl. and S. France 1908-1916; ultimately in
Great Britain, from 1928 in the Aberystwyth area. (<em>Salter</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: NMW. Some further material at E. – Diary at Natl. Libr. Wales;
drawings at Univ. Coll. Aberystwyth.

Rehder 1: 140; Tucker 1: 621.

Salter, Terence Macleane (1883-1969), English amateur botanist; Royal navy pay-
master 1904 (commander 1922) until 1931 (retired as paymaster captain); settled in
Cape Town, S. Africa 1935, devoting himself to the study of the Cape flora; Honorary
Reader in systematic botany, Bolus Herbarium 1930-1960; Dr. sci. h.c. Univ. Cape
Town 1955; Bolus medal 1965; specialist on <em>Oxalis</em>. (<em>T.M. Salter</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: NBG; other material at B, BM, BOL (impt. set), K (id.), MO,
PRE, SAM, UPS, W. Library and mss. at NBG.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 204; Bossert p. 346; Desmond p. 539 (b. 5
Feb 1883, d. 30 Mar 1969); Hortus 3: 1203; IH 1 (ed. 6): 364, (ed. 7): 341; NI 3: 43;
Roon p. 98.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Brit. Mus. gen. cat. print. books 212: 74-75. 1964; Bull. misc. Inf. Kew
	1930: (app. 1) 34, 1931, (app. 1): 32, 1933 (app.): 32, 1935 (app.): 635 (coll.); S. Afr.
Forum bot. 4(10): 1-2. 1966 (Harry Bolus medal).
Bullock, A.A., Bibl. S. Afr. bot. 98. 1978 (bibl.).
Garside, S., frontisp. portr. to R.A. Dyer, ed., Fl. pl. Afr. 33, 1959.
Gunn, M. &amp; L.E. Codd, Bot. expl. S. Afr. 306-307. 1981 (portr., coll.).
Lawder, M., Gard. Chron. 165: 40. 1969 (obit., not.).
Plessis, E.P. du &amp; J.P. Rourke, J.S. Afr. Bot. 37(3): 177-182. 1971 (obit., bibl. portr.).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Salter's <em>The genus Oxalis in South Africa</em>, a taxonomic revision.
Cape Town, Nov 1944, 355 p., was issued as J.S. Afr. Bot. suppl. vol. 1 (rev. M.R.
Levyns, J.S. Afr. Bot. 11: 91-93. 1945), errata in J.S. Afr. Bot. 23(3): 103-104. 1957.
(2) Contributed Ericaceae, Leguminosae, Proteaceae, Geraniaceae and Oxalidaceae to
Adamson &amp; Salter, <em>Flora of the Cape Peninsula</em>. 1950.
(3) M.M. Kidd, <em>Wild flowers of the Cape Peninsula</em> ... with text and nomenclature com-
piled under the supervision of ... T.M. Salter, ... 1950.
(4) <em>Journal of South African Botany, Index</em> to vols. 1-15, 1935-1949, compiled by T.M.
Salter.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Saltera</em> Bullock (1958).

Salter, Thomas Bell (1814-1858), Scottish physician and botanist; Dr. med.
Edinburgh; practiced at Ryde (Isle of Wight). (<em>T.B. Salter</em>).

PAGE: 16
HEADING: SALTER, T. B.

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: K; further material at AK, CGE, E, Ryde Museum.

PR 8019, ed. 1: 8976; Rehder 5: 756; TL-2/792; Tucker 1: 621.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Brit. Mus. gen. cat. print. books 212: 75. 1964.
Bell, T., Proc. Linn. Soc. London 1958 (4 Nov): xxiv-xxxv (obit., bibl.).
Bennett, J.J., Bot. Zeit. 18: 347. 1860 (obit., herb. to LINN [later to K]).

Salwey, Thomas (1791-1877), British clergyman and lichenologist; BD Cambridge;
rector Oswestry, Shropshire 1833-1872. (<em>Salwey</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BM and K; other material at CGE, DBN, H-NYL (Lich.). –
<em>Lichenes centum ex herbario T. Salwey</em>, fasc. 1-4, nos. 1-400; sets at BM, DBN; a note in J.
Bot. 7: 63. 1878, mentions also <em>Lichenes britannici</em>, vols. 1-4, nos. 1-397, possibly identical
with the previous series (see Sayre 1969); mss. journal and lichens also at Ludlow
Museum. <em>Letters</em> at BM and K. – Hawksworth and Seaward (1977) state for S.'s lichens:
"? BM (perhaps lost)".

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 204; BB p. 268 ("Salway"); BL 2: 320, 713;
CSP 5: 387, 12: 647; Desmond p. 540 (b. 19 Oct 1791, d. 3 Dec 1877); GR p. 279; GR,
cat. p. 71; Lenley p. 359; LS 23599-23604 (bibl.); Rehder 1: 401.

Salzmann, Philipp (1781-1851), German (Saxonian) botanist; studied medicine at
Göttingen (1800-1801), Wien (1801-1803), Halle (1803-1805), and Paris (1805); settled
in Montpellier (1806) as hospital physician, later devoting himself to botany and en-
tomology; collecting extensively in S. France, N. Africa, Spain (1823-1825) and Brazil,
mainly Bahia, 1827-1830. (<em>Salzm</em>.).

PAGE: 17
HEADING: SAMPAIO, A. J.

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: MPU; other material at AL, AWH, B (mainly destroyed), BR,

OXF, P, PRC, R, W.

Sampaio, Gonçalo António da Silva Ferreira (1865-1937), Portuguese botanist;
studied at the Coimbra Polytechnic and the University of Coimbra; at the botanical
department of the University of Porto (then "Academia polytechnica") from 1901 as
"naturalista adjunto", from 1912-1935 as professor of botany. (<em>Samp</em>.).

Samuelsson, Gunnar (1885-1944), Swedish botanist; Dr. phil. Uppsala 1913; lecturer
Uppsala 1913; curator Bot. Mus., Univ. Uppsala 1914-1919; professor and director of
the botany department of the Stockholm Riksmuseum from 1924-1944. (<em>Sam</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: S; other material at B (extant), C, E, GB, GH, H, K, LD, NY.
<em>Plantae Sueciae exsiccatae</em>, nos. 1-1617, set e.g. at H. <em>Hieracia scandinavica exsiccata</em> sets 1-6, at
A, C, H, LD, S (with Karl Johansson, see TL-2/2: 447). – <em>Schedae</em> operis quod inscribitur
G. Samuelsson ... <em>Plantae Sueciae exsiccatae</em>. edidit Eric Hultén ... Stockholm 1946.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 660; Barnhart 3: 206; BJI 2: 152; BL 2: 69,
448, 457, 517, 519, 528, 531; BM 4: 1797, 8: 1134; Bossert p. 347 (d. 14 Jan 1944);
Clokie p. 347; GR p. 498; Hirsch p. 258; Hortus 3: 1203; Kleppa p. 331 [index]; KR p.
615-617 (b. 27 Aug 1885); Lenley p. 359; MW p. 425; Nordstedt suppl. p. 13; SIA-HI
107; TL-2/2364, 3369-3370, see K.Johansson; Zander ed. 10, p. 710, ed. 11, p. 810.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon. Bot. Not. 1916: 127 (price), 1924: 311 ("intendent" riksmus.), 1932: 151
	(trip to Palestine and Syria), 1936: 159 (trip Morocco, Algeria); Brit. Mus. gen. cat.
	print. books 212: 355. 1964; Österr. bot. Z. 73: 160. 1924 (app. Stockholm).

	14 Jan 1944).

	232, 304. 1941.

2/2364.

(<em>4</em>) <em>Erik Almquist, ed., Maps of a selection of Scandinavian Hieracium species</em>, Stockholm 1954,
10 p., 123 maps (publ. Jan 1955).

Sanborn, Ethel Ida (1883-1952), American botanist; born at Goodwin, S. Dakota;
A.M. S. Dakota 1907; Dr. phil. Stanford 1928; high school teacher in S. Dakota 1904-
1906, in Minnesota 1907-1909; curator herbarium University of Oregon 1914-1917;
instructor in botany ib. 1918-1927; assist. professor 1928-1932; at Oregon State College
[University] 1932-1933; assoc. professor 1933-1948. (<em>Sanborn</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: OSC.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 206; IH 1 (ed. 7): 342; SIA 7097.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Amer. men sci. ed. 5. 969. 1933, ed. 6. 1230. 1938, ed. 7. 1540. 1944;

PAGE: 26
HEADING: SANBORN

	Amer. women 2: 598. 1937, 3: 788. 1939; Brit. Mus. gen. cat. print. books 212: 398.
	1964.
Gilkey, H.M., Hist. bot. pl. pathol. Oreg. State Univ. (mss. at Corvallis), inf. K.L.
	Chambers in lit. 20 Sep 1982 (d. 31 Oct 1952).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) With Ralph W. Chaney, <em>The Goshen flora of west central Oregon</em> 1933
(Carn. Inst. Wash., Publ. 439).
(2) With Clara J. Chapman, <em>Moss flora of the Willamette Valley, Oregon</em> 1941 (Oreg.
Monogr., Stud. Bot. 4).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Later publications, outside our period, e.g.: <em>Moss flora of the Willamette Valley</em>,
	Oregon (with Clara J. Chapman), O.S.C. Press 1941 ; <em>The marine algae of the Coos Bay</em>-
	Cape Arago Region of Oregon (with Maxwell S. Doty), O.S.C. Press 1944; <em>The Scio
	flora of Western Oregon</em>, O.S.C. Press 1947.

Sandahl, Oskar Theodor (1829-1894), Swedish physician, entomologist and botanist;
studied at Uppsala 1847; Dr. med. Lund 1863; associated with the Karolinska Institute
from 1852, as professor of pharmacology from 1873; also inspector of the pharmaceutical
institute Stockholm from 1873. (<em>Sandahl</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 206; Bossert p. 347; KR p. 617-618 (b. 9
Nov 1829, d. 22 Jun 1894, bibl.); Morren ed. 10, p. 102; Rehder 5: 756, 757.

HEADING: SANDBERGER

Sandberg, John Herman (1848-1917), Swedish-born American botanist, agronomist
and forester; came to America in 1868; practicing physician at Jenkins and Minneapolis,
Minnesota; field agent with USDA (Divi Bot.) 1892; collected widely in Minnesota
(1885-1894), Idaho (1886-1892), Washington (1887-1893), Montana (1887, 1892-
1893), Michigan 1889-1890, Wisconsin 1890. (<em>Sandberg</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: US; further material in B (mainly destr.), BR, C, CAS, DS, E, F,
GH, K, L, LA, LD, MICH, MIN, MSC, MO, NH, NY, NYS, OSC, OXF, PENN, PH,
S, SI, STU, U, WTU (impt. set). – Field notes at US.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 206 (b. 24 Jul 1848, d. 10 Dec 1917); Clokie
p. 237; Ewan ed. 1: 226, 356, 296, ed. 2: 192; IH 1 (ed. 7): (in press), 2: (files); NW p.
56; SIA 1010014; TL-2/2959; Urban-Berl. 391

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Blankinship, J.W., Montana Agric. Coll. Sci. Studies Bot. 1: 13. 1905.
Holzinger, J.H., Contr. U.S. natl. Herb. 3(4): 205-287. 1895 (Rept. on a collection of
	plants made by ... J.H.S. in northern Idaho 1892).
Pennell, F.W. &amp; J.H. Barnhart, Monogr. Acad. nat. Sci. Philadelphia 1: 618. 1935.

Rigg, G.B., Wash. hist. Quart. 20(3): 167. 1929.
Rydberg, P.A., Augustana Coll. Libr. Publ. 5: 40. 1907.
Voss, E.G., Contr. Univ. Mich. Herb. 13: 37. 1978.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Sandbergia</em> E.L. Greene (1911).

Sandberger, Karl [Carl] Ludwig Fridolin von (1826-1898), German (Nassau-
Dillenburg) palaeontologist; Dr. phil. Giessen 1846; secr. Nassau. Ver. Naturk. 1849-
1852; head of the Wiesbaden Natural History Museum 1852-1855; professor of geology
at the Karlsruhe Polytechnic 1855-1863; professor of mineralogy and geology Würzburg
1863-1896; in retirement in München. (<em>K. Sandberger</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Fossil material at the "Naturhistorisches Museum" Wiesbaden
(Schöndorf 1908).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 53: 701-702 (Rothpletz); AG 6(1): 196; Andrews p.

389-390, 6: 752, 8: 824-826, 11: 274-276, 12: 698, 18: 431-433; LS 23611; Quenstedt p.
375.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Ber. Senckenb. naturf. Ges. 1898: viii (obit., not.); Brit. Mus. gen. cat.

Sande Lacoste, Cornelius Marinus van der (1815-1887), Dutch botanist
(bryologist); Dr. med. Utrecht 1843; practicing physician at Amsterdam from 1843,
dedicating himself, however, more and more to botany; co-founder of the Nederlandse
Botanische Vereniging. (<em>Sande Lac</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: L (foreign material, other collectors), NBV (Dutch material);
further material at C, G, GRO, H, U, WAG. – Letters to D.F.L. von Schlechtendal at
HAL, to F.A.W. Miquel at U.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 509; Barnhart 3: 206 (b. 5 Mar 1815, d. 15 Jan
1887); BL 2: 429, 435, 436, 713; BM 4: 1799; Bossert p. 347; CSP 5: 391, 8: 826, 18: 434;

451; LS 23612-23613; Morren ed. 10, p. 90; MW p. 425; NI 1721; PR 2394-2395, 8025;
SBC p. 131; SK 4: cxxv, 71; TL-1/310, 867, 875; TL-2/1512, 1513, 2007, 2460, 6107;
Urban-Berl. p. 312.

Sandéen, Peter Fredrik (1839-1868), Swedish botanist: amanuensis at the Botanical
Museum, Lund, 1858; Dr. phil. Lund 1865; "adjunkt" at schools in Lund (1864) and
Karlskrona (1865). (<em>Sandéen</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Sandéen did not describe any new taxa; his herbarium went to
the Grammar school of Karlskrona and is now at LD (inf. O. Almborn): further
material at F.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 206; BM 4: 1799-1800; KR p. 618-619 (b. 22
Sep 1839, d. 4 Apr 1869); PR 8023-8024; Rehder 2: 184.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Scheutz, N.J., Bot. Not. 1868: 46-47 (obit. not.; d. 4 Apr 1868, not 1869 as in
	Krok).
Wittrock, V.B., Acta Horti Berg. 3(3): 51, <em>pl. 114.</em> 1905.

10.217. <em>Morphologiska iakttagelser</em> öfver bladknopparne hos några Polygoneae. Akademisk

PAGE: 30
HEADING: SANDÉEN

Afhandling, som med tillstånd af vidtberömda Philosophiska Faculteten i Lund for
philosophiska gradens vinnande till offentlig granskning framställes af P.Fr. Sandéen,
... å auditoriet n:o 1, lördagen den 27 Maj 1865, kl. 8 f.m. Lund (tryckt uti Berlingska
boktryckeriet) 1865. Oct. (<em>Morph. iakttag.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1-27 Mai 1865, p. [i], [1]-29, [30-32], <em>pl. 1-2. Copies</em>: C, H, LD, NSUB.
<em>Journal issue, in</em> Lund Univ. Årsskr. [Fysiogr. Sällsk. Handl.] 1: IV. 1-IV.29, [30-32], IV,
	<em>pl. 1-2.</em> 1865 (printed circa 1 Mai 1865, O. Almborn).

10.218. <em>Om individualiteten hos de högre växterna</em>. Ett bidrag till läran om naturens enhet i
mångfald ... (Aftryck ur Inbjudningsskr. t. bevist. af års-exameu) [sic] 1867 vid
Carlskrona H. El. Lärov.). Carlskrona (Alfred Hallén) 1867. Qu. (<em>Individualit. högre
växt.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Jun 1867, p. [i*], [i]-xxvii. <em>Copies</em>: C, H, LD, MO, NY, Peterson. – Note by O.
	Almborn: "On individuality in higher plants. A contribution to the doctrine of the
	unity of nature in manifoldness". S. was a student of J.G. Agardh whose fundamental
	work <em>Theoria systematis plantarum</em> (1858) is often quoted. S.'s final words are a quotat-
	ion from E. Fries, Botaniska utflygter (1853): "the whole creation is a continuous
	whole predestinated by an infinite wisdom to reach higher and higher development"
	(transl.). Darwin is not mentioned. – The pamphlet is a reprint from the invitation to
	attend the 1867 annual examination at the Karlskrona Grammar School. Date of
	publication: probably Jun 1867, the usual time for the annual examination.

Sander, [Henry] Frederick [Conrad] [baptized Heinrich Friedrich Conrad] (1847-
1920), German (Bremen) horticulturist and orchidologist; to England 1865, working in
nurseries at Forest Hill; independent seedsman from 1874, associated with B. Roezl; at
St. Albans 1881, established an orchid nusery at Summit, New Jersey (sold 1896) and
one at St. André, Bruges, Belgium 1894; outstanding grower, hybridizer and introducer
of orchids. (<em>Sander</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Culivated orchids (1881-1899) from "Sander &amp; Co." at K. –
Letters at K.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 207; BM 4: 1800; Desmond p. 541 (b. 1847,
d. 23 Dec 1920); GF p. 75; Hortus 3: 1196, 1203; Lenley p. 440; NI 1722; Zander ed. 10,
p. 672, 710, ed. 11, p. 810-811 (b. 4 Mar 1847).

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Hort. Trade J. 29 Dec 1920, [1] p. (obit.); J. Hort. Cottage Gard. 22:
	449, 551. 1891 (obit.); Orch. Rev. 29: 45-50. 1921 (obit., portr.).
Bridson, G.D.R. et al., Nat. hist. mss. res. Brit. Isl. 269.313. 1980.
Jackson, B.D., Proc. Linn. Soc. 133: 54-55. 1921 (obit.).
Montefusco, M., Amer. Orch. Soc. Bull. 1981 (Mai): 541-546. (... Reichenbachia, a
	Victorian masterpiece).
Reinikka, M.A., Amer. Orch. Soc. Bull. 34: 329. 1965 (on H.G. Moon, the artist of
	Reichenbachia); A history of the orchid 1972, 260-263 (portr., biogr. sketch).
Stearn, W.T., Royal Hort. soc. Exhib. manuscr. books 49. 1954 (Reichenbachia).
Swinson, A., Frederick Sander, the Orchid king, London 1970, 252 p. (biogr.), see also
	Orch. Rev. 78: 129, 159-160, 298-304. 1970.
Watson, W., Gard. Chron. 1921(1): 12 (obit., portr.); Bull. misc. Inf. Kew 1921: 33.
Wittrock, V.B., Acta Horti Berg. 3(2): 97. 1903, 3(3): 82. 1905.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Charles Fearnley Sander (1874-1957) and Frederick K. Sander (1876-1951) were
associated with their father in "Sander and Sons". C.F. Sander was largely responsible
for the Bruges establishment 1920-1934; F.K. Sander was director of "Messrs Sander's
Orchid nurseries, St. Albans" 1946. He published the first post-W.W.II <em>Complete List of
Orchid hybrids</em>, 1946 (see Desmond p. 541). – H.F.C. Sander's wife, Eliza Sander, is
recognized in <em>Nicotiana sanderae</em> Hort. Sand.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Sanderella</em> O. Kuntze (1891).

10.219. <em>Reichenbachia</em>. Orchids illustrated and described by F. Sander with the assistance

HEADING: SANDERSON, A. R.

of scientific authority. St. Albans (F. Sander &amp; Co., ...) London, Berlin, Paris, New

	BR, MO, NY (imperial ed.), U (imperial ed.).

10.220. <em>Sander's orchid guide</em>, containing all the best known species, varieties, and hybrids
of orchids in cultivation. Their native countries, descriptions, seasons of flowering, best
methods of cultivation, temperatures, etc. Together with the names and parentages of
all the known hybrid orchids up to date, January 1st, 1901. F. Sander &amp; Co., St. Albans
[1901]. Oct. (<em>Sander's Orch. guide</em>).

<em>Ed</em>.[<em>1</em>]: 1901 (date on cover), p. [1]-330, [331, corr.]. <em>Copies</em>: DBN, HH, LC, LD, NY.

	Issued by C.F., F.K. and L.C. Sanders.

10.221. <em>Orchid hybrids</em>. Sander's complete up-to-date list, containing the names and par-
entages of all the known hybrid orchids, whether introduced or artificially raised.
Arranged in tabular, alphabetical form, so that all hybrids, derived from each species or
hybrid, may be ascertained at a glance. Concise, reliable, and indispensable to the
amateur, the expert, and anyone who wishes to know all about the whole of the hybrid
orchids known to exist. Price 7/6. Sander &amp; Sons, St. Albans. All rights, reserved [1906].
Oct. (<em>Orch. hybr.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Mai 1906 (Nat. Nov. Jun(2) 1906), p. [i, iii], [1]-125. <em>Copy</em>: BR.
<em>Other issue</em>: 1913 (?; undated copy BR rd 18 Jun 1913), p. [i, iii], [1]-123, [125, err.].
	<em>Copies</em>: BR, USDA. – "price 12/6".

<em>Addenda to Sanders</em>' [sic] <em>list of Orchid hybrids 1921-1922-1923</em>. Printed in Belgium, Antwer-
	pen (Chs. Geo. Kohler ...) s.d., p. [i-iii], 226-281. Pagination continued from that of
	<em>Orch. hybr.</em> ed. 3, vol. 1, 1921. <em>Copy</em>: USDA.
<em>Second addenda to Sanders</em>' [sic] <em>list of Orchid hybrids 1924-1925-1926</em>. Printed in Belgium.
	Antwerpen (by Chs. Geo. Kohler ...) s.d., p. [1]-51. <em>Copy</em>: USDA.
<em>Note</em>: the publication of Sander's list of Orchid hybrids was continued after ed. 3. Our
	material is, however, too incomplete to be listed here.

Sanderson, John (1820/21-1881), Scottish journalist, trader, botanical collector and

secretary of the "Natal Times" Company 1851. (<em>J. Sanderson</em>).

Sandifort, Gerard (1779-1848), Dutch botanist and physician; prosector and adjunct
to his father, the professor of anatomy at the Leiden University 1799; Dr. med. ib. 1801;
honorary professor of anatomy 1801, ord. professor id. 1812, re-affirmed by the Dutch
government in 1815; in charge of the Leiden Botanical Garden 1819-1822. (<em>Sandif</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Aa 17: 86; BM 4: 1800; CSP 5: 392-393; Herder p. 152;

31 Jan 1779, d. 11 Mai 1848; by Simon Thomas; provides further biogr. refs.); PR 8027.

Sandstede, [Johann] Heinrich (1859-1951), German (Oldenburg) botanist; trained
as a baker in his father's bakery which he took over and managed until 1912; from then
on in retirement dedicating himself part of the time to lichenology; Dr. phil. h.c. Univ.
Münster 1930. (<em>Sandst</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B (rd 1931; Cladonia mainly destroyed), BREM (extant),
BRNU (fide GR, retained as war booty); further material at E, GFW, H, LD, W, WA;
also many lichens at Oldenburg, Staatliches Museum. – <em>Cladoniae exsiccatae</em>, 1918-1929,
13 fasc., 1886 nos., 52 sets (fasc. 1, nos. 1-123. Jun 1918, fasc. 2, nos. 124-248. Aug 1918;
see Sayre 1969). – Sets at AMD, B (in part extant), BP, BREM, BRNU, DR, DUKE,
FH, FR, G, GOET, H, HBG, KIEL, LD, LDS, M, MICH, NY, O, PC, PRC, S, STU,
TUR, UP S, W, WELC, WTU, WVA. – See Sandstede, <em>Cladoniae exsiccatae, Berichtigte
Uebersicht</em> Juli 1930, Westerstede, for a list of taxa (below).

PAGE: 34
HEADING: SANDSTEDE

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Grummann (p. 42-43) notes that Sandstede's herbarium was transported to
Czechoslovakia during World War II; it was confiscated in 1945 and is now said to be at
BRNU. We have no confirmation of this situation. The rich material at BREM, how-
ever, is extant; that received by B in 1931 is mainly destroyed.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 208 (b. 20 Mar 1859); Biol.-Dokum. 15:

Sandwith, Noel Yvri (1901-1965), English botanist; Keble Coll. Oxford BA 1926, MA
1929; at Royal Botanic Gardens Kew 1924-1965; collected in British Guyana 1929 and
1937; travelled in Albania, North Africa and South America; son of Mrs. C.I. Sandwith;
specialist on Bignoniaceae; enthusiastic host at Kew for all younger botanical workers on
the flora of tropical South America. (<em>Sandw</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BRISTM (adventive flora Bristol area), BRIST, K (types and
South American collections); further material at B (p.p. extant), BM (orig. Macedonia
1932; Albania 1933, 1935), CGE (S. Spain), F, FDG, G, GH, L, LE, MO, NY, OXF,
P, S, U, US, W. – Correspondence at K; letters from him e.g. in I.A.P.T. archives.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 208 (b. 8 Sep 1901); BJI 2: 152; BL 1: 261,

San Georgio, Anna di née Harley (1803-1874), British-born Italian botanist at
Florence. (<em>A. San Georgio</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: According to Carolina Lemon, daughter of Anna i San Georgio, the latter was
born as a daughter of "Lord Edoardo Oxford e da Giovanna Scott", obviously British
parents. Her father's name must have been Harley before his ennoblement. Her hus-

PAGE: 37
HEADING: SANGUIETTI

band was Giovanni Battista Rabitti, later comte di San-Georgio (see Saccardo 1: 226-
227 and 2: 96).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 209 (b. 31 Jul 1803, d. 18 Mai 1874); BB p.
269; BM 4: 1797; Jackson p. 9; Rehder 1: 72; Saccardo 1: 145, 226-227, 2: 90.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., J. Bot. 12: 256. 1874 (d.).

(Stabilimento di Giuseppe Pellas) 1870. Oct. (<em>Cat. poligl. piante</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1870, p. [1]-2, [i-iv, list authors, symbols], 3-747. <em>Copies</em>: FI, NY, USDA. – Latin
	versus Engl., Fr., Ital., Span., Germ., Sanskr., Beng., Hindust., Teling., Tamul, with
	converse indexes.
<em>Ref</em>.: Britten, J, J. Bot. 11: 280-283. 1873 (rev.).

San Giorgio (Sangiorgio), Paolo (1748-1816), Italian botanist and chemist; demon-
strator for chemistry at the Ospedale maggiore, Milano; in exile 1798-1806; subsequent-
ly teacher of natural history in Milano. (<em>San Giorgio</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

Sanguinetti, Pietro (1802-1868), Italian botanist; director of the botanical garden in
Rome 1851-1855 and professor of botany at the Sapienza 1851-1868. (<em>Sanguinetti</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: RO (Saccardo; see also Sr., Flora 1869); other material at P. –

Sanio, Carl Gustav (1832-1891), German (Eastern Prussian) botanist at Lyck; studied
botany and medicine at Königsberg University; with Alexander Braun at Berlin 1855-
1857; Dr. phil. Königsberg 1858; habil. id. 1858; lecturer 1859-1866; from 1866-1891
"Privatgelehrter" at Lyck; oustanding plant anatomist. (<em>Sanio</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: KBG (destroyed; first herbarium bought by R. Caspary 1866),
Danzig (destroyed; second herbarium, 1866-1891, acquired by the Westpreuss. Prov.
Mus.); further material at AK, B (mainly destr.), BR, GOET, H (Bryoph.), K, L, M,
OXF, P, PC, POZ (Bryoph.), S, WRSL. – Sanio's library was sold by Oswald Weigel,
Leipzig (1891). – 29 <em>letters</em> to Brotherus are at Helsinki Univ. Libr.; 10 <em>letters</em> to F.F.G.
Renauld at PC; <em>letters</em> to D.F.L. von Schlechtendal at HAL.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 53: 709-711. 1907; AG 2(1): 191; Barnhart 3: 209
(b. 5 Dec 1832, d. 3 Feb 1891); Biol.-Dokum. 15: 7843; BM 4: 1801; Bossert p. 381;
Clokie p. 237; CSP 5: 396, 8: 828, 11: 280, 12: 649, 18: 439-440; De Toni 1: cx; DSB 12:
99-100 (K. Mägdefrau); DTS 1: 253-254, 5: lii; Hegi 6(2): 774; Herder p. 434; IF p.
728; Kew 4: 591; KR p. 619; Moebius p. 204, 213, 215, 216, 218, 222; Morren ed. 10, p.
15; PR 8032-8033; Ratzeburg p. 449-450; Rehder 5: 757; SBC p. 131; Tucker 1: 621;
Urban-Berl. 272, 281, 312, 391.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bonplandia 4: 132. 1856; Bot. Centralbl. 46: 399. 1891 (d.); Bot. Gaz.
	16: 242. 1891 (library to be sold by Weigel); Bot. Jahrb. 14 (Beibl. 30): 7. 1891 (d.);
	Bot. Not. 1892: 47 (d.); Bot. Zeit. 16: 360. 1858 (habil. Königsberg), 49: 724. 1891
	(library for sale), 50: 356. 1892 (herb. for sale), 53: 216. 1895 (coll. for sale from
	estate); Flora 42: 15. 1859 (habil. Königsberg); Leopoldina 27: 106. 1891 (obit, not.);
	Nat. Nov. 13: 93. 1891 (d.); Österr. bot. Z. 41: 260. 1891; Rev. bryol. 2(2): 32. 1875
	(exchange requested).

<sm>NOTE</sm>; Sanio's fundamental contributions to wood anatomy are discussed by e.g. Sachs
(1875), Mägdefrau (DSB and 1973), F. Schmucker and G. Linnemann (1951) and by
T.E. Timell (1980) who provides bibliographical references. – Paul Sanio, about whom
we have no further details, published <em>Anatomie des Holzes einheimischer Waldbäume</em>, Progr.
Realschule auf der Burg, Königsberg i. Pr. 31: 1-5. 1878 and "31": [1]-8. 1880.

10.238. <em>Florula lyccensis</em>. Exhibens plantas phanerogamas cryptogamas vasculares et
characeas in circulo lyccensi libere crescentes adiectis adnotationibus in species et genera
nonnullis nec non plantarum rariorum locis natalibus. Dissertatio inauguralis botanica,
quam consensu et auctoritate gratiosi philosophorum ordinis in alma litterarum univer-
sitate Albertina regiomontana ut summi in ordine philosophorum honores rite sibi con-
cedantur die i.m. iunii a. mdccclviii. h. xi. l.c. publice defendet auctor Carolus Gustavus
Sanio borussus ... Halis Saxonum [Halle a.S.] (formis expressum Gebauerio-
Schwetschkianis) [1858]. Oct. (<em>Fl. lycc</em>).

	vitae on p. [41]-43.

Santapau, Hermenegild (1903-1970), Spanish-born clergyman and botanist; Dr. phil.
Gregorian Univ., Roma, 1927; to India 1928; studying botany in London 1936-1940;
professor of botany at St. Xavier's College, Bombay; 1940-1954 with the Botanical
Survey of India; from 1961-1968 as director; rector of St. Xavier's College, Bombay
1968-1970. (<em>Santapau</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BLAT (some types elsewhere but indicated in publications);
other material e.g. at BR and MO.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: IH 1 (ed. 4): 30, (ed. 6): 364, (ed. 7): 342, 2: (files);

	X awards; tributes; portr.).

Santesson, Carl Gustaf (1862-1939), Swedish botanist and pharmacologist; Dr. med.
Uppsala 1892; lecturer (1891) and extraordinary professor of pharmacodynamics and
pharmacognosy at the Karolinska Inst., Stockholm 1895-1909; ordinary professor from
1909-1927. (<em>C. Sant.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

Rolleston, J.D., Nature 144: 1039. 1939 (obit.).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Santessonia</em> M.E. Hale et G. Vobis (1978), <em>Santessoniolichen</em> Tomaselli et Ciferri
(1952) and <em>Santessoniomyces</em> Ciferri et Tomaselli (1953) were all named for R. Santesson
(1916-x), Swedish botanist.

falls outside the scope of TL-2; Grummann (Cat. p. 71) suggests the abbreviation R.

Limn. Inst. 1: 1-70. 1939.

Sántha, László (Ladislaus) (1886-1954), Hungarian lichenologist; Dr. phil. Budapest
1909; assistant at the Botanical Institute of the University of Budapest 1909; at the
Viticultural Institute 1910; in charge of the department of pathology of the Institute for
Plant Protection 1932; professor at the Horticultural and Agricultural College 1942;
director of the Viticultural Institute 1942-1946. (<em>Sántha</em>).

Santi, Georgio (1746-1822), Italian botanist; Dr. med. phil. Siena 1777; in Paris 1777-

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown (if any, possibly at SIENA).

Sapetza, Josef (1829-1868), Moravian botanist; ultimately high school teacher at
Rakovac nr. Karlstadt (Karlovac, Károlyváros) in Croatia (then a free royal city of
Hungary). (<em>Sapetza</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BRNU.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: BM 4: 1803; CSP 5: 404, 8: 831; Futak-Domin p. 518;
Klášterský p. 162 (b. 15 Mar 1829, d. 12 Jun 1868); PR 8037-8038; Rehder 1: 441; WU
28: 212-213. 1874.

Saporta, (Louis Charles Joseph) Gaston, marquis de (1823-1895), French
palaeobotanist of independent means, living at St. Zacharie (Var) near Aix-en-
Provence; corresponding member of the Académie des Sciences, 1877; specially interes-
ted in the Mesozoic. (<em>Saporta</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Some material at P and PC. – 30 <em>letters</em> to Malinvaud at P.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Andrews p. 325-326; Barnhart 3: 210 (b. 28 Jul 1823, d.

283, 12: 649, 18: 443-444; De Toni 1: cx; DSB 12: 104-105 (F. Stockmans); Frank

SBC p. 131; SIA 7230; TL-2/4416; see A.F. Marion; Tucker 1: 622, 3: 267.

Sarasin, [Carl] Friedrich ("Fritz") (1859-1942), Swiss naturalist; studied in Basel
and Würzburg; explored, with his cousin Paul Benedict Sarasin, Ceylon (1883-1886,
1890), and Celebes (1893-1896, 1902-1903); "Privatgelehrter" at Basel; from 1898 presi-
dent of the council for the Basel Museum f. Völkerkunde. (<em>Sarasin</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BAS. – Other material at B (mainly destroyed), H (Bryoph.), K,
P, Z.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 210 (b. 3 Dec 1859); BJI 2: 152; BL 1: 119,
316; BM 4: 1804-1805, 8: 1139; IH 1 (ed. 6): 364, (ed. 7): 342, 2: (files); Kelly p. 205;
SK 1: 460-463 (itin., portr.), 4: cxlvii, 103; Urban-Berl. p. 391.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Aellen, H., ed., Schweiz. Zeitgen.-Lex. 776, 1932.
Anon., Schweiz. Lex. 6: 822. 1948.
Bruckner, A., ed., Neue schweiz. Biogr. 448. s.d.

Poggendorff, J.C., Biogr.-lit. Handw.-Buch 4(2): 1307. 1904, 6(4): 2256. 1940, 7a(4): 25.
	1953 (b. 3 Dec 1859, d. 23 Mar 1942).
Sarasin, F., Aus einem glücklichen Leben. Biographische Notizen. Basel 1941, 47 p.
	(autobiogr., portr.).

	2 vols. Wiesbaden 1905.

Schaub, S., Viertel].-Schr. nat. Ges. Zürich 87: 520-524. 1942.
Sirks, M.J., Ind. natuurond. 173, 223, 225. 1915.
Zischka, G.A., Allg. Gelehrt.-Lex. 566. 1961.

<sm>FESTSCHRIFT</sm>: Verh. Naturf. Ges. Basel 40(2), 1929 (portr., dedication) commemorates at
the same time the zoologist Paul Benedict Sarasin (1856-1929) who died during the
preparation of the text for this publication honoring the two cousins. The biography of
P.B. Sarasin by Fritz Sarasin contains much autobiographical material.

Sarauw, Georg Frederik Ludvig (1862-1928), Danish botanist and forester; studied
botany and forestry at Copenhagen, München, Berlin, Paris 1881-1892; assistant at the
agronomical station at Rostock 1890-1894; assistant at the Copenhagen National
Museum 1894-1911; from 1912 in charge of the archeological department of Göteborgs
Museum (<em>Sarauw</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown; the collections of Vilhelmine Sarauw (x-1907)
(daughter of C.A.W. Sarauw) are at C.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 211 (b. 12 Nov 1862; d. 17 Feb 1928); Biol.-
Dokum. 15: 7848; Christiansen p. 319; Kelly p. 205; LS 23684-23686; Moebius p. 281;
Rehder 5: 758; Tucker 1: 622.

	livr. Bib. natl. 163: 36-37. 1943.

Thomsen, Th. (= Dehn-Nielsen, H.), Dansk biogr. leks. 20: 570-572. 1941.

Sargant, Ethel (1836-1918), English plant anatomist; studied at Cambridge 1881-
1884; from 1892-1893 at the Jodrell Laboratory, Kew, under D.H. Scott; from 1893-
1912 pursuing botanical research privately at her property at Reigate; from 1912-1914
at Cambridge; in war work 1914-1918. (<em>Sargant</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 211 (b. 28 Oct 1863, d. 16 Jan 1918); BB p.
269; CSP 18: 448; Desmond p. 543; Moebius p. 147.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Nature 100: 409, 428-429. 1918 (obit.), Science ser. 2. 47: 189. 1918

	bibl.); Ethel Sargant, Girton Rev. 1927 [8 p.] (reprint undated and not paginated;

Sargent, Charles Sprague (1841-1927), American (Bostonian) botanist and dendro-
logist; graduated from Harvard 1862; in the Civil War 1862-1865; travelled in Europe
1865-1868; professor of horticulture at Harvard 1870; Arnold professor of arboriculture
ib. 1879-1927; founder (1872) and first director of the Arnold Arboretum of Harvard
University 1872-1927; travelled and collected extensively in the United States, the West
Indies, Mexico and Japan; active conservationist; LL.D. h.c. Harvard 1901. (<em>Sarg</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: A and AAH; other material at E, GH, K, MO, NY, NYS, PH,
US. – Smithsonian Archives SIA 189, 220, 221, 222, 224, 227, 7004, 7177, 7230, 7272.
Correspondence and archives at A; 123 <em>letters</em> to W.G. Farlow at FH; other letters at
GH.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 6(2): 110; Backer p. 512; Barnhart 3: 211 (b. 24 Apr
1841, d. 23 Mar 1927); Biol.-Dokum. 15: 7848; BJI 2: 152; BL 1: 159, 317; Blunt p. 248-
249; BM 4: 1805-1806, 8: 1140; Bossert p. 348; Bret. p. 1049; CSP 11: 284, 18: 448-449;
DAB 16: 354-355; Ewan ed. 1: 72, 177, 205, 285, 297, 306, ed. 2: 193; GF p. 75; Herder
p. 381; Hirsch p. 260; Hortus 3: 1203; IH 1 (ed. 1): 68, (ed. 3): 78; Jackson p. 360; Kew
4: 597-598; Langman p. 673-674; Lenley p. 359; LS 23687-23688; Moebius p. 348;
Morren ed. 10, p. 122; MW p. 426-427; NI 1726-1729, see also 1: 150, 235-236; NW p.
57; PH p. 523 [index]; Rehder 5: 758-759; SK 1: 463; SO 495, 3512, 3513; TL-1/ 705;
TL-2 see J.S. Gamble, T. Nuttall; Tucker 1: 622-624, 677, 779, 2: xxxiv, 3: 267-268;
Zander ed. 10, p. 710-711, ed. 11, p. 811.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Amer. men Sci. 1: 279. 1906, 2: 408. 1910; Bot.Mag. Tokyo 4: 538-539. 1927,
	Bull. misc. Inf. Kew 1927: 221-223 (obit.); J. Bot. 61: 62. 1923; J. Forestry 25: 513-
	514. 1927 (obit.); Mitt. deut. dendr. Ges. 1917: 248 (portr.); Natl. cycl. Amer. biogr.
	13: 398. 1906; Nat. Nov. 33: 366. 1911 (Roy. Irish Acad., Dublin), 23: 425. 1901 (dr.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) <em>Garden and Forest</em>, 10 vols., 1888-1897, editor (Sargent contributed
367 articles).
(2) Editor, <em>Asa Gray, scientific papers</em>, 2 vols. 1889.
(3) A. Rehder, <em>Bradley bibliography</em>, 5 vols. 1911-1918, compiled under the direction of
C.S. Sargent.
(4) Editor, <em>Bulletin of popular Information</em>, Arnold Arb., Jamaica Plain, vols. 1-12, 1915-
1926.
(5) Editor, <em>Journal of the Arnold Arboretum</em> vols. 1-8(1), 1919-1927.
(6) Editor, E.J. Palmer, <em>Synopsis of North American Crataegi</em>, 1925, see TL-2/4: 30.
(7) Introduction to Ernest H. Wilson, A naturalist in Western China, 1913.

<sm>HANDWRITING</sm>: Bartonia 28: <em>pl. 7. 1957.</em>

<sm>NOTE</sm>: No relation of the horticulturist Henry Winthrop Sargent (1810-1882), owner of
the estate and garden "Wodenethe" on the Hudson from 1839; author of various books
on landscape gardening.

PAGE: 55
HEADING: SARGENT, C. S.

<em>6</em>(<em>3</em>): Nov 1905, Rh. 7(83): 192-219.
<em>Note</em>: We list only a few of Sargent's numerous publications on <em>Crataegus</em>. They are all
journal publications; several of them were reprinted with original pagination and a
special t.p. or a cover-t.p. – "Crataegus" was characteristic for Sargent who tried to
master the apomictic diversity of the genus before the genetic understanding of the
reproductive processes involved. Sutton (1970) states that 866 species were described
between 1896 and 1910, many of them by Sargent.

Sargent, Frederick LeRoy (1863-1928), American botanist; studied at the Lawrence
Science School, Harvard University 1883-1886; head Department of Botany, Madison,
Wisconsin 1886-1887; instructor in botany at the Medical School, Boston 1894-1895;
assistant Botanical Museum, Harvard University 1902-1904; later botany teacher at
Cambridge, Mass. (<em>F.L. Sargent</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: US; other material at GH, M, MIN, OKLA.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 211 (b. 25 Dec 1863, d. 16 Jan 1928);
Bossert p. 348; CSP 18: 449; GR p. 242; Kelly p. 205; Kew 4: 598; Lenley p. 359; LS
23690-23696; Rehder 5: 759; Tucker 1: 624.

Sarnthein, Ludwig (Graf) <em>von</em> (1861-1914), Transsilvania-born Austrian botanist; gov-
ernment administrator in Brixen, Triest (1892), Innsbruck (1905) and Ampezzo
(S.Tirol) (1906), ultimately as "Bezirkshauptman" (district governor). (<em>Sarnth</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: IBF; other material at A, AK, C, E, GOET, L, M (Lich.), W,
WRSL.

<sm>NAME</sm>: full name Ludwig, Graf von Sarnthein zu Rottenbuch, Kellerburg und
Kränzenstein.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 12(2): 682; Barnhart 3: 212 (b. 4 Jan 1861, d. 1 Feb
1914); BFM no. 825, 826, 829; Biol.-Dokum. 15: 1893; BL 2: 404, 714; BM 8: 1140;
Bossert p. 348; CSP 18: 449; DTS 1: 2524-255, 3: li, 6(4): 191-192; GR p. 439; GR, cat.
p. 71; Hawksworth p. 185; IH 1 (ed. 7): 342, 2: (in files); LS 6510, 23697-23698, 32442,
38779; Morren ed. 10, p. 37; Nordstedt suppl. p. 6; Saccardo 2: 97; SBC p. 131; TL-
2/1299, 5242; Tucker 1: 624 and add.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bot. Centralbl. 52: 450. 1892 (to Trient); Magy. bot. Lap. 13: 172. 1915
	(d.); Nat. Nov. 36: 288. 1914 (d.); Österr. bot. Z. 55: 123. 1905 (to Innsbruck), 56:
	491. 1906 (to Ampezzo), 64: 208. 1914 (d.).

Murr, J., Neue Übers. Farn Bl.-Pfl. Vorarlberg xxi. 1923.
Sayre, G., Bryologist 80: 517. 1977.
Wagenitz, G., Index coll. princ. herb. Gott. 143. 1982.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: with K.W. von Dalla Torre, <em>Fl. Tirol</em> 1900-1913, see TL-2/1299.

<sm>HANDWRITING</sm>: Candollea 33: 163-164. 1978.

Sartorelli, Giovanni Battista (1780-1853), Italian (Trentino) botanist; forestry in-
spector in Lecco and Bergamo. (<em>Sartorelli</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BASSA.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 212 (b. 11 Aug 1780, d. Mar 1853); BL 2:

<em>Publ</em>.: 1816, p. [i-vii], [1]-454. <em>Copies</em>: FI, G, HH, MO, NY.

Sartori, Franz (1782-1832), Austrian author and naturalist; Dr. med. Wien 1807; with
the "k.k. Bücher-Revisionsamt", from 1812-1832 as director; editor of various
magazines such as the Annalen der österreichischen Literatur und Kunst, Wiener
Literatur-Zeitung, Vaterländische Blätter and Österreichischer Kalender. (<em>F. Sartori</em>).

PAGE: 58
HEADING: SARTORI, F.

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: BM 4: 1809; Bossert p. 348; PR 8042, ed. 1: 8998;
Rehder 1: 439, 5: xxiii; Saccardo 1: 146-147; Tucker 1: 624; WU 28: 252-255 (bibl.).

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Brit. Mus. gen cat. print. books 213: 361. 1964.
Bamberger, R. &amp; F. Maier-Bruck, Österr. Lex. 2: 1006. 1966.

10.310. <em>Specimen nomenclaloris plantarum phaenogamarum in Styria</em> sponte crescentium ... ad-
junctis annotationibus ... Viennae [Wien] sumtibus Antonii Doll) 1808. Oct. (<em>Spec. nom.
pl. Styria</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1808, p. [1]-107. <em>Copies</em>: G, HH, NY.

Sartori, Joseph (1809-1880), German (Bavarian) botanist; came to Greece as court
pharmacist with King Otto, 1833; explored the Greek flora based at Nauplia 1833-1835
and at Athens 1835-1863; ultimately court physician to King Otto; returned to
München 1862; close associate of E. Boissier and Th. v. Heldreich. (<em>Sartori</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: material at ATHU (in Heldreich coll.), B (mainly destr.),
BASSA, BR, FI, G, KIEL, M, MW, P, W. – When leaving Athens in 1862 Sartori left
most of his collections at Athens. Many Sartori specimens were distributed by Th. v.
Heldreich.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 2(1): 663; Barnhart 3: 212 (b. 30 Jun 1809, d. 15
Sep 1880); DTS 2(1): 663, 5(2): 85, 12(3): 77; Hortus 3: 1203; Urban-Berl. 391.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bot. Not. 1881: 39; J. Bot. 9: 352. 1880 (obit.); Österr. bot. Z. 12: 410.
	1862 (returns to München), 30: 378. 1880 (d.); Bonplandia 10: 368. 1862.
Boissier, E., Fl. orient. 1: xiv. 1867.
Heldreich, Th. v., Bot. Centralbl. 3/4: 1182-1184. 1880 (obit.); Magy. növen. Lap. 4:
	144. 1880 (d.).
Landerer, X., Bonplandia 10: 368. 1862 (leaves Greece for political reasons).

Sartorius, Carl [Christian Wilhelm], (later: Carlos] (1796-1872), German (Hessen)
farmer and botanist; emigrated to Mexico circa 1825; from 1830 running a farm and
distillery at Mirador near Huatusco, Vera Cruz; plant collector and gracious host to
many travellers in Mexico; from 1846-1852 in Darmstadt. (<em>Sartorius</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: US (orig. herb.); other material at B (mainly destr.), BR, G,
GOET, K, L, M (lich.), W.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Bossert p. 348 (b. 31 Aug 1796, d. 16 Jan 1872), Ewan
ed. 1: 286; Urban-Berl. p. 391.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bull. Soc. bot. France 18: 238. 1872 (herb. to US).
Candolle, Alph. de, Phyographie 446. 1880.
Langman, I.K., Rev. Soc. mex. Hist. nat. 10: 329. 1949 (biogr., portr.).
Leon, N., Bibl. bot. mexic. 281-282, 345. 1895.
Pferdekamp, W., Auf Humboldts Spuren 153-173, 221. 1958.
Reichenbach, H.G., Bot. Zeit. 30: 509-510. 1872 (obit.).
Sabin, J., Dict. books America 18: 529-530. 1889 (bibl.).
Sartorius, C., Bonplandia 2: 56-60. 1854 ("Bilder aus Mexico").
Schultz, Bipont., C.H., Flora 39: 160. 1856 (has received rich material from Sartorius);
	Österr. bot. W. 6: 159. 1856 (id.).
Wagenitz, G., Index coll. princ. herb. Gott. 143. 1982.
Zittel, K.A. von, Gesch. Geol. Paläont. 491. 1899.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Published e.g. <em>Mexico als Ziel für deutsche Auswanderung</em>, Darmstadt 1850 (Spanish
transl. Mexico 1852), and <em>Mexico, Landschafsbilder und Skizzen aus dem Volksleben</em>,

HEADING: SARTORY

Darmstadt s.d., translated <em>Mexico. Landscapes and popular sketches</em>, New York 1858,
London 1859, <em>reprinted</em> as <em>Mexico about 1850</em>, Stuttgart 1961.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Sartorina</em> R.M. King et H.E. Robinson (1974).

Sartory, Auguste Theodore (1881-1950), French mycologist and bacteriologist; Dr.
Sci. Paris 1908; "chargé de cours" École supérieure de pharmacie de Nancy, later "chef
du service bactériologique" ib.; associate professor at the École supérieure de Pharmacie
de Strasbourg 1919; doyen ib. 1936; id. Clermont-Ferrand 1939-1945 (war-time locat-
ions of Strasbourg faculty); professor of microbiology at Strasbourg 1947-1950. (<em>Sartory</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 212; BM 8: 1140; Hawksworth p. 197; Kelly
p. 205-206; Kew 4: 599; LS 23708, 30794, 32045, 32112, 32617, 38488, 38780-38797,
32045, 32112, 32617, suppl. 1572, 1584, 2554, 3994; Stevenson p. 1257; TL-2/see Maire,
L.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Grand Larousse encycl. 9: 607. 1964.
Poggendorff, J.C., Biogr. lit. Handw.-Buch 6(4): 2286-2287. 1940 (bibl.).
Stein, H., ed., Cat. gén. libr. franç. 26: 740, 28: 476-477. 1924, 29: 852. 1927, 32: 697.
1934.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Sartorya</em> Vuillemin (1927) and the derived genus <em>Neosartorya</em> D. Malloch et
R.F. Cain (1972) were named for this author and his brother, R. Sartory.

Sartwell, Henry Parker (1792-1867), American botanist and physician; lic. med.
Oneida County Med. Soc. 1811; practicing at New Hartford, New York 1811-1812,
after the 1812 war at Springfield, N.Y. and Bethel; ultimately (1832-1867) at Penn
Yang, N.Y.; Dr. phil. h.c. Hamilton College, Clinton, N.Y. 1864. (<em>Sartwell</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Hamilton College, Clinton, N.Y., now at NY; further material at
BM, CGE, E, F, GH, K, L, LZ (destr.), M (lich.), MASS, MO, NY, NYS, OXF, P,PH,
US, WECO, WELC. – <em>Exsiccatae</em>: <em>Carices Americae septentrionalis exsiccatae</em>, 2 parts, 1848,
1850; sets e.g. at BM, G, NYS (in all 158 numbers). – <em>Letters</em> at GH.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 212 (b. 18 Apr 1792, d. 15 Nov 1867); BL 1:
203, 317; BM 4: 348; Clokie p. 237; DAB 16: 374; IH 1 (ed. 7): 342; Lenley p. 468

Sauerbeck, Friedrich Wilhelm (1801-1882), German (Baden) botanist; "Hofge-
richtsrath" (law court official) at Freiburg i.B.; ultimately "Oberlandesgerichtsrath" in
Karlsruhe. (<em>Sauerb</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Sauerbeck's own bryophyte herbarium was acquired by Jean
Nicolas Boulay and is now at LILLE; the "Jaeger and Sauerbeck" herbarium is at NY
(see under A. Jaeger); further Sauerbeck material is at FI and H.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 214 (d. 30 Aug 1882); BM 4: 1810; Morren
ed. 10, p. 25; SBC p. 131; TL-2/3263.

Saunders, William (1822-1900), Scottish horticulturist; Kew gardener; to the U.S.A.
1848; partner of T. Meehan 1854; naturalized U.S. citizen 1857; botanist and superin-
tendent of horticulture USDA, Washington 1862; planned Fairmount Park, Philadel-
phia; introduced the seedless (navel) orange into the United States. (<em>W. Saunders,
U.S.A.</em>).

HEADING: SAUNDERS, W. (CAN.)

Saunders, William of Canada (1836-1914), English-born botanist and agricultural
scientist; to Canada 1848; active as industrial pharmacist, entomologist and plant
breeder; owner of a private experimental farm from 1868; professor of materia medica
Western Univ., Ontario 1882-1886; director Experimental Farms Canada, 1886-1911;
originated the work which led to the development by his son, Charles Edward, of the
Marquis wheat; LL.D. Queen's (Can.) 1896, id. Toronto 1903.(<em>W. Saunders, Can.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 215 (b. 16 Jun 1836, d. 13 Sep 1914); BL 1:
143, 317; BM 8: 1141; CSP 5: 412, 12: 650, 651, 18: 459; DNB 17: 820-821; Desmond p.
544; LS 38802-38803; Rehder 5: 766; Tucker 1: 624-625.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Amer. men sci. ed. 1: 279-280. 1906; Canad. Entomologist 27(8): 197.
	1895 (portr., tribute); Encycl. canad. 237. 1972; Entom. News 25(10): 480. 1914 (d.);
	J. Amer. Pharm. Ass. 3(12): 1623-1624. 1914 (d., portr.); Proc. Trans. R. Soc.
	Canada ser. 3. 9: viii-x. 1916 (obit.); Who's who London 1909-1915; Who was who
	1897-1915: 629. 1935.

Saunders, William Wilson (1809-1879), English botanist, horticulturist and entomo-
logist; with the East India Company 1830-1832; underwriter at Lloyds, London 1832-
1873; treasurer Linnean Society, London 1861-1873; had large living collections of

PAGE: 69
HEADING: SAUNDERS, W. W.

plants at East Hill, Wandsworth, from 1857 at Hallfield, Reigate; from 1874 in retire-
ment at Raystead, Worthing. (<em>W.W. Saunders</em>).

auction (1873); Smithsonian Archives SIA 7112.

Saussure, Horace Bénédict de (1740-1799), Swiss (Genève) naturalist; professor of
philosophy at Genève 1762-1786; travelled extensively in the Alps and other parts of
Central and Southern Europe between 1758 and 1779, especially interested in geology
and meteorology; ascended Mont Blanc 1787. (<em>Saussure</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: G (see Briquet 1940); other material at BM.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 3: 53; Backer p. 513; Barnhart 3: 215 (b. 17 Feb

p. 733-734; DSB 12: 119-123. 1975 (A.V. Carozzi); Moebius p. 456; PR 8049-8050, ed.
1: 2105, 2474-2477, 9568; Quenstedt p. 376; Ratzeburg p. 450-451; Rehder 1: 129, 433;
Saccardo 1: 147, 2: 97; Tucker 1: 625.

Saussure, Nicolas Théodore de (1767-1845), Swiss (Genève) botanist and chemist,
son of Horace Bénédict de Saussure; scientist of independent means dedicating himself
entirely to his research. (<em>N.T. Saussure</em>).

Sauter, Anton [Eleutherius] (1800-1881), Austrian botanist and physician at
Salzburg; Dr. med. Wien 1826; physician in the St. Johannes hospital at Salzburg 1826-
1828; practicing physician at Kitzbühel 1828-1830; at Bregenz (city physician) 1830-
1831; regional physician at Zell am See 1831-1836, in Mittersill 1836-1839, Reid 1839-
1840 and from 1840-1848 in Steyr; from 1848-1871 regional physician at Salzburg.
(<em>Saut</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Museum f. Naturk. Salzburg (see ÖbZ 75: 194-195); BREG. –
Further material at BM, BR, C, E, FI, GFW, GLM, GOET, H, H-SOL, HAL, IBF,
JE, KIEL, L, LI, M, MW, REG, SAM, SZB, W, WAG, WRSL (these collections may
include those by Andreas and Ferdinand Sauter, see <em>Note</em>, below).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: A.E. Sauter's brother, Andreas Sauter (b. 20 Aug 1802, d. 15 Jul 1872) was also
an active botanist, forester at Zirl, Bozen and Ried, ultimately "Bergrath" in Hall.
Andreas S. distributed exsiccatae, e.g. <em>Decaden getrockneter Alpenpflanzen</em> and <em>Flora tirolensis
exsiccata alpina atque subalpina</em> dec. 1-6, 1830-1833. Ferdinand Sauter (b. 14 Dec 1835)
was a son of A.E. Sauter; he was also a practicing physician and an active botanist who
collected widely in Tirol and was especially interested in Bryophyta. The present data in
the Index herbariorum files do not allow us to differentiate between the three Sauters in
the listing of holdings by herbaria.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 3: 725, 12(1): 144, 12(2): 118; Backer p. 660;
Barnhart 3: 215 (b. 19 Apr 1800, d. 6 Apr 1881); BFM 846; Biol.-Dokum. 15: 7867; BM
4: 1812; Bossert p. 350; CSP 5: 416-417, 8: 837, 11: 289, 12: 651; De Toni 1: cx; DTS 1:
256-261, 6(4): 192 (bibl.); GR p. 439; GR, cat p. 71; Hegi 4(1): 375, 6(2): 1213; Hortus
3: 1203; IH 2: (files); 103; Jackson p. 269; Kew 4: 603; LS 23723-23739; MD p. 212;
Morren ed. 2, p. 14; Nordstedt p. 28; PR 8053-8054, 10632-10634, ed. 1: 9008; Rehder
5: 761; SBC p. 131; TL-2/2847; WU 28: 288-290. 1874.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bonplandia 4: 134. 1856, 8: 34. 1860; Bot. Not. 1882: 30 (d.); Bot. Zeit.
	39: 392. 1881 (d.), 6: 96. 1848 (app. Salzburg); Bull.Soc. bot. France 28 (bibl.): 139.
	1881; Flora 7: 607. 1824, 14: 133-137. 1881 (on exsicc. Andreas S.), 16: 236-238. 1833
	(id.), 31: 118. 1848 (to Salzburg), 46: 272. 1863, 64: 160. 1881 (d.); Hedwigia 20: 64.

HEADING: SAUVAGEAU

Sauvage, Charles [Philippe Felix] (1909-1980), French botanist; studied at the École
normale supérieure and the Faculté des Sciences, Paris; assistant for botany at the École
normale supérieure 1935-1938; head of the Laboratory for phanerogamy of the Institut
scientifiqiue chérifien, Rabat, Marocco, 1939-1962; director ib. 1960-1962; professor of
botany (titular) at the Université des Sciences du Languedoc, Montpellier, 1962-1965;
director of the Institut de botanique Montpellier 1965-1969; director of the Centre
d'études phytosociologiques ib. 1969-1974. (<em>Sauvage</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: RAB and MPU; duplicates e.g. at BR.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: IH (ed. 1): 82, (ed. 2): 102, (ed. 3): 129, (ed. 4): 143, 2:
(files); Roon p. 99.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Taxon 29: 701. 1980 (b. 14 Aug 1909, d. 13 Jun 1980); Who's who in
	France (Qui est qui en France), ed. 8: 1261-1262. 1967-1968, ed. 9: 1311. 1969-1970,
	ed. 10: 1417. 1971-1972.
Granel de Solignac, L. &amp; L. Bertrand, Naturalia monsp., Bot. 18: 285. 1967 (coll.
	MPU).
Sauvage, C., Information sent to the senior author 8 Sep 1956 (files I.A.P.T.; bibl.).
Sauvage, C. &amp; J. Vindt, Taxon 2: 7-9. 1953 (plan for <em>Flore du Maroc</em>, 1953-x).

Sauvageau, Camille [François] (1861-1936), French botanist; studied at Montpellier
(lic. sci. nat. 1884, agrégé 1884); assistant to Charles Flahault, Montpellier 1884-1888;
high school teacher at Bordeaux 1884-1885; worked with P. van Tieghem, Paris 1885-
1891; Dr. Sci. Paris 1891; lecturer Fac. Sci. Lyon 1892; professor at the Faculté des
Sciences, Lyon 1892; id. Bordeaux 1901-1932; prix Montagne 1915. (<em>Sauv</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: PC; further material at AHFH, BM, C, K, L. – 33 <em>letters</em> to W.G.
Farlow at FH.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 215 (b. 12 Mai 1861, d. 5 Aug 1936); BM 4:
1814, 8: 1142; Bossert p. 350; CSP 18: 462-463; De Toni 4: xlix-1; DSB 12: 124-126 (J.
Feldmann); Hirsch p. 260; Hortus 3: 1203; IH 1 (ed. 3): 119, (ed. 6): 364, (ed. 7): 342,
2: (files); Kew 4: 604; Langman p. 675; LS 23742-23747, 27802-27809, 38808-38809;
Moebius p. 88, 89, 90; Nordstedt p. 28, Rehder 5: 761; Stevenson p. 1257; Tucker 1:
625.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bot. Centralbl. 52: 287. 1892 (app. Lyon), 117: 96. 1911 (prix Des-
	mazières), 128: 112. 1915 (prix Montagne); Bull. Soc. bot. France 39 (bibl.): 192.
	1892 (app. Lyon), 45: 336 (app. Dijon), 494 (prix Gay). 1898; Hedwigia 38: (60).
	1899 (app. Dijon), 114 (prix Gay). 1899, 41: (51). 1902 (app. Bordeaux), 77: (109).
	1937 (d.); Index biogr. Acad. Sci., Paris 458. 1954; J. Bot., Morot 6: 347. 1892
	(mission to Montpellier), 12: 252. 1898 (app. Dijon), 15: cxviii. 1901 (app.
	Bordeaux); Nat. Nov. 20: 621. 1898 (app. Dijon), 24: 236. 1902 (app. Bordeaux); Qui
	êtes-vous 1924: 688-689; Rev. bryol. 21(1): 16. 1894 (prix Desmazières); Rev. gén.
	Bot. 48: 632. 1936 (d.).
Beauverd, G., Bull. Soc. bot. Genève ser. 2. 29: 141-142. 1938 (obit. not.).
Carazzi, D., Un botaniste gentilhomme (C. Sauvageau). Genève 1908, 14 p. (polemics
	on greening of Oysters).
Dangeard, P., Bull. Soc. bot. France 84: 13-18. 1937; Bull. Sta. biol. Arcachon 34: 5-59.
	1937 (obit., bibl., portr.).
Feldmann, J., <em>in</em> Hist. bot. France 212-217. 1954 (see also DSB).

Maire, R., Progr. conn. bot. Algérie 188-189. 1931.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Sauvageau received the Prix Desmazières of the Académie des Sciences Paris, in
