11.487. <em>Afrikanisches Skizzenbuch</em> Verschollene Merkwürdigkeiten ... Berlin (Deutsche
Buch-Gemeinschaft ...) [1925]. Oct. (<em>Afrik. Skizzenbuch</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1925 (p. 8: Sep 1925), p. [1]-312, [313]. <em>Copy</em>: B. – Contains an autobiography of
	S. on p. 9-24.

Schweinitz, Lewis David von (1780-1835), American botanist; educated in the
Moravian community at Nazareth, Pennsylvania, 1787-1798; with his family to
Germany 1798; at the theological college of Niesky (Upper Lusatia) 1798-1801; teacher
at the Niesky College 1801-1807; Moravian preacher at Gnadenburg (Silesia), 1807-
1808, id. at Gnadau (Saxony) 1808-1812; Dr. phil. Kiel 1817; administrator of the
church estates of the Moravian brethern in North Carolina; resident in Salem, North
Carolina 1812-1821; "proprietor of the church estates in the North" at Bethlehem,
Pennsylvania 1821-1835; "patron saint" of North American mycology. (<em>Schwein</em>.).

PAGE: 438
HEADING: SCHWEINITZ

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: PH (23.000, including his fungi); some fungi also at BM, BPI,
FH, CGE, K, NY, NYS, PH, UPS; further material at BR, CGE, CUP, DWC, E, FH,
H, LZ, M, NY, OXF, PC-Durand, PUR, UPS, W. – For Schweinitz's record books see
Pennell (1931). Various authors mention Schweinitz's "lamentable scheme ... in dis-
carding the collector's original labels in favor of his own copied tickets" (Ewan 1962).
Most of Schweinitz's books are at PH; for unpublished manuscripts and correspondence
(mostly also at PH) see below. The manuscript material may often help to determine
when and how a specimen was added to the herbarium, a circumstance especially im-
portant because of the above-mentioned discarding of original labels. A mss. <em>Index
phaenogamicae herbarii</em> (cat. of his herb.) in von Schweinitz's handwriting is at GH. –
<em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 16: 483-484 (by A.G. Rau); Ainsworth 314, 347
[index]; Barnhart 3: 250 (b. 13 Feb 1780, d. 8 Feb 1834); BM 4: 1877-1878; Bossert p.
357; Clokie p. 241; CSP 5: 593; DAB 16: 483-484; Frank 3 (Anh.): 95; GR 196, cat. p.
71; Hawksworth 185, 197; Herder p. 279; Hortus 3: 1203; IH (ed. 1): 76, (ed. 2): 96,
(ed. 3): 122, (ed. 6): 364, (ed. 7): 342, 2: (files); Kelly p. 209-210; KR p. 631; Lenley p.
337, 340, 348, 362, 363, 468 (Torrey corr.); LS 796, 24485-24490; ME 3: 651 (index);
NI 1820n, na; PH see p. xxiv; PR 8535-8537, 88, ed. 1: 127, 9484-9486; Rehder 1: 310;
SBC p. 132; Stevenson p. 1257; TL-1 /968a, 1212-1212b; TL-2/75, 3560, 4644 and see
indexes; Tucker 1: 14, 641, 3: 275; Zander ed. 10, p. 715, ed. 11, p. 816.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Ainsworth, G.C., Dict. fungi ed. 6. 522. 1971.
Allibone, S.A., Crit. dict. Engl. lit. 2: 1954. 1878.
Anon., Natl. cycl. Amer. biogr. 8: 380. 1898.
Arthur, J.C. &amp; G.R. Bisby, Proc. Amer. philos. Soc. 57: 172-292. 1918 (annotated
	transl. of S.'s papers on rusts).
Barnhart, J.H., Mem. Torrey bot. Club 16: 290-300. 1921 (biogr. notices persons ment-
	ioned in Schweinitz-Torrey corr.); Bartonia 16: 19-36. 1934 (botanical correspond-
	ents Schweinitz).
Benedict, D.M., Bartonia 16: 12-19. 1934 (on Schw. as a mycologist; list of books in his
	library).
Berkeley, M.J. &amp; M.A. Curtis, J. Acad. nat. Sci., Philadelphia 2: 277-294, <em>pl. 25.</em> Apr

(2) <em>A catalogue of plants collected in the North-Western Territory</em> by Mr. Thomas Say, in the

1825 (in London ed., 1825, 2 (app.): 105-123), see TL-2/3560 and R.L. Stuckey (1970).
(3) <em>Fungi, in</em> J. Torrey, <em>Catalogue of North American genera of plants ..., in</em> J. Lindley, <em>Intr.
nat. syst. bot.</em>, first Amer. ed. Dec 1831, TL-2/4644.

HEADING: SCHWEINITZ

<sm>HANDWRITING</sm>: Bartonia 28: <em>pl</em>. 7. 1957, Mycologia 41(4): 457. 1949.

<sm>MANUSCRIPTS AND LETTERS</sm>: (1) Most archival material concerning Schweinitz is at PH
(see PH p. xxiv, coll. 4, 130, 137, 248, 437, 438, 557, 657), e.g.:
	(a) <em>Synopsis plantarum americanorum</em>, 357 p. in PH coll. 130, item no. 3 (coll. 130 consists
	of 8 "synopses of various botanical groups").
	(b) Systematically arranged catalogue of the Schweinitz herbarium, 326 p., in PH
	coll. 137, item no. 12 (coll. 137 consists of 14 "herbarium catalogi and indexes").
(2) Several manuscripts which belonged to J. Torrey were given to Sullivant in 1860
and are now at FH. Among them a <em>Conspectus muscorum frondosorum americanorum herbarii</em>, a
list of 267 American musci with indication of which are in his herbarium; also a similar
mss. on Hepaticae and a diary of observations on cryptogams in 1821 (inf. G. Sayre).
(3) For the archival holdings of Schweinitz items at NY see Lenley 362, 363, 468
(Torrey corr.).
(4) <em>Correspondence</em> (published): with C.F. Denke (R.L. Stuckey &amp; J.R. Wehrmeister,
1979), E. Fries (CL. Shear 1902), A. Gray (J.L. Gray 1893; C.L. Shear 1905), C.H.
Mertens (G.H.M. Lawrence 1964), Th. Nuttall (J.E. Graustein 1967), D. Steinhauer
(R.L. Stuckey 1967), J. Torrey (C.L. Shear &amp; N.E. Stevens 1921 and see H.D. Rodgers,
1942).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Schweinitzia</em> S. Elliott ex T. Nuttall (1818); <em>Schweinitzia</em> Greville (1823);
<em>Schweinitzia</em> Massée (1895); <em>Schweinitziella</em> Spegazzini (1888).

11.488. <em>Conspectus fungorum in Lusatiae superioris agro niskiensi crescentium e methodo
Persooniana</em>. Cum tabulis xii aeneis pictis, species novas xciii sistentibus ... Lipsiae
[Leipzig] (sumtibus Kummerianis) 1805. Oct. (in fours). (<em>Consp. Jung. Lusat.</em>).

<em>Co-author</em>. Johannes Baptista von Albertini (1769-1831), see TL-1/p. 27 and no. 75. This
	is an amended entry. – For the part of Albertini in publishing the <em>Conspectus</em> see D.P.
	Rogers (1977, p. 235-236) and D.M. Benedict (1935).
<em>Publ</em>.: 1805 (p. xii: Mai 1804; Jenaische Allg. Lit.-Zeit. 14 Mar 1806), p. [i]-xxiv, [1]-
	376, <em>pl. 1-12</em> (col. copp. Schweinitz). <em>Copies</em>: BR, NY, PH, Stevenson; IDC 5284. –
	Survey of the fungi growing around Niesky in Upper Lusatia (not Nisko as err. stated
	sub TL-2/75), the seat of a sizeable colony of Moravian brethern of the Herrnhut
	group. The colony counted educational institutions, such as a teacher's college, a
	mission school and an elementary school for boys.

11.489. <em>Specimen florae Americae septentrionalis cryptogamicae</em>; sistens: muscos hepaticos huc
usque in Am. Sept. observatos. or: specimen of a systematic arrangement and descript-
ion of the cryptogamous plants of North-America: comprising a diagnostic description of
all the hepatic mosses hitherto observed in North-America; with ampler descriptions of a
number of new species by Lewis D. de Schweiniz [sic], D.P. Raleigh (printed by J.
Gales) 1821. Oct. (in fours). (<em>Spec. fl. Amer. crypt.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: probably Sep-Oct 1821 (letters Schweinitz to Torrey 19 Apr and 29 Oct 1821), p.
	[1]-27. <em>Copies</em>: FH, HH, NY, PH, US.
<em>Note</em>: see also <em>On two remarkable hepatic mosses found in North Carolina</em> ... J. Acad. nat. Sci.
	Philadelphia 2(2): 361-370. <em>1 pl</em>. 1822 [read 26 Nov 1822].

11.490. Art. x. – <em>Attempt of a monography of the Linnean genus Viola</em>, comprising all the
species hitherto observed in North-America; by Lewis D. de Schweinitz, of Salem, North
Carolina. [Amer. J. Sci. 5: 48-81. 1822]. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: Jun 1822 (journal issue Jun 1825; a footnote on p. 41 states of Schweinitz: "Now
	(April, 1822) of Bethlehem, Penn."), p. [48]-81. <em>Copies</em>: FI, US. – Reprinted with
	original pagination and to be cited from Amer. J. Sci. 5(1): 48-81. Jun 1822.

11.491. <em>Synopsis fungorum Carolinae superioris</em> secundum observationes Ludovici Davidis de
Scweinitz [sic] ... edita a D.F. Schwaegrichen. E commentariis Societatis Naturae Curi-
osorum lipsiensis excerpta. [Leipzig 1822]. Qu. (<em>Syn. fung. Carol. sup.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 18 Jul-15 Nov 1822 (see Rogers 1944 and 1977 for further details; the date of 15
	Nov is that of sending a copy from Bethlehem, Pa.; the copies must have been de-
	spatched to the author from Leipzig at least six weeks earlier which would put the

PAGE: 441
HEADING: SCHWEINITZ

	date of publication between 18 Jul and 1 Sep 1822; the publication came out after
	Persoon, Mycol. eur. vol. 1, and before E. Fries, Syst. mycol. 2(1)), p. [1]-105, <em>pl. 1-2</em>
	(col. copp. J.F. Schröter). <em>Copies</em>: FH, G, NY, PH, USDA; IDC 6313. – Preprinted or
	reprinted from Schr. naturf. Ges. Leipzig 1: 20-131, <em>pl. 1-2</em> (id.) and generic index on
	p. 231-232 (1822). – Schweinitz never saw a copy of the journal publication (Rogers
	1977); it contains on p. 20-27 an editorial introduction by Christian Friedrich
	Schwägrichen (1775-1853). The plates were made by J.F. Schröter for the editor
	Schwägrichen, and not by Schweinitz himself. – Reprints or tear-sheets with the
	journal pagination are e.g. at BR, FH, G, HH, MICH, MO, Stevenson.
<em>Facsimile ed</em>.: 1976, p. [i*-iv* new mat. facs. ed.], [i-iii, journal t.p. &amp; ded.], 20-131, <em>pl. 1-
	2.</em> ISBN 3-7682-1065-0. Bibliotheca mycologica Band 49 (J. Cramer in der A.R.
	Gantner Verlag Kommanditgesellschaft FL-9490, Vaduz, Liechtenstein). <em>Copy</em>: FAS.
	- See Taxon 26: 126. 1977.
<em>Ref</em>.: Arthur, J.C. &amp; G.R. Bibsy, Proc. Amer. philos. Soc. 57: 172-292. 1918 (on rusts in
	Synopsis; translation, notes).
	Rogers, D.P., Mycologia 36: 530. 1944 (comparison with Persoon, <em>Traité champ.
	comest</em>., see TL-2/7734.

11.493. <em>Description of a number of new American species of Sphaeriae</em>. By Lewis D. de
Schweinitz. Read February 15, 1825. [J. Acad. nat. Sci. Philadelphia 5: 3-16, <em>pl. 1-2.</em>
1825]. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: Jun 1825 (date of journal issue), p. 3-16, <em>pl. 1-2. Copy</em>: FH. – Reprinted with
	original pagination and to be cited from J. Acad. nat. Sci. Philadelphia 5: 3-16. <em>pl. 1-

11.494. <em>Monograph of the North American species of the genus Carex</em> by the Rev. L.D. de
Schweinitz. Edited by John Torrey. From vol. i. part ii of the Annals of the Lyceum of
natural History of New-York [sic]. New-York (printed by J. Seymour) 1825. Oct. (in
fours). (<em>Monogr. N. Amer. Carex</em>).

<em>Authorship</em>: John Torrey is listed as having edited the paper. However, in a note on p.
	[374], dated "Bethlehem, Penn. Dec. 20, 1825" von Schweinitz states that, in view of
	the amendments proposed by Torrey, "the Monograph should be considered and
	quoted in all respects, as the joint production of Dr. Torrey and myself. The cont-
	ents of the journal issue list the paper as "by L.D. Schweinitz and J. Torrey".
<em>Publ</em>.: late Dec 1825 or early 1826 (in view of the note on p. [374], dated 20 Dec 1825
	from Bethlehem, the earliest possible date would be very late in December but more
	likely early in the year 1826), cover-t.p., p. 283-373, [374, note], <em>pl. 24-28, 28bis</em>
	(uncol. copp. P. Maverick). <em>Copies</em>: Ewan, G, HH, MO, NY, PH; IDC 5161.
<em>Preliminary publ</em>.: <em>An analytical table to facilitate the determination of the hitherto observed North
	American species of the genus Carex</em>, Ann. Lyc. nat. Hist. New York 1(2): 62-64. Feb, 65-
	71. Mar 1824. – Reprint p. 62-71 at US.

11.495. Transactions of the American philosophical Society, held at Philadelphia, for
promoting useful knowledge. Vol. iv. new series. – part ii. Art. viii. – <em>Synopsis fungorum in
America boreali media degentium</em>. Secundum observationes Ludovici Davidis de Schweinitz.
Published by the Society. Philadelphia (printed by James Kay, Jun and Co. ...) 1832.
Qu. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 24 Mai-29 Aug 1832 (Rogers 1977, p. 238; the special cover of the issue for "Art.
	viii" is dated 1832; the volume as a whole is dated 1834; the mss. was submitted to the
	Society on 15 Apr 1831), cover-t.p., [141]-316, <em>pl. 19</em> (uncol.), [1, expl. pl.]. Published
	as and to be cited from Trans. Amer. philos. Soc. ser. 2. 4(2). 1832. <em>Copies</em> (journal
	issue): FH, G(2), HH, MO, NY, PH(3); IDC 7729. – Rogers (1977): "Perhaps 80%

PAGE: 442
HEADING: SCHWEINITZ

	of the species described as new really are new. This is a remarkable batting average
	..." See also R.H. Petersen (1980) and M.S. Stieber (1980).
<em>Facsimile ed</em>.: 1962, J. Cramer (Weinheim), Historiae naturalis classica tomus xxiv, p. [i-
	v], 141-316, <em>pl. 19</em>, [1]. <em>Copies</em>: B, BR, FAS. – The t.p. reproduced on p. [v] is that for
	the completed volume 4 of the new series, and is dated 1834. It should be noted that
	the actual date is 1832 as stated above.
<em>Ref</em>.: Arthur, J.C. &amp; G.R. Bisby, Proc. Amer. philos. Soc. 57: 172-292. 1918 (rusts;
	partial translation).
	Berkeley, M.J. &amp; M.A. Curtis, J. Acad. nat. Sci. Philadelphia ser. 2. 3: 205-224. 1856.

Schweizer, Jakob (1885-?), Swiss high school teacher and botanist. (<em>Schweizer</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

11.496. <em>Polyploidie und Geschlechterverteilung bei Splachnum sphaerium</em> (Linn. fil.) Swartz.

Schwencke, Martinus Wilhelmus (1 707-1 785), Dutch botanist and physician; pract-
icing in 's Gravenhage [The Hague]; kept a "hortus medicus" and gave botany courses
to surgeons and pharmacists. (<em>Schwencke</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown; some material in herb. Giseke at E.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 250 (d. 21 Jan 1785); Dryander 3: 102, 232,
459, 547; Hortus 3: 1204; Jackson p. 440; JW 4: 406; Oudemans 2: 236-237; PR 8538-
8541, ed. 1: 9487-9490; Rehder 5: 787; TL-2/9732.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anker, J., Centaurus 1: 251. 1951 (Oeder visits S's medical garden in the
	Hague).
Forbes, R.J., ed., Martinus van Marum 3: 128. 1971.
Heine, H., Kew. Bull. 16(3): 465-469. 1963 (on the correct spelling of <em>Schwenckia</em>).
Hulth, J.M. &amp; A.H. Uggia, Bref Skrifv. Linné 2(2):- 80, 81. 1943.
Kuijlen, J. et al., Paradisus batavus 25, 26, 98, 99, 207. 1983.
Sprengel, K.P.J., Gesch. Bot. 2: 376. 1818 (most impt. plants from his garden sold to
	Schönbrunn after his death).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: <em>Loci natales quarundam plantarum</em> circa Hagam comitis crescentium, <em>in</em>
D. de Gorter, <em>Fl. belg.</em> 1767, p. 382-389.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Microschwenckia</em> Bentham ex W.B. Hemsley (1882); <em>Protoschwenkia</em> Solereder
(1898); <em>Schwenkia</em> Linnaeus (1764); <em>Schwenkiopsis</em> Dammer (1916).

11.497. Mart. Guil. Schwencke ... <em>Officinalium plantarum catalogus</em>, quae in horto medico,
qui Hagae comitum est, aluntur. Hagae-Comitum (apud Petrum de Hondt) 1752. Oct.
(in fours). (<em>Off. pl. cat.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1752, p. [i]-vi, [1]-86. <em>Copies</em>: B-S, BR, Kon. Bibl. 's Gravenhage.

11.498. <em>Verhandeling over de</em> waare gedaante, aart en uytwerking' der <em>Cicuta aquatica</em>
Gesneri, of Groote-Waterscheerling: een gewas 't welk hier te lande in groote menigte
voortkoomt, en genuttigd van de doodelykste gevolgen is. Ten algemeenen nutte, in-
zonderheyd der geenen die ten plattenlande woonen, met de behulpmiddelen daarte-

PAGE: 443
HEADING: SCHWENDENER

gens, bschreeven, afgebeeld, en in 't licht gegeeven ... in 's Gravenhage (by Mattheus
Gaillard) 1756. Oct. (<em>Verh. Cicuta</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1756, p. [i]-xii, [13]-54, <em>4 pl</em>. (copp. engr.). <em>Copy</em>: Univ. Tilburg.

11.499. <em>Kruidkundige beschryving der in- en uit-landsche gewassen</em>, welke heedendaagsch meest
in gebruik zyn, door Mart. Wilh. Schwencke, med. doct. en professor in de botanie. In 's
Gravenhage (gedrukt voor den autheur, by Jacobus van Karnebeek) 1766. Oct. (<em>Kruidk.
beschr. gew.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1766, p. [i-viii], [1]-327, [328, err.], [appendix: [i-viii], <em>1 pl</em>. (col. copp.), <em>Novae
	plantae Schwenckia</em> by D. v. Royen]. <em>Copies</em>: B-S, BR, G, Kon.-Bibl. 's Gravenhage, L,
	P. – See our entry (TL-2/9732) on D. v. Royen, <em>Nov. pl. Schwenckia</em> 1766 for the
	appendix, and H. Heine (1963) for further details.
<em>Other ed</em>.: 1784, p. [i-viii], [1]-334. <em>Copy</em>: U. – <em>Kruidkundige beschryving</em> ... gedrukt voor
	den autheur". In 's Gravenhage (by Jacobus van Karnebeek, ...) 1784. Oct. – No
	binomials.

Schwendener, Simon (1829-1919), Swiss (St. Gallen) botanist; Dr. phil. Zürich 1856;
assistant with Carl Nägeli in Zürich 1856-1857; habil. Zürich 1857; with Nägeli to
München 1857; habil. München 1860; lecturer (Privatdocent) 1860-1867; professor of
botany at Basel 1867-1877; id. Tübingen 1877-1878; id. Berlin 1878-1909, as first profes-
sor of general botany and director of the Botanical Institute; outstanding morphologist
and physiologist; originator of the theory of the lichen symbiosis, the "mechanical prin-
ciple" in physiological plant anatomy and the mechanical theory of phyllotaxis.
(<em>Schwend</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Ainsworth p. 97-99, 318; Barnhart 3: 250 (b. 10 Feb
1829, 27 Mai 1919); Biol.-Dokum. 16: 8512; BJI 1: 54, 2: 162; BM 4: 1879-1880; Bossert
p. 357; Collander hist. p. 28, 34, 46; CSP 5: 596, 8: 906, 11: 365, 12: 668, 18: 638; De
Toni 1: cxiv, 2: lxxxiv; DSB 12: 255-256; Frank 3 (Anh.): 95; GR p. 634-635, <em>pl</em>. [5];

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: With C. Naegeli, <em>Das Mikroskop</em> 1865-1867, see TL-2/6614.

<sm>FESTSCHRIFT</sm>: <em>Botanische Untersuchungen</em> S. Schwendener zum 10. Februar 1899 darge-
bracht ... Berlin (Verlag von Gebrüder Borntraeger) 1899. Oct., portr. Schwendener,

PAGE: 445
HEADING: SCHWENDENER

p. [i]-vii, [1]-470, <em>pl. 1-14</em> (uncol.). <em>Copies</em>: B, G, PH, U (Bot. Zeit. 16 Apr 1899 (K.F.G.
Giesenhagen et al.) (Nat. Nov. Mar(2) 1899).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Schwendener's fundamental theory of the symbiotic nature of the lichens was first
published in an abstract of a lecture in Verh. Schweiz. naturf. Ges. 51: 88-90. 1867, not
provided with a title, but mostly referred to as "Über die Natur der Flechten". See also
Bot. Zeit. 26: 289-292. 1868, followed by the Algentyp. Flecht.-Gon. 1869. For contem-
porary criticism e.g. G.W. Koerber, <em>Abwehr Flechtentheorie</em> 1874, TL-2/3835.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Schwendenera</em> K. Schumann (1886); Simon Schwendener-Strasse, Berlin-
Dahlem.

11.525. Schwendeners Vorlesungen über <em>mechanische Probleme der Botanik</em> gehalten an der
Universität Berlin ... Leipzig (Verlag von Wilhelm Engelmann) 1909. Oct. (<em>Mech.
Probl. Bot.</em>).

<em>Editor</em>: Carl Holtermann (1866-1923).
<em>Publ</em>.: Jan 1909 (AbZ 15 Feb 1909), frontisp., portr. Schw., p. [i]-vi, [1]-134. <em>Copy</em>: U.

Schwertschlager, Joseph (1853-1924), German (Bavarian) geologist, botanist, high
school teacher and clergyman; ordained 1877; town chaplain of Monheim ca. 1877-
1880; studied philosophy and natural sciences at Würzburg; Dr. phil. ib. 1882; professor
of natural sciences at the episcopal Lyceum of Eichstätt 1882-1923. (<em>Schwertschlager</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Some material at STU. – Contributed to <em>Flora exsiccata bavarica</em>
(from 1898 onward; roses). – "Eine bedeutende Sammlung Solnhofener Fossilien bildet
heute die Sammlung der Phil.-theol. Hochschule Eichstätt". (Quenstedt).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 250 (b. 5 Jun 1853, d. 15 Nov 1924); Biol.-
Dokum. 16: 8535-8536; BJI 2: 162; BM 4: 1880, 8: 1168; Christiansen A780; CSP 18:
639; Quenstedt p. 391, 495; Rehder 2: 285, 3: 28; Tucker 1: 641, 3: 275.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Allg. bot. Z. 28/29: 56. 1925 (d.); Hedwigia 66: (55). 1926 (d.).
Lang, J., Ber. bayer. bot. Ges. 18: xv-xvi. 1925 (obit., portr.).
Mayr, F., <em>in</em> J. Schwertschlager, <em>Rosen Bayerns</em>, p. [iv], 1926.
Schmid, B. &amp; C. Thesing, Biologen-Kalender 1: 313-314. 1914.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Schwertschläger took his degree on a thesis <em>Kant und Helmholtz, erkenntnisstheoretisch
verglichen</em> (1882); published e.g. a topographical-geological work <em>Altmühltal und Altmühlge-
birge</em> and further geological-geomorphological papers, as well as <em>Philosophie der Natur</em>, ed.
1. 1921 (ed. 2, 1922).

high school teacher at Schweicheln 1901-1905; attended the Sondershausen music school
1905; subsequently conductor of theatre orchestras in Celle and Hannover, ultimately
music director in Göttingen; in retirement at Petershagen. (<em>Schwier</em>).

Scoffern, John (1814-1882), British physician, botanist and chemist; professor of

Scopoli, Joannes Antonius [Giovanni Antonio] (1723-1788), Austrian-Italian (Tirol-
born) physician, chemist and botanist; educated at Trento (Trient) and Innsbruck;
studied medicine at the Innsbruck medical college; Dr. med. 1743; practicing medicine
in Cavalese, Trento and Venice; from 1751-1753 in Graz and Seckau; state doctor's
examination Wien 1754; state physician at Idria (Krain, Carniola, now part of Slove-
nia) 1754-1767; professor of mineralogy and metallurgy at Schemnitz (Banska Štiav-
nica, now Czechoslovakia) 1767-1776; professor of chemistry and botany at Pavia 1776-
1788. (<em>Scop</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Scopoli herbarium specimens are at LINN (set received by Lin-
naeus), C (through M. Vahl), M (some lichens through J.C. Schreber), UPS (in herb.
Thunberg some plants grown in Upps. garden from seeds sent by S.), B (some material
in pre-1943 general herb., mainly destr.), MPU (through Lapeyrouse). – The Scopoli
material in the Moretti herbarium at PAV has not been retraced; R. Tomaselli stated in
1971 (in a letter to Yoshimura, fide P. Isoviita) that the material was destroyed during
World War II. – A possible further source of Scopoli material may be P-HAL.- Letters
at G.

<sm>NAME</sm>: We accept Joannes Antonius Scopoli as the most likely variant spelling of
Scopoli's name (German: Johann Anton, Italian: Giovanni Antonio). He signed himself
this way as is clear from the autograph reproduced by Voss (1882, p. 19). We have no
information on the names registered on baptism. Scopoli was born in Cavalese, Fleim-
serthal, Tirol, Austria (1723) now Val di Fiume, Trentino-Alto Adige, Italy. Scopoli's
father was called Franz Antonius.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 2(2): 177, 6(2): 951; Ainsworth p. 347 [index];
Backer p. 523; Barnhart 3: 250 (b. 3 Jun 1723, d. 8 Mai 1788); BM 4: 1883-1883, 8:
1169; Bossert p. 358; CSP 5: 602; Dawson p. 738, 761, 956 (index); Dryander 3: 23, 32,
47, 154, 205, 219, 227, 305, 326, 431, 434, 533, 638; DTS 1: 277, 6: 197; Frank 3 (Anh.):
95; GF p. 76; GR p. 440, <em>pl</em>. [<em>23</em>]; GR, cat. p. 71; Hawksworth p. 185, 197; Hegi 4(1):
410, 4(3): 1544, 5(4): 2569 6(1): 34; Herder p. 477 (index); Hortus 3: 1204; Jackson p.
265; Kanitz 51; Kelly p. 210; Lasègue p. 342, 358, 535; LS 24515-24522; NI 1822-1824;
PR 8552-8558, 10288, ed. 1: 9502-9508; Quenstedt p. 392; Rehder 5: 788; RS p. 141;

11.545. <em>Methodus plantarum</em> quam divina favente clementia decreto, authoritate, et con-
sensu illustrissimorum, perillustrium, magnificorum, spectabilium &amp; clarissimorum vir-
orum, perillustris, ac magnifici domini Universitatis rectoris, illustrissimi, magnifici, ac
clarissimi domini domini inclytae Facultatis medicae praesidis, perillustris spectabilis,
clarissimi, inclytae Facultas medica domini decani, venerabilis domini senioris, dd.
Sacrae caesareae Majestatis consiliariorum, ac archiatrorum, nec non clarissimorum dd.
professorum, adeoque totius amplissimi dd. medicorum collegii, in antiquissima, ac
celeberrima Universitate Viennensi, publicae disputationi subjecit Joannes Antonius
Scopoli, Tyrolensis, AA. LL. Philosophiae &amp; Medicinae Doctor. Die [26, mss] Mensis
[Martii h. 4., mss] Anno M.DCC.LIV. Viennae Austriae [Wien] [Typis, Joannis Petri
von Ghelen, ...) [1754]. Qu. (<em>Meth. pl</em>.).

<em>Publ</em>.: 25 Mar 1754, p. [1]-28. <em>Copies</em>: B-S, HH; IDC 5735. Dandy 1967: "Genera
	grouped, but mostly not individually defined, in a diagnostic key. The preface states
	that Tournefort's names are usually retained, so that those previously published with
	definitions by Tournefort, are validly published".

11.546. Joannis Antonii Scopoli ... <em>Flora carniolica</em> exhibens plantas carniolae indigenas
et distributas in classes naturales cum differentiis specificis, synonymis recentiorum, locis
natalibus, nominibus incolarum, observationibus selectis, viribus medicis. Viennae
[Wien] (sumptibus Joannis Thomae Trattner, ...) 1760. Oct. (<em>Fl. carniol</em>.).

<em>Ed. 1</em>: 15 Jun-21 Jul 1760 (p. viii: 15 Jun 1760; TL-1; letters van Swieten in Cobelli
	1895; Scopoli sent a copy to Linnaeus on 1 Sep 1760 (see E. Mayer 1972), p. [i-xxii],
	[1]-607. <em>Copies</em>: B-S, BR, FH, FI, G, HH, M, MICH, MO, NY, PH, Stevenson, U,
	USDA; IDC 5736. – A proposal by Wilmott (1935) to declare names, published in
	this work, as not validly published, was not accepted by the Amsterdam Botanical
	Congress (1935). The generic names first published here (after 1753) and provided
	with a description or reference to an earlier description are validly published by
	Scopoli; the circumscription and nomenclature of the genera is almost entirely Lin-
	naean; the classification is a natural one, close to that of Haller. There are no binary
	names for species.
<em>Ed. 2</em>: 1771-1772, 2 vols. "editio secunda aucta et reformata". Wien (Impensis Joannis
	Pauli Krauss). Oct. (a) vol. 1 dated 1771; vol. 2 dated 1772. <em>Copies</em>: BR, GZU, PH.
	(b) vol. 1 and 2 dated 1772. <em>Copies</em>: B, B-S, FH, FI, G, HH, M, MICH, MO, NY,
	PH, U, USDA.
	<em>1</em>: 1771, p. [i-lxxii], [1]-448, [1-16, index, errr.], <em>pl. 1-22, 22*, 23-32</em> (uncol. copp.).
	<em>1</em> (other issue): 1772, p. [i-lxxii], [1]-448, [1-16], <em>pl. 1-22, 22*, 23-32</em> (id.).
	<em>2</em>: Jan-Aug 1772 (GGA 5 Sep 1772), p. [i], [1]-496, <em>pl. 33-65.</em> This edition has binary
	names and is written in the Linnaean tradition in all other respects as well.
<em>Facsimile ed</em>.: 1972, Graz (Akademische Druck- u. Verlagsanstalt), introduction by Otto
	Guglia.
	<em>1</em>: [i]-xxiii, <em>pl. 1-7</em>, facsimile [i-lxxii], [1]-448.

PAGE: 456
HEADING: SCOPOLI

	<em>2</em>: [i-ii], facsimile [i], [1]-496, <em>pl. 1-22, 22*, 23-65.</em>
<em>Note</em>: Original paintings of fungi for Fl. carniolica at Paris, Mus. Hist. nat., see La
	Bibliofilia, Firenze, 56: 63. 1954.

11.551. <em>Deliciae florae et faunae insubricae</em> seu novae, aut minus cognitae species plantarum
et animalium quas in Insubria austriaca tarn spontaneas, quam exoticas vidit, descripsit,
et aeri incidi curavit Joannes Antonius Scopoli ... Pars I [-III] Ticini [Pavia] (ex
Typographia Reg. &amp; Imp. Monasterii S. Salvatoris ...) 1786 [-1788]. 3 vols. Fol. (<em>Delic.
fl. faun. insubr</em>.).

<em>1</em>: Jan-Jun 1786 (TL-1), p. [i*, iii*], i-ix, [1]-85, [86], <em>pl. 1-25</em> (uncol. copp.).
<em>2</em>: Feb-Mar 1787 (t.p. 1786; letters Scopoli to A. Castiglioni at PAV dated 4 Feb and 19
	Mar 1787; H.W. Lack), p. [i*, iii*], [i-ii], 1-115, <em>pl. 1-25.</em>
<em>3</em>: Jan-Sep 1788, p. [i*, iii*], [i-ii], 1-87, <em>pl. 1-25.</em>
<em>Copies</em>: BR, FI, G, MO, NY, PH, Teyler, USDA; IDC 5738. – Each volume starts off
	with an engraved t.p. [i*] and a second t.p. with frontisp. engraving [iii*]. – The
	plates are engravings of drawings by B. Bordiga, J. Cairoli, J.F. Chiesa and J.
	Lafranchi. – "Insubria" is cisalpine Gallia (Gallia transpadana, north of the Adda
	and Ticinus).

Scortechini, Benedetto (1845-1886), Italian clergyman and botanist; in Queensland,
Australia 1871-1884 as parish priest in Brisbane, Stanthorpe, Gympie and Roma; later
resident in the Logan District; from 1884-1886 Government botanist of Perak, conduct-
ing a botanical survey of the Straits Settlements, Malay Peninsula. (<em>Scortechini</em>).

PAGE: 457
HEADING: SCOTT, D. H.

Bertold, hence the eponym <em>Oberonia bertoldi</em> King.

Scott, Arthur Moreland (1888-1963), English civil engineer and amateur phycologist;
settled in the United States; ultimately in New Orleans; published on Desmidiaceae
from 1942 onward. (<em>A.M. Scott</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: FH, inch 63 original drawings. – Vials of Desmids went to G.W.
Prescott, East Lansing, Mich.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 251 (b. 25 Jan 1888); Bossert p. 358; Rehder
5: 788; Roon p. 101.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Prescott, G.W., Rev. algol. ser. 2. 7(2): 119-121. 1964 (obit., portr., bibl.).
Scott, A.M., Private comm. to senior author 1957 (list of publ. from 1942).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Amscottia</em> Grönblad (1954); <em>Scottia</em> Grönblad (1954).

Scott, Dukinfield Henry (1854-1934), British palaeobotanist; BA Oxford 1876; Dr.
phil. Würzburg 1881 (with J. Sachs); lecturer University College London 1882-1884;
assistant professor of botany Royal College of Science, London 1885-1892; hon. keeper
Jodrell Laboratory, Kew 1892-1906; in retirement at Oakley nr Basingstoke; FRS 1894;
Royal medal 1906, Darwin medal 1926, gold medal Linnean Soc. 1928. (<em>D.H. Scott</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BM (Geol. Dept.); further fossil material in NMW. – Letters at
FH, G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Andrews p. 329-330; Barnhart 3: 251 (b. 28 Nov 1854,
d. 29 Jan 1934); BJI 1: 54, 2: 162; BM 4: 1885, 8: 1170; CSP 11: 370, 18: 643-644;
Desmond p. 547; De Toni 1: cxv; DNB 1931-1940: 796-797; DSB 12: 258-260 (C.W.
Wardlaw); KR p. 632; LS 24523, 39089; Moebius p. 143, 144, 381; Quenstedt p. 392;
Rehder 5: 789; Tucker 1: 642, 3: 275.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Andrews, H.N., The fossil hunters 18, 97-100, 380. 1980.

HEADING: SCOTT, D. H.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: D.H. Scott married (1887) Henderina Victoria Klaassen (x-1929). Mrs. Scott was
also a botanist and drew a number of illustrations for her husband's <em>Intr. struct. bot.</em> and
<em>Slud. foss. bot</em>.; she was one of the earliest Lady-Fellows of the Linnean Society of London
(1905), see Desmond p. 547 and A.R. Rendle, J. Bot. 67: 57. 1929.

Scott-Elliot, George Francis (1862-1934), India-born British botanist; BA Cam-
bridge 1882; botanist on the French and English Delimitation Commission of the Sierra
Leone Boundary 1891-1892; in East Africa 1893-1894; lecturer in botany Glasgow
Royal Technical College 1896-1904. (<em>Scott-Elliot</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Mainly at BM and K (3251 W. Afr. and mss.); further material
at A, B (mainly destr.), CAL, E, GH, LE, MO, MPU (lich.), NH, NY, P. – Letters at
G.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: First listed by us as Elliott [sic, error], George Francis Scott in TL-2/1: 740-741.
This is a corrected entry. Often listed under Elliot, but since the author wrote his name
"G.F. Scott-Elliot" on the title-page of his <em>Fl. Dumfriesshire</em> we treat him here under
Scott-Elliot.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 1: 504; BL 1: 53, 294, 2: 292, 299, 650; BM 2:
522, 6: 299; CSP 14: 820-821; Desmond p. 548 (b. 6 Jan 1862, d. 20 Jun 1934); GR p.

Scouler, John (1804-1871), Scottish geologist and botanist; surgeon and naturalist on
the voyage to Columbia River (American Northwest) 1824-1825 with David Douglas;
travelled to Calcutta via the Cape 1826; professor of geology Glasgow 1829-1833; profes-
sor of geology, zoology and botany to the Royal Dublin Society 1833-1854. (<em>Scouler</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: K (N.W. America), GGO (algae; Scottish and Irish herbarium);
further material at BM, DBN, E (inch Calcutta Voy.), GH, NY, OXF, TCD.

HEADING: SCRIBA

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 523; Barnhart 3: 252; BB p. 271; Clokie p. 241;

1060-1061); Lasègue p. 194, 453, 504; LS 468 (John Torrey corr.); ME 3: 397; PR 1196.

Scriba, Julius [Karl] (1848-1905), German (Hessen) physician and botanist; Dr. med.

Scriba, Ludwig Philipp Karl (1847-1933), German (Hessen) mechanical engineer
and lichenologist; studied engineering at Zürich (exam. 1867); engineer in various fac-
tories in Bremen, Berlin, London and Frankfurt a.M.; started the Höchster Giessereien
L. Scriba in 1878; Dr. h.c. Frankfurt a. Main 1927. (<em>L. Scriba</em>).

Scully, Reginald William (1858-1935), Irish botanist; studied medicine but never
practiced, dedicating himself to botany. (<em>Scully</em>).

Seaver, Fred Jay (1877-1970), American mycologist; MS State Univ. Iowa 1904; as-
sistant Biology Dept. Iowa City 1904-1905; instructor of biology Iowa Wesleyan Univ.
1905-1906; at the New York Botanical Garden 1906-1907; assistant professor of biology
Fargo, North Dakota and mycologist to the Fargo Experiment Station 1907-1908; again
at the New York botanical Garden from 1908; Dr. phil. Iowa 1912; director of labora-
tories at NY 1908-1911; curator 1912-1943, head curator 1943-1948, from 1948-1970
curator emeritus; Dr. Sci. h.c. Sioux City, Iowa 1931. (<em>Seaver</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: NY. – Seaver left library, collections of fungi and other mycolog-
ical data to NY on retirement (1943); further herbarium material at DPU, IA
(Discomycetes), K and OSC.
<em>Exsiccatae</em>: (1) With Herbert Floyd Bergman (1883-?) <em>North Dakota fungi</em>, fasc. 1-2, nos. 1-
40, Feb and Aug 1908. Sets at BPI, CUP, F, FH, H, MICH, NDA, NY, OS. (2) With
Guy West Wilson (1877-?), <em>Ascomyctes and lower fungi</em>, fasc. 1-4, nos. 1-100, 1907-1909,
sets at BPI, CUP, FH, H, ISC, MASS, MU, NHES, NY, OC, OS, TRTC, VT. – See
Stevenson (1971). – Letters to W.G. Farlow at FH; other letters at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 254 (b. 14 Mar 1877); BM 4: 1889; Bossert
p. 359; Ewan ed. 1: 158, 302, 304, ed. 2: 198; Hawksworth p. 186; Hirsch p. 270; IF (ed.
2): 88, (ed. 3): 111, (ed. 6): 364, (ed. 7): 342; Kelly p. 210-211, 257; Lenley p. 364-365;
LS 24565-24567, 39120-39135, 40630-40631; suppl. p. 25134-25194; Stevenson p. 1257;
TL-2/781, 788, 1142, see J.F. Brenckle; Urban-Berl. p. 396.

	romana s.l. et d. 24 p. Oct (n.v.).
<em>Ref</em>.: Sprengel, K.P.J., Neu. Entd. 2:244-248. 1821.
	Treviranus, L.C., Gött. gel. Anz. 1819 (204): 2033-2040. 23 Dec 1819 (rev.).

dent of N.J. von Jacquin. (<em>Sebeòk</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

	<em>Crambe tataria</em> dissertatio inauguralis medica publicae disquisitioni submissa ab Alex-
	andre Sebéok [sic] de Szent-Miklòs nobili hungaro. Viennae 5. die Junii 1779.
	Aucta".
<em>Note</em>: Kanitz (no. 58): "... es liegt kaum eine Grund vor, diese Arbeit Jacquin zuzusch-
	reiben, da sie kaum den Vergleich mit ähnlichen Arbeiten des grossen Meisters aus-
	hält, und andererseits auf gewisse Volksgebräuche hingewiesen wird, die Jacquin
	schwerlich gekannt haben mag".

Sebert, Hippolyte (1839-1930), French marine officer and wood technologist;
educated at the École Polytechnique (1860); in New Caledonia before 1870; with the
staff of the artillery of the Right Bank, Paris, 1870-1871; Inspector of various marine
establishments in France from 1871. (<em>Sebert</em>).

Academy for fine arts; with Th. Kotschy in Asia minor 1859; artist for <em>Flora brasiliensis</em>
and for Schott's works on Aroids. (<em>Seboth</em>).

Seckt, [Heinrich Karl Felix] Hans (1879-1953), German (Berlin)-born botanist who
emigrated to Argentina; Dr. phil. Berlin 1901; assistant at the Institute for plant physi-
ology Berlin 1901-1906; professor at the "Instituto nacional del professorado sec-
undario" in Buenos Aires 1906-1920; professor of botany at the University of Córdoba
1920-1947. (<em>Seckt</em>).

Secretan, [Gabriel-Abraam-Samuel-Jean-] Louis (1758-1839), Swiss botanist, lawyer
and statesman; Dr. jur. Tübingen 1780; lawyer at Lausanne; served in various political
functions from 1798. (<em>Secr</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: LAU (Wilczek 1937); neither herbarium specimens nor drawings
of his fungi are known to be extant. – Letters at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Ainsworth p. 226, 314; Barnhart 3: 254 (b. 5 Sep 1758, d.

	"Mycographie suisse" ?).

11.595. <em>Mycographie suisse</em>, ou description des champignons qui croissent en Suisse, parti-
culièrement dans le canton de Vaud, aux environs de Lausanne ... Genève (imprimerie
de P.A. Bonnant, ...) 3 vols. Oct. (<em>Mycogr. suisse</em>).

<em>1</em>: 1833, p. [i]-lv, [1]-522.
<em>2</em>: 1833, p. [i, iii], [1]-576.
<em>3</em>: 1833 (Hinrichs 9-15 Feb 1834), p. [i]-viii, [1]-759, [760, err.], [1]-95 index.
<em>Copies</em>: B, BR, FH, G, M, MICH, MO, NY, Stevenson, USDA; IDC 6314.
<em>Note</em>: See Int. Code bot. Nom. Art. 23.6, example 10 under c: "Secretan (Mycographie
	suisse, 1833) introduced a large number of new specific names, more than half of
	them not binomials, e.g. <em>Agaricus albus corticus, Boletus testaceus scaber, Boletus aureus carne
	lutea</em>. He is therefore considered not to have consistently used the Linnaean system of

PAGE: 473
HEADING: SEELIGER

	binary nomenclature and none of the specific names, even those with a single epithet,
	in this work are validly published".
<em>Ref</em>.: M., Flora 17(1) Lit. 6: 90-95. 7 Mai 1834 (rev.).

Sedgwick, Leonard John (1883-1925), British botanist; B.A. Cambridge 1905; in the
Indian civil service from 1907. (<em>Sedgwick</em>).

Seeland, Hermann (1868-1954), German (Hannoverian) botanist and clergyman at
Ruthe, Celle, Hannover and, from 1932, at Hildesheim. (<em>Seeland</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: GOET. – The Seeland herbarium itself was for the greater part
destroyed in 1945.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: BFM 390, 399, 400; Biol.-Dokum. 16: 8563; BJI 2: 162.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Hiltermann, H., Ber. naturh. Ges. Hannover 102: 5-6. 1954 (obit., portr.,
	bibl).
Oberschelp, R., ed., Gesamtverz. deut. Schriftt. 121: 3-4. 1980 (publ. 1911-1954).
Wagenitz, G., Index coll. princ. herb. Gott. 154. 1982.

<sm>HANDWRITING</sm>: Wagenitz, G., Index coll. princ. herb. Gott. 211. 1982.

Gerstenberg) 1929. Oct. (<em>Orch. Hildesheim</em>).

Seeliger, Rudolf (1889-1943), German (Posen-born) botanist, phytopathologist and
geneticist; Dr. phil. Göttingen 1911; assistant at the "Biologische Anstalt für Land- und
Forstwirtschaft" Berlin-Dahlem 1911-1920 (on active service 1914-1918) at the

PAGE: 474
HEADING: SEELIGER

Naumburg/Saale branch office of the "Biologische Anstalt" 1920-1924; from 1924-1940
director of the laboratory for wine- and apple culture; again on active service 1940; fell
at Stalingrad 1943. (<em>Seeliger</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown. – Letters at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 255 (b. 26 Jun 1889); Biol.-Dokum. 16:
8565, 8567-8568; BM 4: 1892; Hirsch p. 270; LS suppl. 25203-25205; MW p. 443;
Tucker 3: 276.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Gollmick, F., Ber. deut. bot. Ges. 68a: 257-258. 1955 (obit., portr.).
Verdoorn, F., ed., Chron. bot. 1: 132. 1935, 2: 161. 1936, 3: 124. 1937.

Seemann, Berthold [Carl] (1825-1871), German (Hannover) botanist, publisher and
traveller; trained to be a botanical collector at Kew 1844-1846; naturalist to the
"Herald" 1847-1851; Dr. phil. h.c. Göttingen 1853; editor of "Bonplandia" 1853-1862;
botanised in the Fiji Islands 1860; editor of the Journal of Botany 1863-1869 (1871);
travelled in Venezuela 1864; in Nicaragua and Panama 1866-1871; died as director of a
gold-mining company in Nicaragua. (<em>Seem</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: The main set of most of Seemann's collections is at BM (see
Murray 1904), however, the first set of Fiji material is at K (over 1000) with duplicates
in BM (Fiji, 594) and further material in A, AMES, C, CAL, CGE, DPU, DUKE, E,
FI, G, GH, GOET, H, K, L, LD, MEDEL, MEL, MO, NY, OXF, P, S, TCD, US, W.
The "study set" including the types of the <em>Bot. Voy. Herald</em> is at BM (2000, acquired
1868) with an important set also at K. –For discrepancies between the labels and the
Bot. Voy. Herald see Radlkofer, Monogr. Serjania, p. 55. – <em>Letters</em> and mss. (incl. those
from the "Herald") at K. – <em>Field notes</em> at US (SIA); <em>letters</em> to F.A.W. Miquel at U; other
letters at G, GH.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 33: 581-584 (E. Wunschman); AG 3: 592, 593;
Backer p. 525; BB p. 271-272; Biol.-Dokum. 16: 8568 (one entry, sic); BL 1: 108, 132,
153, 318; BM 4: 1892; Bossert p. 359; Bret. p. 384-386; Clokie p. 241; CSP 5: 622-623, 8:
926-927, 12: 671; Desmond p. 550; DNB 51: 194-195 (17: 1132-1133) (G.S. Boulger);
Frank 3 (Anh.): 95; GF p. 76; GR p. 137-138; Herder p. 477 [index]; Hortus 3: 1204;
Jackson p. 11, 133, 139, 215, 224, 240, 404, 473; Kelly p. 211; KR p. 632; Langman p.
690-692; LS 24579; ME 3: 652; MW p. 443; NI 1827-1828; PR 8573-8583; Rehder 5:
790-791; RS p. 141; SBC p. 132; SIA 1010014; SK 1: 481 (coll.), 4: ccxii, 8: lxxxviii;
TL-1/1218-1221; TL-2/2417, 3690, and see indexes for cross-refs.; Tucker 1: 643, 3: 276;
Urban-Berl. p. 313, 396; Zander ed. 10, p. 715, ed. 11, p. 816.

Reichenbach, H.G., Bot. Zeit. 30: 503-510. 1872 (critical obituary; named a <em>Dendrobium</em>
	collected by Seemann <em>D. mohlianum</em>, after Mohl who had been severely attacked by S.
	in Bonplandia; "lacked a solid foundation in botany", was a poor collector but a good
	popular writer; opponent of Darwin, good musician; "Autor zu sein war seine
	Leidenschaft").
Sabin, J., Dict. books Amer. 9: 513. 1877, 14: 218. 1884, 15: 218. 1885, 19: 225-226.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Editor and translator of F.H. v. Kittlitz, <em>Twenty-four views of the
vegetation ... of the Pacific</em> 1861, see TL-2/3690. Was published 1-14 Aug 1862 fide
Seemann, Bonplandia 9: 233. 1861 ("Vorige Woche").

TL-2/2417. Additional copy seen: USDA. – Brief history of the book, mainly taken from
the preface, evidently by B.C. Seemann, in Bonplandia 10: 100-102. 1862.
(3) Editor, <em>Bonplandia</em> 1-10, 1853-1862, see below.
(4) Editor, <em>Journal of Botany</em> 1-7, 1863-1869, see below.

11.601. <em>The botany of the voyage of H.M.S. Herald</em>, under the command of Captain Henry
Kellett, R.N., C.B., during the years 1845-51. Published under the authority of the
Lords Commissionars of the Admiralty by Berthold Seemann, ... naturalist of the expe-
dition ... London (Lovell Reeve, ...) 1852-1857. Qu. (<em>Bot. voy. Herald</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: in 10 parts, 1852-1857 (see below), p. [i]-vi, [5]-483, <em>pl. 1</em> (frontisp.), <em>2-45, 46/47,
	48-100</em> (uncol. liths., mostly by W. Fitch, some by J.D. Hooker). <em>Copies</em>: B-S, BR, FI(1-
	4), HH, MO, NY, PH, Teyler, USDA; IDC 5739. – <em>Plates 11</em> and <em>12</em> are maps.
	The BR copy of part 1 has a preliminary t.p., dated 1852, and a dedication to Henry
	Kellett as p. [1] and [3]; the Summary of the Voyage starts on p. [5]; the last part
	(10) contained the definitive t.p. with new preface, in all vi pages, which accounts for
	the formula "[i]-vi, [5]". – For the sources of the dates and for the list below see TL-
	1/1218. Plates [11] and [12], unnumbered, are maps of "W. Esquimaux-land" and
	Panama.

part	pages	plates	dates
--------------------------------------
1	5-56	1-10	Apr 1852
2	57-80	11-20	Aug 1852
3	81-120	21-30	Nov 1853
4	121-160	31-40	Feb 1854
5	161-200	41-50	Jul 1854
6	201-253	51-60	late 1854 (v. early 1855?)
7, 8	255-320	61-80	1856
9	321-360	81-90	Dec 1856
10	361-483,
i-vi	91-100	Mai-Jun 1857

Seemann sent part 1 [only] to Miquel on 17 Aug 1852. The last part included 16 pages
to be substituted for pages previously published: 19-20, 107-108, 163-164, 203-204, 253-
254, 279-280, 319-320, 345-346. Page 254 was blank as first issued but the 1857 reissue
had final additions and corrections to the entire volume.
<em>Collaborators</em>: Babington, Churchill (1821-1899), <em>Lichens</em>, p. 47-49, 246-248, 344-345, 432.
	Bentham, George (1800-1884), <em>Leguminosae</em>, p. 106, 176, 187, <em>Scrophularineae, Labiatae</em>.
	Grisebach, August Heinrich Rudolph (1814-1879), <em>Gentianaceae</em> p. 169-170, 318-319.
	Harvey, William Henry (1811-1866), <em>Algae</em> p. 49-50.

	Miers, John (1789-1879) <em>Menispermaceae</em> p. 76-78, <em>Solanaceae</em> p. 172-176.

11.603. <em>Bonplandia</em>. Zeitschrift für die gesammte Botanik. Officielles Organ der K.L.-C.
Akademie der Naturforscher. Herausgegeben von Wilhelm E.G. Seemann, ... Berthold
Seemann, ... "Nunquam otiosus" i.[-x.] Jahrgang. Hannover (Verlag von Carl
Rümpler), London (Williams and Norgate, ...), Paris (Fr. Klincksieck, ...) 1853-1862,
10 vols. Qu. (<em>Bonplandia</em>).

<em>Co-editor</em>: Wilhelm Eduard Gottfried Seemann (x-1868), brother of B.C. Seemann. <em>Note</em>:
	the front pages of the individual, two-weekly issues of vols. 1-3 mention only Berthold
	Seemann as editor, whereas both are mentioned on the volume t.p.-'s. From vol. 4
	onward both are mentioned as editors in each number.
<em>1</em>: 1853, 25 nos. published on the first and fifteenth of each month; nos. 1 &amp; 2 on 1 Jan),
	p. [i]-vii, [1]-262. – Heading on issues for 1 Jan-15 Jun 1853: ... Zeitschrift für
	angewandte Botanik; from 1 Jul onward as on vol. t.p.: "Zeitschrift für die gesammte
	Botanik ... Naturforscher". On p. 1: "Diese Zeitung soll dem praktischen Leben
	gewidmet sein ..."
<em>2</em>: 1854, 24 nos. (id.), p. [i]-viii, [1]-296, <em>pl. 1.</em>
<em>3</em>: 1855, 24 nos. (id.), p. [i]-vi, [1]-346, <em>pl. 1-3.</em>
<em>4</em>: 1856, 24 nos. (id.), p. [i]-viii, [1]-400, frontisp. portrait of A. Bonpland. – Issue titles
	have from no. 1/2, 15 Jan 1856 onward: "Redaction: Berthold Seemann in London.
	W.E.G. Seemann in Hannover".

11.610. <em>The Journal of Botany</em>, British and Foreign. Edited by Berthold Seemann, ...
"Nunquam otiosus" ... London (Robert Hardwicke, ...) Edinburgh (Andrew Elliot,
...), Paris (J. Rothschild), Leipzig (L. Denicke), New York (Westermann) 1863-1945,
80 vols. Oct. (<em>J. Bot</em>.).

<em>Publ</em>.: in monthly parts, all dated; several volumes with independently paged supple-
	ments. <em>Copies</em>: U; IDC 399.
<em>Editors</em>: (1) Berthold Seemann, sole editor vols. 1-7, 1863-1869, assisted by John Gilbert
	Baker (1834-1920) and Henry Trimen (1843-1896) for vols. 8-9, 1870-1871.
	(2) Henry Trimen, assisted by J.G. Baker, vols. 9-13, 1872-1875 (new series 1-4).
	(3) Henry Trimen, sole editor, vol. 14, 1876 (n.s. 5).
	(4) Henry Trimen, assisted by Spencer Le Marchant Moore (1850-1931), vols. 15-17,
	1877-1879 (n.s. 6-8).
	(5) James Britten (1846-1924), vols. 18-62, 1880-1924 (vols. 18-20 also as n.s. 9-11).
	(6) Alfred Barton Rendle (1865-1938), vols. 63-75, 1925-1937.
	(7) John Ramsbottom (1885-1974), vols. 76-80, 1938-1945 (vol. 80, no. 956, August
	1942, was published July, 1945).
<em>Title</em>: (1) The Journal of Botany, British and Foreign, vols. <em>1-17</em>, 1863-1879, and <em>21-80</em>,
	1883-1945.
	(2) Trimen's Journal of Botany, British and Foreign, vols. 18-20, 1880-1882.
	For some timeafter Seemann's death the journal continued to be referred to unoffici-
	ally as <em>Seemann's Journal of Botany</em>; this, however, never appeared on the official
	t.p.'s.
<em>Imprints</em>: (1) London (Robert Hardwicke, ...), as in heading, vols. 1-5, 1863-1868.
	(2) London (L. Reeve and Co., ...), vols. 6-7. 1868-1869.

11.613. <em>Flora vitiensis</em>: a description of the plants of the Viti or Fiji Islands with an

Seemann, Wilhelm Eduard Gottfried (x-1868), German (Hannover) botanist, geo-
logist and editor; brother of B.C. Seemann. (<em>W. Seem</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 255 (d. 3 Mar 1868); BM 4: 1892; Jackson
p. 477; Rehder 4: 500; TL-1/1221; TL-2/see A.J.A. Bonpland.

	640. 1868 (d.); Flora 51: 236. 1868 (d.); J. Bot. 6: 128. 1868 (d.); Österr. bot. Z. 18:
	333. 1868 (d.).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Co-editor <em>Bonplandia</em> 1-10, 1853-1862, see above under B.C. Seemann.

Seemen, [Karl] Otto von (1838-1910), German (East-Prussian) botanist and soldier;
officer in the Prussian army, at Münchengrätz and Königgrätz 1866, in the Franco-
Prussian war 1870-1871; from then on in semi-retirement ("Rittmeister a.D.") in Berlin;
professor's title 1909; Rother Adlerorden iv. Kl. 1910; active floristic botanist; specialist
on <em>Salix</em>; longtime honorary collaborator at the Botanical Museum, Berlin. (<em>Seemen</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B (rd 1892; mainly destr.); some material in BHU, L. – Types of
new <em>Salix</em> species may be in various herbaria, enumerated in <em>Salic. jap.</em> p. v-vii. – <em>Letters</em>
at G.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Seemen's brother Hans von Seemen (b. 22 Nov 1836, d. 13 Nov 1909) was an
active entomologist who also built up a (small) herbarium which went to the Preussische
bot. Verein (now destroyed).

PAGE: 482
HEADING: SEEMEN

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 1: 335 (ed. 2: 511), 5(3): 26; Backer p. 525; Barnhart
3: 255 (b. 2 Aug 1838, d. 23 Jun 1910); Biol.-Dokum. 16: 8569-8570; BL 1: 54, 2: 162;
BM 4: 1892-1893, 8: 1175; Christiansen A629; Hortus 3: 1204; IH 2: (files); Langman p.
692; LS 24580; MW p. 443; Rehder 5: 791; TL-2/200, 7684; Tucker 1: 644; Urban-Berl.
p. 396; Zander ed. 10, p. 715-716, ed. 11, p. 816.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Ber. deut. bot. Ges. 28: (74). 1910 (d.).
Bässler, M., Wiss. Z. Humboldt Univ. Berlin mat.-nat. R. 19(2/3): 299. 1970 (Salix in
	BHU).
Harms, H., Verh. bot. Ver. Brandenburg 52: (51)-(64). 1911 (obit., bibl., epon.) (ab-
	stract Just's Bot. Jahresb. 2. 39: 919-920. 1915).

1908, 81-160. 30 Mar 1909, 161-240. 26 Oct, 241-320. 31 Dec 1909, 321-350. 2 Aug
1910, see below <em>Mitteleur. Weiden</em> 1911.

Seenus, Joseph Freiherr von (<em>fl</em>. 1805), Austro-Hungarian botanist; travelled in
Istria and Dalmatia ca. 1798-1802. (<em>Seenus</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown; a few specimens at MW.

Rehder 1: 447; Saccardo 1: 152.

HEADING: SEGERSTEDT

11.620. <em>Beschreibung einer Reise nach Istrien und Dalmatien</em> vorzüglich in botanischer Hin-

Seetzen, Ulrich Jasper (1767-1811), German (Oldenburg) naturalist and traveller at
Jever; Dr. phil. Göttingen 1789; traveller in the Orient and Africa 1802-1811. (<em>Seetzen</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Some material (phan., lich.) at H. – A note in Bot. Zeit. (15: 64.
1857) states that the remains of Seetzen's Orient herbarium at Gotha would be handed
to H.G.L. Reichenbach at Leipzig; however, this was never realized; the specimens were
in very poor shape (see Kruse (1859) in note below).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 256 (b. 30 Jan 1767, d. 8 Sep 1811); BM 4:
1893; CSP 5: 623-624; De Toni 1: cxv; Dryander 3: 128, 425, 654; LS 24581; PR 8585,
ed. 1: 9530; Rehder 1: 202, 4: 159; Tucker 1: 644.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bonplandia 5: 225. 1857 (herb. at Gotha to H.G.L. Reichenbach); Bot.
	Zeit. 1 (Int. Bl.): 175. 1843 (seed collection for sale); Brit. Mus. gen. cat. print. books
	218: 374-375. 1964; Cat. gén. livr. impr. Bibl. natl. 169: 722. 1946; Encycl. brit. ed.

in collaboration with Hinrichs, by G.Fr. Hermann Müller and H.L. Fleischer: "Ulrich
Jasper Seetzen's <em>Reisen durch Syrien, Palästina, Phönicien, die Transjordan-Länder, Arabia pet-
raea und Unter-Aegypten</em>, 4 vols. Berlin (G. Reimer) 1854-1859, (copy: U). The account
contains little botany; the explanation is given in vol. 4 (commentary by Kruse and
Fleischer) on p. xxvii (and in 1: xliv): "Die von Seetzen geschickten Pflanzen fand ich
[Kruse] ... in einem sehr traurigen Zustande ...". An attempt to have them identified

the countries adjoining the Lake of Tiberus</em> ... Bath 1810.

Segret, L. (1867-1949), French clergyman and botanist. (<em>Segret</em>).

Séguier, Jean François (1703-1784), French botanist, historian, bibliographer and
archeologist at Nîmes; studied law at Montpellier and botany at Paris with Antoine de
Jussieu; accompanied the archeologist Francesco Scipione on his European travels 1732-
1736, visiting e.g. Holland (Boerhaave, J.F. Gronovius, G.P. van Swinden); to Verona
with Scipione 1736-1755; at Nîmes 1755-1784 working mainly on archeology. (<em>Séguier</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Municipal library (Bibliothèque Séguier) Nîmes, France; further
material in LINN (Monte Carlo, nr Verona), M (types Monte Baldo), and P (via
Pourret). Manuscripts also at Bibl. Séguier, Nîmes; correspondence ib. 17 vols. Other
letters at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 5(1): 776, 12(3): 552; Backer p. 525, 568; Barnhart
3: 256 (b. 25 Nov 1703, d. 1 Sep 1784); BM 4: 1894; Bossert p. 359; Dryander 3: 7, 147-
148; DTS 1: 278; Frank 3 (Anh.): 95; GR p. 351; Hegi 3: 327, 570, 4(2): 604, 5(1): 177,
5(2): 1318; Henrey 2: 84n., 86; Herder p. 75, 180; Hortus 3: 1204; HU 525; Jackson p.
1, 323; Kelly p. 211; Lasègue p. 321, 336, 337, 341, 358; LS 24581a; NI 1829; Plesch p.
403; PR 1081, 3609, 8586-8591, ed. 1: 3921; Rehder 5: 792; Saccardo 1: 152, 2: 100,
cron. p. xxxiii; SK 1: cxvii; SO 632b, 3613; Sotheby 691; TL-1/1222-1223; TL-2/4230,
see P.J. Bergius; Zander ed. 10, p. 716, ed. 11, p. 816.

	Johnson, Huntia 3(2): 113-114. 1979).
<em>Note</em> (1) on Seguier's <em>Bibliotheca botanica</em>. Séguier quotes with approval the bipartite
	division of botanical publications made by Tournefort in his <em>Institutiones</em> (ed. 3, 1719):
	the works dealing with botany proper and those dealing with the medicinal uses of

PAGE: 486
HEADING: SÉGUIER

	plants. Those two categories are dealt with in the first and second parts of the <em>Biblio-
	theca</em>, but the "vires" were taken very narrowly, and a third part dealing with hortic-
	ulture and agriculture was necessary. In addition to this there is a forty-page <em>Index
	rerum</em> which is singularly impractical because the reference is only to authors' names
	and not to pages, or even to the three main parts.
	The bibliography includes not only books and other independent bibliographical
	productions, but also references to publications in the periodical literature. Haller
	(1771-1772) and Dryander (1798-1800) later did the same, thus obviating the need
	for a special catalogue of botanical publications in the periodical literature of the
	eighteenth century. Almost all entries are quite detailed. The authors' names are
	followed by brief indications of profession and nationality (usually taken from
	Montalbanus, Tournefort or Jussieu) and Séguier frequently provides in the margin,
	in minute print. abbreviated references to biographical literature.
	The entries for the publications contain usually the title fully transcribed and in the
	original language, the place of publication, the publisher, the size (although not the
	number of pages) and sometimes a critical commentary and an indication of the
	location where he saw the book or found a reference to it. These statements of locat-
	ion are obviously of great importance because they will very often allow us at once to
	identify the library where the publications are presently located; an item of informat-
	ion of capital value for many of these rare books.
	A further interesting and especially useful feature is again the provision of marginal
	notes giving relevant references to reviews, publications, comments or other second-
	ary publications relevant to the main entry. These references are often to the main
	secondary literature of Séguier's time, e.g. to the <em>Acta eruditorum</em>, published at Leipzig
	(50 vols., 1682-1732), the <em>Journal des Sçavans</em>, the <em>Giornale de' Letterati</em> (Venice).
	The first two parts of the <em>Bibiotheca botanica</em> are not provided with introductions.
	Séguier explains in his preface (p. 5) that Tournefort's <em>Isagoge</em> is sufficient intro-
	duction to the subject. For the third part, however, he provides an introduction on
	the early development of the literature on horticulture and agriculture.
	The coverage of the book is excellent, due to the fact that Séguier saw an unusual
	number of libraries on his European tour. He furthermore consulted as many cata-
	logues of private libraries as possible. With the major Paris and London libraries
	accounted for, with the information obtained from Gronovius in Holland, and with
	his careful scanning of the literature, Séguier achieved a very high degree of coverage.
	The system of cross-references is good and special attention is given to contributions
	by one author to the work of a second.
	A letter from C.P. van Swinden at the Hague to Séguier, dated 23 September 1740,
	now at Nîmes, makes it clear that van Swinden acted as an intermediary between
	Séguier and the publisher. Séguier had sent some <em>errata</em> but van Swinden says that
	they arrived too late to be incorporated. The work was not only ready at the time he
	wrote his letter, but quite a few copies had already been distributed. Van Swinden
	advises Séguier to keep them for a second edition, or for an appendix. "Comme les
	livres de Botanique s'augmentent tous les jours aussi bien que ceux des autres sciences
	il y a apparence que vous ne manquerez pas d'initiatives". He adds that complimen-
	tary copies have been sent to various scientists, among them Sloane, Burman and
	Gronovius. The proofs had been read by himself and by a physician from the Hague
	who is not mentioned by name.
	Reviews and announcements of the <em>Bibliotheca botanica</em> in the contemporary period-
	ical literature are relatively scarce, (see above, <em>Reviews</em>). The <em>Commercium litterarium</em> of
	1741 gives a lengthly "review" on 3, 10 and 17 May 1741, mainly consisting of an
	enumeration of titles followed by criticism of some details. It ends with the somewhat
	enigmatic statement on the differences between the bibliographies of Linnaeus and
	Séguier: "Thus our attempt surpassed that of Linnaeus; in the same way someone else
	will correct our own shortcomings". A second "edition" of the <em>Bibliotheca botanica</em> was
	published in Leiden by Cornelius Haak in 1760. This is actually a reissue of the old
	sheets with a new title-page and with the addition of Gronovius' <em>Auctuarium</em>. The
	bibliography of Séguier's book has been complicated by the fact that the main title-
	page of this reissue (Leiden) carries the date 1740 rather than 1760; this is evidently
	an error, because the Montalbanus item and the Gronovius <em>Auctuarium</em>, which are
	bound with the reissue, both carry the correct date. The main title-pages can easily be

PAGE: 487
HEADING: SÉGUIER

	distinguished because the original one has the imprint Hagae-Comitum [the Hague]
	apud Joannem Neaulme; the reissue is from Leiden by Haak.
<em>Note</em>(<em>2</em>) on Ovidius Montalbanus (1601-1671) and <em>Bibliotheca botanica</em>, the text of which
	was reprinted by Séguier in 1740:
	Montalbanus, professor of natural sciences and mathematics at Bologna, published,
	in 1657, a <em>Bibliotheca botanica</em> under the pseudonym Johannus Antonius Bumaldus. Lin-
	naeus, at the time of his <em>Bibliotheca botanica</em>, had not yet seen the book and did not know
	that the author's name was a mystification. This publication was the main source for
	Séguier with respect to older literature; he included a reprint of it in his own <em>Bibliotheca
	botanica</em> of 1740, citing the actual name of the author: Ovidius Montalbanus (1601-
	1671)... Séguier praises the work highly and explains that Jo. Ant. Bumaldus is an
	anagram of the real author's name (Io. Antonius Bumaldus <em>versus</em> Ovidius Montal-
	banus). There are four parts: <em>Graeci, Latini veteri extantes, Scriptores arabes extantes</em>, and
	<em>Recentiores</em> ... The order is more or less chronological under each heading; in the case of
	the <em>recentiores</em> the order is more or less chronological by the date of each author's first
	publication. Montalbanus provides useful biographical information and on the whole it
	can be said that the book is fairly complete. The works of Aldrovandi (Montalbanus'
	teacher, whose collections he was curating) receive especially detailed treatment. Bumal-
	dus very definitely does full justice to Montalbanus: on p. 38 we find a neat biographical
	summary with a list of quite a few – mostly unpublished – works. He bestows high praise
	upon his alter ego when speaking about the <em>Hortus botanographicus</em> (then in manuscript,
	published in 1670): "Tres tandem tomos Botanographiae in octava folii forma, mole
	quidem parvos, sed virtute quam maximos nec non admirabilissimos, ad manus habet,
	in quibus innumerae Plantae quantumvis procerae &amp; ingentes a natura &amp; arte simul
	junctis artificiosissimè ... effigiatae visuntur in aeternitatem ... persentiuntur". Had
	Montalbanus only known that he would find, less than a century later, a sympathetic
	admirer in Séguier, he might perhaps have spared Bumaldus this panagyric upon him-
	self. Meyer, in his <em>Geschichte der Botanik</em> (4: 269. 1857), notes kindly that this praise of his
	own publications is not all that conspicuous, because Bumaldus praises every botanist
	from Bologna above all others.
	Notwithstanding all this embellishment, however, Bumaldus' <em>Bibliotheca botanica</em> was
	undoubtedly a significant bibliographical effort from which his most important fol-
	lowers, Séguier and Haller, derived much benefit. The original publication of 1657
	(which we have not seen) numbers 188 pp. in duodecimo, the lists of which are-
	occupied by a special bibliography of publications on grasses. This part, entitled
	<em>Species graminum individuales</em>, occupies p. 41-62 of the Séguier reprint of 1740 and con-
	sists of a list of books treating grasses, with indication of the described or depicted
	species; it is, probably the first published agrostological bibliography. The book ends
	with a useful alphabetical index to author's names.
<em>Note</em>(<em>3</em>) on the 1760 supplement by Laurens Theodoor Gronovius (1730-1777) entitled:
	<em>Auctuarium in bibliothecam botanicam</em>. Leiden, 1760, Cornelius Haak.
	This <em>Auctuarium</em> was issued "fere semper" (Pritzel) together with the 1760 reissue of
	Séguier's <em>Bibliotheca botanica</em>. We know of no separate copies, but Pritzel's statement
	seems to imply that they occur. Dryander (Cat. Banks 3: 7) cites the book as an
	independent entity. Laurens Theodoor Gronovius was the son of Jan Frederik
	Gronovius (1690-1762), the well-known Leiden patron of Linnaeus. Laurens
	Theodoor Gronovius published, in addition to this <em>Auctuarium</em>, the second edition of
	his father's <em>Flora virginica</em>. His other publications are mainly zoological, including a
	<em>Bibliotheca regni animalis atque lapidei</em> of 1760. For a detailed list of L.T. Gronovius'
	publications see Dryander (1798-1800).
<em>Note</em>(<em>4</em>) on the 1745 supplement by Séguier himself, published in the second volume of
	his <em>Plantae Veronenses</em>, entitled Joannis Francisci Seguieri <em>Bibliothecae botanicae quae pro-
	diit Hagae Comitum anno MDCCXL Supplementum</em>.
	This is the supplement mentioned by Séguier in his letter to Linnaeus. There are 79
	pages; the pagination in the 1745 issue was independent of that of the <em>Plantae
	Veronenses</em>.
	In his preface Séguier mentions again his indebtedness to the Dutch classicist
	Gerard Jacob van Swinden, who sent him many corrections and additions, especially
	with respect to editions of classical authors. The literature of 1740-1745 is added,
	although not in the same detail as in the original work. Some last-minute acquisitions

PAGE: 488
HEADING: SÉGUIER

	are mentioned on p. 72 and 73 in the addenda, "including even a Linnaean dis-
	sertation from 1745 ("<em>Dissertatio de Corallis maris Balthici</em>"; title actually slightly
	changed).

11.625. <em>Calalogus plantar urn quae in agro Veronensi reperiuntur</em> ... Veronae [Verona] 1745.
Oct. (<em>Cat. pl. Veron</em>.).

	Francisci Seguierii Bibliotheca botanicae quae prodiit Hagae Comitum anno mdccxl

<em>Notes</em>: a proposal by A.J. Wilmott (Bull. misc. Inf. Kew 1935: 90-91) to treat names in
	the <em>Pl. veron.</em> as not validly published was rejected by the Amsterdam International
	botanical Congress of 1935. – For a note on the present status (validly publ.) of
	Séguier's generic names see J.E. Dandy, Regn. veg. 51: 18-19. 1967. – See also ICBN
	Art. 41, ex. 1, for an example involving the <em>Pl. veron.</em> – Séguier does not use Linnaean
	binary names for his species; his generic names, however, are validly published either
	by reference to an earlier description or by the provision of a new description.

Segura, José Carmen (1846-1906), Mexican botanist and agricultural engineer;
studied at the Escuela de Agricultura, Mexico; in the Mexican army as technical en-
gineer 1870-1876; later teaching at agricultural schools and employed by the Mexican
government in various administrative and advisory capacities. (<em>Segura</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 256 (d. 12 Feb 1906); Langman p. 692

	México 2(83): 3. 1895 (n.v.).

Sehlmeyer, Johann Friedrich (1788-1856), German (Hannover) botanist and phar-
macist; from circa 1821 until 1852 in charge of the "Hofapothek" in Köln. (<em>Sehlm</em>.).

Seidenfaden, Gunnar (1908-x), Danish explorer, politician, diplomat and botanist;

PAGE: 492
HEADING: SEIDENFADEN

travelled in the Arctic 1928-1934, to Spitsbergen 1938 ; economic counsellor at the
Danish embassy at Washington 1940-1945, ambassador in S.E. Asia 1955-1959, in
Moscow 1959-1961; stationed in Denmark from 1961; specialist on Thailand Orchida-
ceae. (<em>Seidenf</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: C; other material at NY (1300), S.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 257; BJI 2: 163; BL 1: 157, 318; BM 8: 1175.

	37: 51. 1936 (Arctic coll. acquired by NY); Kraks blå bog 1973, p. 1235, 1983, p.
	1032 (q.v. for further details on career; b. 24 Feb 1908).
Christensen, C., Danske bot. Litt. 1912-1939, 1940, p. 266 (bibl., portr.).
Fox Maule, A., Bot. Tidsskr. 69: 179, 180, 181, 200. 1974.
Hansen, A., Dansk bot. Arkiv 21(1): 49. 1963 (curr. vitae, portr.).
Jørgensen, C.A. et al., Biol. Skr. Dan. Vid. Selsk. 9(4): 6, 169. 1958.
Seidenfaden, G., [Autobiography in] Festskrift Københavns Univ. Nov 1969, p. 253-
	255.
Verdoorn, F., ed., Chron. bot. 3: 310. 1937, 5: 124. 1939.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: For Seidenfaden's major series of publications on Orchids see <em>The Orchids of
Thailand</em>, a preliminary list, with T. Smitinand, 1: 1-98, <em>2 pl</em>. 1954, 2(1): 99-184b, <em>3 pl</em>.
1959, 2(2): 185-326a, <em>8 pl</em>. 1960, 3: 327-516a, <em>8 pl</em>. 1961, 4(1): 517-647b, <em>8 pl</em>. 1963, 4(2):
648-870. 1965 (Bangkok), and: <em>Orchid genera in Thailand</em> 1-11, 1975-1983 see Dansk bot.
Ark. 29(2-4). 1975, 31(1). 1976, 31(3). 1977, 32(2). 1978, 33(1). 1978, 33(3). 1979 ...
Nordic J. Bot. 2(3). 1982; Opera bot. 72, 1983. 1983. – These and other post-1950
Orchid publications by S. are listed e.g. by A. Hansen, in his compilations of the Danish
botanical literature 1960-1979 (in Bot. Tidsskr.), and in Taxon.

Blasius Mann (1799-1839) and "Moschner", distributed by P.M. Opiz.

Seidlitz, Nicolai [Karl Samuel] von (1831-1907), Latvian (Baltic-German) botanist
and statistician; studied botany at Dorpat 1852-1854; travelled in the Caucasus and
Persia 1855-1857; Mag. bot. Dorpat 1858; director of a serilogical school in Nucha
(Transkaukasia) 1858-1863; with the surveyors office of the Caucasus 1866-1868; with
the Office of Statistics at Tiflis 1868-1877, later judge at Tiflis. (<em>Seidlitz</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: TU; 600 sp. "Herbarium balticum" in LE; further material at
BR.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 257 (b. 25 Jun/7 Jul 1831, 15/28 Oct 1907);
Bossert p. 359; CSP 5: 631, 11: 385, 18: 677; Herder p. 59, 212, 400; Jackson p. 328;
Rehder 1: 369, 3: 601; Tucker 1: 644.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Nat. Nov. 30: 71. 1908 (d.).
Gillian-Smith, B. &amp; W.B. Turrill, Bull. misc. Inf. Kew 1930: 278.
Kusnezow, H., Act. Hort. Bot. Univ. Jurjew 9: 41-47. 1908 (obit., portr.).
Lipschitz, S., Fl. URSS fontes 1975, nos. 1138, 1141, 1398.
Radde, G., Grundz. Pfl.-Verbr. Kaukasusländ. 5, 19. 1899 (Veg. Erde 3).

Welding, O. et al., eds., Deutschbaltisches Biographisches Lexikon 1710-1960, p. 723.
	1970.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Seidlitzia</em> Bunge ex Boissier (1879).

11.640. <em>Botanische Ergebnisse einer Reise durch das östliche Transkaukasien</em> und der Aderbeid-
shan, ausgeführt in den Jahren 1855 und 1856. Erstes Heft, den Reisebericht und die
Aufzählung der Thalamifloren von den Ranunculaceen bis zu den Polygaleen enthal-
tend. Abhandlung zur Erlangung der Würde eines Magisters der physiko-
mathematische Facultät öffentlich zu vertheidigen von Nikolai von Seidlitz. Dorpat
[Tartu] (gedruckt bei Schünmann's Wwe &amp; C. Mattiesen) 1857. Oct. †. (<em>Bot. Erg. Reise
Transkaukas</em>.).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1857 (p. [2] censor: 12 Oct 1857; rev. ÖbZ 1 Feb 1859; KNAW rd Dec 1858), p.
	[1]-100, [1, theses]. <em>Copies</em>: B-S, G, HH, MO.

Seifriz, William Ernest (1888-1955), American botanist (of German parents); BS
Johns Hopkins 1916; Dr. phil. ib. 1920; instructor in botany Univ. Michigan 1923-1924;
National Research Council fellow Univ. Pennsylvania 1924-1925; professor of botany at
the Dept. of Botany ib. from 1925; mainly interested in protoplasm but published also
on phytogeography. (<em>Seifriz</em>).

Selby, Augustine Dawson (1859-1924), American botanist and phytopathologist; B.S.
Ohio State Univ. 1893; high school teacher at Huntington W.Va. 1884-1886, Ironton,
Ohio 1886-1887, Columbus, Ohio 1890-1894, with Ohio Agricultural Experiment
Station, Columbus, 1894-1923; collected in Colorado with L.M. Underwood 1901;
worked at the New York Botanical Garden 1903-1904. (<em>A. Selby</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: OS; first set of Colorado fungi at NY; some further material at

Seier, Eduard Georg (1849-1922), German (Prussian) plant collector, archeologist
and ethnologist; studied at the universities of Breslau and Berlin; on active service in the
Franco-Prussian war; state teacher's examination 1875; high school teacher at Berlin
1876-1879; turned to ethnological studies; Dr. phil. Leipzig 1887; assistant (1892) later
divisional director (1904) at the Berlin ethnological museum; habil. Berlin 1894; profes-
sor of American languages 1899; travelled in Mexico and Central America 1887-1888,
1895-1897, 1902-1903, 1904-1905, 1910-1911; mainly studying the Maya culture but
also collecting plants. (<em>Seler</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B (6000; orig. set destr.; dupla extant; see Urban p. 396); further
material at A, CAS, DS, F, GH, K, MEXU, MO, NY, US. – Seler's Central-European
herbarium was offered for sale in Herbarium 65: 167. 1923 and 71: 223. 1925.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 258 (b. 5 Dec 1849, d. 23 Nov 1922); CSP
18: 681; Langman p. 693; TL-2/4935; Urban-Berl. p. 396.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Cat. gén. livr. impr. Bibl. natl. 170: 181-187. 1947; Verh. bot. Ver.
	Brandenburg 64: 244. 1922 (d.); Deut. biogr. Jahrb. 4 (for 1922): 370. 1929.
Breedlove, D.E., Fl. Chiapas 25. 1981.
Harms, H., Verh. bot. Ver. Brandenburg 63: 95-96. 1922 (congratulations 70th
	birthday).

	1-4. 1924 (obit.).

HEADING: SELLAND

taken from Catesby feature also plants. – Also published in Dutch: <em>Verzameling van uit-

by Seligmann.

2/3766.

11.650. <em>Die Nahrungs-Gefäse</em> [sic] <em>in den Blättern der Bäume</em> nach ihrer unterschiedlichen
Austheilung und Zusammenfügung so wie solche die Natur selbst bildet abgedruckt von
Johann Michael Seligmann ... Nebst Tit. Herrn Hof-Raths Christoph Jacob Trew his-
torischen Bericht von der Anatomie der Pflanzen und von der Absicht dieses Werkes.
Nürnberg (gedruckt bey Johann Joseph Fleischmann) 1748. Fol. (<em>Nahrungs-Gefäse</em>).

<em>Author</em> of text on plant anatomy: Christoph Jacob Trew (1695-1769).
<em>Publ</em>.: 1748, p. [i], [1]-8, <em>36 pl</em>. (incl. title) of which 34 (33?) nature prints; pl. 2 double.
	<em>Copies</em>: NSUB (inf. G. Wagenitz), NY (<em>pl. 1, 1</em>*, <em>2, 2*, 3-25</em>). – Fischer no. 20 (2 + 33
	pl.).

Selin, Gustaf (1836-1862), Finnish botanist. (<em>Selin</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: H. – Some further material at E.

Seiland, Sjur Knutsen (1867-1920), Norwegian botanist and school teacher at

1920. (<em>Selland</em>).

Sellow, [orig.: Sello] Friedrich (1789-1831), German gardener and botanical explorer;
worked in the Berlin and Paris (1810-1811) botanical gardens and studied botany with
Willdenow, Desfontaines and A.L. de Jussieu as well as in London (sponsored by A. v.
Humboldt 1811-1813); from 1814 in Brazil, collecting widely from 1815-1817 with
Maximilian zu Wied-Neuwied; with Ignaz Franz Werner von Olfers [1793-1871] in
1819; continued to collect 1819-1831 in Brazil and Uruguay. (<em>Sellow</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B (10.000 mainly destroyed; duplicates extant; see Urban p. 396-
397); further material at A, BM, BR, CGE, DPU, E, F, FI, G, GH, GOET, HAL, K,
KIEL, L, LD, LE, LISU, LZ, M, MO, MW, NY, P, PH, POM, R, S, SGO, U, UPS,
US, VT, W, WRSL, WU.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 2(1): 325; Backer 516; Barnhart 3: 259 (b. 12 Mar
1789, d. Sep 1831); BM 4: 1897; Frank 3 (Anh.): 96; IH 1 (ed. 6): 364, (ed. 7): 342;
Lasègue p. 225, 303, 327, 334, 476, 505; PR 5902, ed. 1: 6597; TL-1/798; Urban-Berl. p.
269, 282, 291, 313, 396-397; Zander ed. 10, p. 716, ed. 11, p. 816.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Arechevaleta, J., Fl. Uruguaya 2: xxviii. 1903 (coll. Uruguay).
Candolle, Alph. de, Phytographie 450. 1880 (coll.).
Chamisso, A. von, Und lassen gelten was ich beobachtet habe, ed. R. Schneebeli-Graf;
	Berlin 1983, p. 268, 286, 306 (plants by S. described in Linnaea).
Herter, W., Bot. Jahrb. 74(1): 119-149. 1945 (analysis of itineraries, identification of
	localities).
Herter, W.G. &amp; B. Rambo, Nas pegadas dos naturalistas Sellow e Saint-Hilaire. Itinera
	Sellowio-Hilariana. Basilea (Basel) 1953, 100 p. (itin.).
Jessen, K.F.W., Bot. Gegenw. Vorz. 467. 1864.
Lowden, R.M., Taxon, Index pers. names vols. 1-30. 658. 1985.
Miller, H.S., Taxon 19: 541. 1970 (Lambert holdings of Sellow material).
Papavero, N., Essays hist. neotrop. dipterol. 1: 56-60, 69-80, 99-101, 215. 1971, 2: 218.
	1973.
Sayre, G., Mem. New York Bot. Gard. 19(3): 397-398. 1975 (coll.).

	1939 (<em>Svitramia</em> Chamisso, eponym for C.F.P. von Martius, based on a Sellow plant);
	Chamisso als Naturforscher 172 [index]. 1942.
Souza Sobrinho, R.J. de, Insula 8: 15. 1976.

HEADING: SÉLYS-LONGCHAMPS

Stieber, M.T., Huntia 3(2): 125. 1979 (mentioned in A. Chase mss.).

	ions), Fl. bras. 1(1): 105-111. 1906 (detailed itineraries), Chileans 8(30): 137-140.
	1975 (English transl.).
Verdoorn, F., ed., Chron. bot. 3: 332. 1937.
Wagenitz, G., Index coll. princ. herb. gott. 155. 1982.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Sellow's original family name was Sello; he adopted the spelling Sellow only after
his arrival in Brazil (1814). A cousin of Sellow, Hermann Ludwig Sello was head-
gardener in Sans-Souci nr Potsdam (1800-1876). The family dropped the spelling
Sellow and S.'s other cousin J. Hanstein crossed out the letter "w" on many labels.

<sm>TRAVELS</sm>: 1, Rio de Janeiro, 1814-1815 (ca. 1000 nos.).
2, Rio de Janeiro, Espirito Santo, Bahia, 1815-1818 (ca. 1800 nos.).
3, Minas Geraës, São Paulo, 1818-1820, Rio de Janeiro 1820-1821 (ca. 2500 nos.).
4, Uruguay, Rio Grande do Sul, S. Catharina, Parana, São Paulo 1821-1829 (6019
nos.).
5, São Paulo, Minas Geraes 1829-1831 (ca. 1450 nos.). For detailed itineraries see W.G.
Herter &amp; B. Rambo (1953).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: (genera): <em>Selloa</em> K.P.J. Sprengel (1819, <em>nom. rej.</em>); <em>Selloa</em> Humboldt, Bonpland
et Kunth (1820, <em>nom. cons.</em>); <em>Sellocharis</em> Taubert (1889); <em>Sellowia</em> Roth ex J.J. Roemer et
J.A. Schultes (1819-1820); (journal): <em>Sellowia</em>, Anais Botânicos do Herbário "Barbosa
Rodrigues", Itajaí, Santa Catarina, Brazil. Vol. 6-x, 1954-x.

Sélys-Longchamps, Michel Edmond Baron de (1813-1900), Belgian zoologist, bota-
nist and politician, member of the Belgian House of Representatives 1848-1855, of the
Senate 1855-1898; living on his property of Longchamps near Liège. (<em>Sélys-Longch</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Had a herbarium.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 1: 446, 3: 259 (b. 25 Mai 1813, d. 11 Dec
1900); BM 4: 1898-1899, 8: 1177; Herder p. 298, 365; Hortus 3: 1204; PH 12, 150, 567,
939; Quenstedt p. 395; Rehder 5: 793; SO 1248b; Tucker 1: 644.

Senckenberg, Johann Christian (1707-1772), German (Frankfurt a.M.) physician
and naturalist; founder of the Senckenberg Stiftung consisting of a library, botanical
garden, chemical laboratory and hospital. (<em>Senckenberg</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: The Senckenberg herbarium has not been seen after 1782,
during Reichard's professorship (H.J. Conert, in Lit. 2. 2. 1982, and (1979)). – Archival
material at FR.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 259 (b. 28 Feb 1707); BM 4: 1900; Dryander
3: 485; Herder p. 412; PR 8601, ed. 1: 9554; TL-2/8833.

	Reichard; see TL-2/8833).

	J.C.S.).

HEADING: SENDTNER
