Senckenb. naturf. Ges. 458: 1-175. 1941.

Sendtner, Otto (1813-1859), German (Bavarian) botanist, privately employed in
Silesia studying the cryptogamic flora of the Sudeten 1837-1840; Dr. phil. München
1840; curator of the Leuchtenberg Museum at Eichstädt 1841; travelled in Istria, Illyria
and Bosnia; habil. Univ. München 1848; adjunct with the Bavarian Academy of
Sciences in charge of the plant-geographical exploration of Bavaria; extraordinary pro-
fessor at the University of München 1853; ordinary professor and curator of the
München herbarium 1857-1859. (<em>Sendtn</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: M; other material in B (in herb. Koch), BM, BR, CGE, FI, G,
GOET, K, L, LZ (destr.), ROST, S, W, WRSL (lich., musci). – Musci sold to Westhoff
(Düsseldorf). – <em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 34: 7-8 (E. Wunschmann); AG 2: 477-478, 5(2):
188, 12(2): 685; Backer p. 661; Barnhart 3: 259 (b. 27 Jun 1813, d. 21 Apr 1859); Biol.-
Dokum. 16: 8619-8620; BM 4: 1900; CSP 5: 643-644, 12: 674; DTS 1: 279-280; Frank 3
(Anh.): 96; GR p. 138; Henrey 4(1): 27, 6(2): 1290; Herder p. 189, 224, 313; Hortus 3:
1204; Jackson p. 266; Kanitz no. 189; Lasègue p. 337; Maiwald p. 152, 176, 235;
Moebius p. 375; PR 8602-8605, ed. 1: 2995, 9559; Rehder 5: 793; Saccardo 1: 152, 2:
100; SBC p. 132; TL-2/see J.A. Perktold; Tucker 1: 645; Urban-Berl. p. 291, 314;
Zander ed. 10, p. 716.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bonplandia 4: 122. 1856 ("Ansichten aus dem baierischen Walde"), 5:
	188. 1857 (ord. prof. curator herb.), 7: 114 (note, d.), 137-138 (obit.), 301 (Radlko-
	fer succeeds S.) 1859; Bot. Zeit. 6: 471 (habil. München), 824 (adjunct bot. gard.)
	1848, 15: 408. 1857 (ord. prof. bot., curator herb.), 17: 169, 280, 344. 1859 (obit.,
	herb. musci to Westhoff, publ. Heufler, succession); Bull. Soc. bot. France 6: 176.
	1859 (obit.); Flora 31: 254. 1848 (habil. München), 37: 336. 1854 (extraord. prof.
	bot.), 40: 336. 1857 (ord. prof., curator herb.), 42: 256-257 (note d.), 268-272 (obit.,
	bibl.) 1859; Österr. bot. W. 4: 238. 1854 (extraord. prof), 7: 251. 1857 (ord. prof.,
	curator herb.); Österr. bot. Z. 9: 201. 1859 (d.).
Beck, G., Veg.-Verh. Illyr. Länd. 8, 15, 42. 1901 (Veg. Erde 4).

	on letters).
Hooker, J.D., <em>in</em> W.J. Hooker, London J. Bot. 6: 51. 1847 (to Bosnia).
Mägdefrau, K., Beitr. naturk. Forsch. S.W. Deutschl. 27: 3-20. 1968; Gesch. Bot. 105,

Urban, I., Fl. bras. 1(1): 202-203. 1906.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) <em>Solanaceae</em> et <em>Cestrineae, in</em> Martius, <em>Fl. bras.</em> 10: 1-228, <em>pl. 1-19.</em> 1 Jul
1846.

<sm>HANDWRITING</sm>: Hoppea 34(2): 419. 1976.

11.657. <em>De Cyphomandra</em>, novo Solanacearum genere tropicae Americae. Dissertatio
inauguralis botanica, [1845]. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 21 Mar 1845 (in journal), p. [1]-18, <em>1 pl</em>. (uncol. lith.). <em>Copies</em>: B-S, G, M. –
	Reprinted and to be cited from Flora 28: 161-176. <em>1 pl</em>. 1845.
<em>Note</em>: <em>Sicklera</em> Sendtn. (Solanaceae) was published in Flora 29: 194 ("178"). 7 Apr 1846;
	it antedates <em>Sicklera</em> M.J. Roemer (14 Sep-15 Oct 1846), and is dedicated to the
	pomologist Johann Volkmann Sickler (1741-1820).

11.658. <em>Beobachtungen über die klimatische Verbreitung der Laubmoose</em> durch das österreichische

Maximilians-Universität pro facultate legendi vorgelegte Abhandlung ... 1848. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 28 Mar, 7, 14 Apr 1848 (in journal), p. [1]-32. <em>Copies</em>: B, G, M. –Reprinted and to
	be cited from Flora 31: 189-197. 28 Mar, 210-221. 7 Apr, 229-240. 14 Apr 1848.

11.659. <em>Liste der in der deutschen Flora enthaltenen Gefässpflanzen</em> zunächst nach Koch's

...) 1849. Oct. (<em>Liste deut. Fl. Gefässpfl.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1849, p. [1]-114. <em>Copy</em>: M.

11.660. <em>Die Vegetations-Verhältnisse Südbayerns</em> nach den Grundsätzen der Pflanzengeo-

Senebier, Jean (1742-1809), Swiss linguist, bibliographer, meteorologist, physiologist,
botanist, philosopher and clergyman; pastor at Genève (1765) and Chancy 1769-1773;
librarian of the city of Genève 1773-1809; in temporary retirement at Rolle, Vaud
during the Genève revolution (1793). (<em>Seneb</em>.).

PAGE: 505
HEADING: SENEBIER

Senft, [Philipp] Emanuel (1870-1922), Austrian (Bohemia-born) botanist (lichenolo-
gist) and pharmacist; army pharmacist 1896; military pharmacist at the Josefinum,
Wien, 1908; "Oberinspector" of the "k.k. landwirtschaftlich-chemischen Versuchssta-
tion", Wien, from 1913. (<em>E. Senft</em>).

Senft, [Carl Friedrich] Ferdinand (1810-1893), German (Thuringian) botanist, geolo-
gist and mineralogist; studied theology and natural sciences at Göttingen; cand. theol.
ib. 1834; lecturer, later professor (1850) for natural sciences at the Forestry College of
Eisenach 1834-1890; also high school teacher at the Eisenach Gymnasium 1843-1875;
Geh. Hofrath 1890. (<em>Senft</em>).

HEADING: SENNEN

	"Sammlung naturwissenschaftlicher Taschenbücher ii. Alpen-Flora ... Westalpen

<em>Ref</em>.: Mez, C., Bot. Centralbl. 104: 236-237. 1907 (rev.; "in dieser für die systematische
	Wissenschaft kritischen Zeit tritt ein Docent der Botanik einer deutschsprechenden
	Hochschule mit einem systematischen Werk hervor, welches an Dilettantismus die
	schlimmsten Leistungen der Botanophili weit hinter sich lässt. Die Senn'sche
	Alpenflora und ihren Verfasser abzuschütteln ist eine Lebensnotwendigkeit für die
	systematische Botanik". ..." Die systematische Botanik ... hat mit dem Verfasser
	nichts zu tun".

Senn, Harold Archie (1912-x), Canadian botanist; Dr. phil. Univ. Virginia 1937;
natural research fellow in botany, Harvard from 1937-1938; Asst., Div. Bot., Dept.
Agric. Ottawa 1938-1941, assoc. botanist 1941-1945, senior botanist from 1945. (<em>H.
Senn</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: DAO; further material at BR, C, DPU, E, GB, MO, TRT, U,
US. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 260 (b. 12 Jan 1912); Biol.-Dokum. 16:
8624; Bossert p. 360; IH 1 (ed. 1): 72, (ed. 2): 91, (ed. 3): 115, (ed. 6): 165, 342, (ed. 7):
342, 2: (files); Langman p. 693; PH 209; SIA 226-227 (HI 107).

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., World biography L-Z: 4304. 1948; Who's who Agric. Inst. Canada 185.
	1948.

Sennen, <em>frère</em> [Étienne Marcelin Grenier-Blanc; also: Granié] (1861-1937), French bota-

PAGE: 510
HEADING: SENNEN

nist and clergyman to the "Frères des écoles chrétiennes"; director of schools at Prades
1896-1898 and La Nouvelle 1898-1904; from 1904 director of his congregation's school
at Figueiras (Catalonia); ultimately at Marseilles; student of the flora of the Iberian
Peninsula and Morocco. (<em>Sennen</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BC (100.000). Other material at A, AL, B (extant), BC, BCF,
BH, BM, BP, BR, C, CR, DAO, DBN, DPU, DS, G, GB, GE, GZU, H, JE, K, KRA,
L, LA, LAU, LD, MA, MAF, MANCH, MO, MPU, NY, OXF, PH, RAB, S, SI, U,
US, VT, W, WELC. Most of the plants in these herbaria are from his series of exsiccatae
<em>Plantes d'Espagne</em>, 1907-1936, 9850 nos. – <em>Letters</em> (50) of S. to Malinvaud at P; other
letters at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 1: 197 (under Blanc, b. 13 Jul 1861, d. 16 Jan
1937), 3: 260; BJI 2: 163; BL 1: 47, 318, 2: 715-716 (index); BM 8: 1178; Bossert p. 360;
Clokie p. 241 (n.b. "Sennen, Granier and Étienne" are all Sennen); Hegi 6(1): 98;
Hortus 3: 1204; IF suppl. 1: 85; IH (ed. 2): 19, (ed. 3): 22, (ed. 6): 364, (ed. 7): 342, 2:
(files); Tucker 3: 277.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Aymonin, G.G., C.R. Congr. Sav. (Limoges) 102(3): 57. 1977 (corr.
	Malinvaud).

	d'Espagne").

Sennholz, Gustav (1850-1895), German (Frankfurt) botanist and gardener; educated
at the Kassel gymnasium; student gardener at Wilhelmshöhe i.d. Lehre and Kassel;
gardener at Potsdam 1869-1870; in Franco-Prussian war 1870-1871; again in Potsdam
and Kassel 1871-1874; with Gebr. Siesmayer in Bockenheim nr. Frankfurt a. M. 1874-
1884; city-gardener of Wien 1884-1895; also active as a floristic botanist. (<em>Sennholz</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: MB (Ludwig, Hess. fl. Briefe 16); further material at GOET, W.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 260 (d. 24 Aug 1895); DTS 1: 280-281; Hegi
6(2): 912.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Allg. bot. Z. 1: 200. 189 (d. 27 Aug 1895); Bot. Centralbl. 64: 143. 1895
	(d. 27 Aug 1895); Österr. bot. Z. 45: 407. 1895 (d. 27 Aug 1895).
Fritsch, C., Verh. zool.-bot. Ges. Wien 45(8): 315-317. 1895 (obit.).
Magnus, P., Ber. deut. bot. Ges. 13: (55)-(58). 1895 (obit., d. 24 Aug 1895).
Wagenitz, G., Index coll. princ. herb. Gott. 156. 1982.

Senni, Lorenzo (1879-1954), Italian forester and botanist who conducted forestry
explorations and made botanical collections in Eritrea 1905-1907, 1929, 1937, and
Somalia 1937; consul in the "Fascist forest militia" during the Mussolini era. (<em>Senni</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Material in BI, FT and MOD.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Saccardo 2: 100; TL-2/5684.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Cufodontis, G., C.R. AETFAT 4: 247. 1962 (coll.).
Lusina, G., Annali di Bot. 25: 171. 1958.
White, A. &amp; B.L. Sloane, The Stapelieae 1: 139. 1937, ed. 2: 139, 183. 1937.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Sennia</em> Chiovenda (1932).

11.691. Biblioteca agraria coloniale. Dott. Lorenzo Lorenzo Senni console milizia fore-
stale <em>Gli alberi e le formazioni legnose della Somalia</em> ... Firenze (Istituto agricolo coloniale
italiano) 1935-XIII. (<em>Alb. form. legn. Somalia</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1935, p. [i-vi], [1]-305. <em>Copies</em>: FI, USDA.

Senoner, Adolf (1806-1895), Austrian physician, botanist and librarian; educated as
surgeon at Pavia and Padua; military surgeon, later practicing physician in Lower
Austria; from 1866 librarian, later archivist of the Austrian Geologische Reichsanstalt.
(<em>Senoner</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Some material at FI. – <em>Letters</em> to D.F.L. von Schlechtendal at
HAL; other letters at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 260 (b. 29 Jul 18 1806, d. 30 Aug 1895;
Biol.-Dokum. 16: 8624-8625; BL 2: 356, 716; BM 4: 1901; Bossert p.3 60; CSP 5: 645-
646, 8: 935-936, 11: 393, 12: 675, 18: 695; Herder p. 23, 330, 376, 394, 423; Hortus 3:
1204; Morren ed. 10, p. 31; MW p. 444; Quenstedt p. 396; Saccardo 1: 152, 227, 2: 100
(d. 29 Aug 1895).

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Ackermann, Abh. Ber. Ver. Naturk. Kassel 41: vii. 1896.
Anon., Bot. Centralbl. 64: 143. 1895 (d. 29 Aug 1895); Flora 39: 16. 1856 (herbarium
	for sale), 40: 48, 222. 1857; Österr. bot. Z. 11: 372. 1861 (Greek decoration), 45: 407.
	1895 (d.); Verh. k.k. geol. Reichsanst. 11: 295. 1895 (obit. not); Zool. Gart. 36: 287.

HEADING: SERINGE

Sergievskaja, Lidia Palladievna (1897-1970), Russian botanist at the P.N. Krilov
Herbarium of the V.V. Kuibyshev State University of Tomsk. (<em>Sergiev</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: TK. – Other material at C, DAO, LE, M.

Serguéeff, Marguérite (1877-?), Russian botanist, who studied at Genève 1900-1908;

Seringe, Nicolas Charles (1776-1858), French botanist; studied medicine at the
Faculté de Paris; army-surgeon 1796-1801; teacher (French language) in Bern 1801-
1820, in Genève 1820-1830; professor of botany and director of the botanical garden at
Lyon 1830-1858. (<em>Ser</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: LY (ca. 17.000). – The types of Seringe's work for the <em>Prodromus</em>
of de Candolle are at G. – Other material, including various series of <em>exsiccatae</em> at AWH,
B (mainly destr.), BERN, BM, BR, C, CGE, DBN, E, FI, G, G-DC, GOET, H, KIEL,
L, LE, M, MANCH, MPU, MO, NEU, NY, OXF, P, RAB, S, SI, TL, TO, U, US, W,
WELC, WRSL.

PAGE: 514
HEADING: SERINGE

<em>Exsiccatae</em>: (1) <em>Saules de la Suisse</em>, 88 nos., 1805-1814 sets at BR, G, GOET, GH, L, LE,
NEU, P, S, TL, TO, W, WRSL. – For text see below.
(2) <em>Herbarium helveticum</em>, nos. 1-612, sets a FH, W.
(3) <em>Décades des roses desséchées</em>, Bern, 1(1-10) Jan 1807, 2(11-20), 3(21-30) Feb 1808, 4(31-
40), 5(41-50). 1818. – For commentary see <em>Mél. bot.</em> 1: 1-63. Jul 1818 (below). Sets at
BR, G, NEU, TO.
(4) <em>Dryadeae</em>, Agrimoniaceae et Ulmariae exsiccatae, Bern, 1823, 2 decades. – For com-
mentary see below <em>Dryadeae</em> (1823). Sets at BR, G.
(5) <em>Mousses helvétiques</em> Bern, 1804-1809, 10 dec., nos. 1-100. Not seen by us but see Sayre
1971 for dates and further information (sets at BM, G, TO). – J. Collins saw a set with
the title <em>Collection des Mousses de la Suisse</em>, Bern 1809, 10 dec., accompanied by 2 p. text.
(in litt.).
(6) <em>Herbier portatif des Alpes</em>, Bern 1809-1813, 5 cent. Set: G. – See below for text.
(7) <em>Plantes de France</em>, Bern 1810, see below for text. Set at G.
(8) <em>Collection des Graminées, Cyperacées et Joncées de la Suisse</em>, Bern 1816, 2 cent., see below
for text. Set at G.
(9) <em>Exemplaires desséchés de la révision inédite du genre Salix</em>, Genève 1824 (text at M, see
below).
(10) <em>Souvenir de la Suisse</em> ou collection de plantes choisies des Alpes (n.v.).
<em>Letters</em> to D.F.L. von Schlechtendal at HAL; other letters at G, GH.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 6(1): 186; Backer p. 529; Barnhart 3: 260 (b. 3 Dec
1776, d. 29 Sep 1858); BM 1: 750, 1903; Clokie p. 241; CSP 5: 646-647, 11: 394; Frank 3

<em>Cucurbitaceae</em>, 3: 297-320. med. Mar 1828.
<em>Leguminosae</em>, 2: 171-215, 354-380. med. Nov 1825.
<em>Onagrariae</em> (<em>Epilobium, Gaura, Oenothera</em>), 3: 40-52. med. Mar 1828.
<em>Ranunculaceae</em> (<em>Aconitum</em>), 1: 56-64. med. Jan 1824.
<em>Rosaceae</em>, 2: 530-625. med. Nov 1825.
<em>Saxifragaceae</em> (<em>Weinmannia, Hydrangea, Saxifraga, Leptarrhena, Chrysosplenium, Mitella, Tiarel-
la, Heuchera</em>) 4: 8-51. Sep (sero) 1830.
(2) <em>Rétablissement du genre Scorodonia de Moench</em> and <em>Mémoire sur le fruit et l'embryon des
Labiées</em>, in A. Hamilton, <em>Esq. monogr. Scutellaria</em> 1832, TL-2/2338.
(3) Collaborator, G. Roffavier, <em>Suppl. fl. Lyonn.</em> 1835, see TL-2/9432.
(4) <em>Verzeichniss der Pflanzen welche auf der Scheideck, der Wengernalp</em>, und in den Thälern von
Lauterbrunnen, Grindelwald und Hasli gefunden werden, <em>in</em> F.N. Koenig, <em>Reise in die
Alpen</em> 1814 (n.v.).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Seringe's son Jean Claude Seringe (1810-1833) was primarily an entomologist but
also a botanist and botanical artist (see Levrat 1833 and Magnin 1910, p. 77).

<sm>HANDWRITING</sm>: Candollea 33: 383-384. 1978.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Seringia</em> K.P.J. Sprengel (1818, <em>nom. rej.</em>); <em>Seringia</em> J. Gay (1821, <em>nom. cons.</em>).

11.696. <em>Saules de la Suisse</em> 1er [-7me] cahier. [Bern 1805-1814], 7 parts. 

<em>Publ</em>.: in 7 "cahiers", 1805-1814, preceding Seringe's formal treatment in his <em>Essai
	monogr. Saules</em> (1815). Complete <em>copy</em> seen by us: MICH; for other copies see above
	under Herbarium and Types.
	<em>1</em>: Dec 1805, cover and 1 p. text, exs. nos. 1-6.
	<em>2</em>: Dec 1805, cover, 1 p. text, exs. nos. 7-11.
	<em>3</em>: Dec 1805, cover, 1 p. text, exs. nos. 12-18.
	<em>4</em>: Dec 1806, cover, 1 p. text, exs. nos. 19-27.
	<em>5</em>: Jan 1808, cover, 2 p. text, exs. nos. 28-44.
	<em>6</em>: 1809, cover with list of names, no text, exs. nos. 45-60.
	<em>7</em>: 1814, cover with list of names, no text, exs. nos. 61-88.
	"Des remarques sur les 7 cahiers de cette collection vont être publiées" (bottom line
	on text of cover cahier 7): refers to <em>Essai monogr. Saules.</em>
<em>Ref</em>.: McVaugh, R., Mich. Botanist 7: 9-11. 1968.

11.704. <em>Mélanges botaniques</em> ou recueil d'observations, mémoires, et notices sur la
botanique, par Nicolas Charles Seringe, Instituteur à l'Académie de Berne ... Berne
(chez l'Auteur) 1818-1831, 2 vols., 6 parts. Oct. (<em>Mél. bot.</em>).

<em>1</em>: 1818 (HH copy has imprint Berne-Leipzig 1819), p. [i]-vi, [1]-244, <em>1 pl</em>. (uncol.),
	contains:
	(<em>1</em>): Jul 1818, <em>Critique de cinq décades de Roses désséchées</em>, p. [1]-63.
	(<em>2</em>): Sep 1818, <em>Monographie des céréales de la Suisse</em>, p. [65]-244.
<em>2</em>: 1824-1831, issued in four parts (nos. 3-6) with various imprints.
	(<em>3</em>): Mai 1824, p. [i-iv], [1]-44, chart. – <em>Mélanges</em> ... botanique ... vol. ii no. 3 de la
	collection. Genève (chez l'Auteur, ...) 1824. – Title on p. [1]: "<em>Notes sur les Plantae
	selectae siccae collatae in herbario De Candollii</em> et descriptae in Prodromo systematis
	naturalis regni vegetabilis".
	(<em>4/5</em>): Mar 1826, p. [i, t.p. dated Mar 1826], [45, dated 1 Mar 1826]-70, [71, dated 28
	Mar 1826]-114. – <em>Mélanges</em> ... botanique ... vol. ii. Deuxième partie. N.° 4 et 5 de
	la collection. <em>Observations sur le genre Ranunculus</em>, et particulièrement sur les
	charactères à tirer des carpelles pour la distinction des espèces [p. 45-70, 1 Mar
	1826], Observations sur la nature des fleurs et des inflorescences, par J. Roeper [p.
	71-114, 28 Mar 1826; Johannes August Christian Roeper, 1801-1885]. Genève
	(chez l'Auteur, ...) Mars 1826.
	(<em>6</em>) Oct 1831, p. [115]-156, [157-158], <em>pl. 1-2. Mélanges</em> ... botanique, ... volume ii. –
	n.° 6 de la collection, contenant un <em>mémoire sur la culture et l'emploi des céréales</em> et de
	quelques autres graminées, pour la fabrication des chapeaux et des tissus de paille,
	suivi de notes sur les graminées en général. Extrait des Memoires de la Société
	royale d'agriculture histoire naturelle et arts utiles de Lyon. Lyon (Imprimerie de
	J.M. Barret, ...) Octobre 1831. Oct.
<em>Copies</em>: B-S, BR, G, HH, MO, NY, PH (vol. 2), USDA (vol. 2).
<em>Other issue of vol. 1</em>: 1819, p. [i]-vi, [1]-244, <em>1 pl</em>., chart. <em>Copies</em>: G, NY. – Berne (chez la
	Société typographique), Leipsic [Leipzig] (chez Ch. Cnobloch en commission) 1819.
	Oct.

11.727. <em>Nouvelle disposition des familles végétales</em>. Par classes, sous-classes, ordres et sous-
ordres, avec les caractères distinctifs de ces divisions, accompagnée d'un catalogue al-
phabétique des familles renvoyées au tableau général ... Paris (Victor Masson ...) 1856.
Qu. (<em>Nouv. disp. fam. nat.</em>).

Seraander, [Johan] Rutger (1866-1944), Swedish botanist; Dr. phil. Uppsala 1894;
lecturer in plant geography and general botany Uppsala 1899; acting professor of plant
biology 1908, ordinary professor 1909; outstanding plant ecologist and quarternary
botanist, founder of the Uppsala School of phytosociology. (<em>Sern</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: UPSV. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 261 (b. 2 Nov 1866); BFM 2684-2685; BJI

112; Collander p. 483, hist. p. 48, 77, 115; GR p. 481-482, <em>pl</em>. [<em>39</em>], cat. p. 71; Hirsch p.
271; Kleppa p. 6, 8, 59, 62, 170, 234, 237, 238; KR p. 635-640 (detailed bibl.); Lenley p.
366; LS 24675-25676, 39171, suppl. 25311-25316; Moebius p. 364, 375; Nordstedt p. 29;
Rehder 5: 794; SBC p. 132; SO see index p. 49-50; TL-2/5252, 8189, see A.H. Magnus-
son; Tucker 1: 645.

Serres, Jean Jacques (1790-1858), French botanist and soldier; with the Napoleonic
Army in the Russian campaign; in charge of a gun factory at Toulouse, ultimately in
retirement at Roche-des-Arnauds, nr Gap, France, dedicating himself entirely to
botany. (<em>J. Serres</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown; the herbarium (7000 sp.) was bought by the seminary
of Embrun (Bull. Soc. bot. France 5: 400. 1858, 6: 384. 1859).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 261 (b. 24 Apr 1790, d. 16 Aug 1858); BM
4: 1904; PR 8628-8629, ed. 1: 9589; Rehder 1: 409.

Anon., Bull. Soc. bot. France 6: viii. 1859 (d.); Table art. originaux 1854-1893 Bull.
	Soc. bot. France 219.

époques de fleuraison de chaque plante; suivi d'une clef analytique des genres et des

11.748. <em>Korte verhandeling van de boomen</em>, heesters en houtagtige kruid-gewassen, welke in
de Nederlandsche lugtstreek de winterkoude konnen uitstaan, en dienen tot beplanting
van lust-hoven, laanen, haagen, wild- en wandel-bosschen; enz. Opgesteld na de letter-
order der latijnsche naamen, aanwyzende wat klas en rang zij hebben in het samenstel
der planten van den heer en ridder Linnaeus; waar bij overal de natuurlijke groei-
plaats, aankwekinge, de hoedanige grond, stand-plaats, de bekwaame afstand waar op
zij moeten geplant worden en het huishoudelijk gebruik der zelve, beknopt en klaarlijk
is aengetoond. Met een afbeelding van de kenteekens der klassen. Tot Mechelen (by
Petrus-Josephus Hanicq, Boekdrukker) 1789. Oct. (<em>Korte verh. boom.</em>).

Servít, Miroslav (1886-1959), Moravian botanist (lichenologist); studied at the
Charles University and Agricultural College Praha; assistant at the Agricultural College
of Tabor 1910-1914; Dr. phil. 1915; from 1920 professor, from 1923 director of the state
agricultural experimental station and college at Horice, from 1936 id. at the Agricul-
tural college, Königgrätz (Hradec Kralové); retired 1943 but from 1945-1950 director of
the Agricultural college at Kaaden (Kadan); in retirement at Bettlern nr Klösterle
(Klašterce nad Ohre). (<em>Servít</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: PRM; other material at BP, BRNM, BRNU, M, PRC, W.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 261 (b. 17 Dec 1886); Biol.-Dokum. 16:
8630; Bossert p. 360; Futak-Domin p. 521; GR p, 666-667, <em>pl</em>. [<em>25</em>], cat. p. 71;
Hawksworth p. 186; Hirsch p. 271; IH 1 (ed. 6): 364, (ed. 7): 342; Kelly p. 211;
Klásterský p. 163 (d. 6 Apr 1959); LS 39174-39176, suppl. 25318-25323; Roon p. 102;
SBC p. 132.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Preslia 31: 431. 1959 (d.), 48: 272. 1976 (d. 6 Apr 1959); Rev. bryol.
	lichénol. 8: 237. 1935, 10: 113. 1937, 18: 198. 1949, 19: 257, 258. 1950, 20: 242. 1951,
	23: 239. 1954, 24: 181, 407. 1955, 25: 406. 1956 (rev. and notes on his publ.), 28(3-4):

Sesler, Lionardo (x-1785), Venetian physician and naturalist and director of a botan-
ical garden at Santa Maria di Sala. (<em>Sesl</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 2(1): 310; Backer p. 529-530; Barnhart 3: 261; BM
4: 1905; Bossert p. 361; Dryander 3: 245; DTS 1: 281; Frank 3 (Anh.): 96; Hegi 1: 265;
Herder p. 317; Hortus 3: 1204; PR 2370, ed. 1: 2681; RS p. 142; Saccardo 1: 153; TL-
2/1500; Zander ed. 10, p. 716, ed. 11, p. 817.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Dandy, J.E., Regn. veg. 51: 19. 1967 (standing of his publication in V. Donati's
	<em>Essai</em>).
Fries, T.M., Bref Skrifv. Linné 1(3): 67. 1909.
Hulth, J.M., Bref Skrifv. Linné 2(1): 90, 91. 1916.
Lowden, R.M., Taxon, Index pers. names vols. 1-30. 660. 1985.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: See Vitaliano Donati, Stor. nat. Adriat. 1750, TL-2/1500, for Sesler's
letter on <em>Vitaliana</em> and its standing in nomenclature (the French edition of 1758 counts).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Sesleria</em> Scopoli (1760); <em>Sesleriella</em> Deyl (1946).

Sessé y Lacasta, Martin de (1751-1808), Spanish physician and botanist; practiced in
Madrid 1775-1776; army doctor in Spain and Cuba; to Mexico City 1785; director of
the Royal botanical expedition to New Spain and director of the Royal botanical
garden in Mexico 1787; devoting himself only to botany from 1789; in the field in

PAGE: 526
HEADING: SESSÉ Y LACASTA

Western Mexico 1789-1792; to the Atlantic slope of Mexico 1793, to Cuba and Puerto
Rico 1795-1798; returned to Madrid in 1803. (<em>Sessé</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: The original Sessé and Mociño herbarium is at MA (8000).
Duplicates are in several herbaria (BM, F, FI, G, G-DC, K, MO, NY, OXF, US). In
addition to the herbarium, Sessé and Mociño brought together a large collection of
coloured plates (now at HU) drawn from living specimens in Mexico and Puerto Rico
(artists Atanasio Echeverria and Juan Cerda). These drawings were obtained on loan by
A.P. de Candolle, who had them copied before returning them to Mociño (IDC 713).
De Candolle based 279 species and 17 new genera on them. These sets of "outlines"
were distributed by Alph. de Candolle to B, BR, C, FI, GH, K, L, LE, P, US, W. – See
TL-2/977. For the original drawings see below (Manuscripts).

<sm>MANUSCRIPTS</sm>: Botanical manuscripts mainly at MA (see Divito 1968); other manuscript
material relative to the Royal botanical expedition is in the Mexican national archives.
See R. McVaugh (<em>in</em> DSB and other publications listed below) for a summary of the
material, and see H.W. Rickett 1947 for an account of the Expedition and its partici-
pants. The original collection of botanical and zoological illustrations mentioned above
were acquired by the Hunt Institute for Botanical Documentation (HU) in 1981, see
e.g. R.W. Kiger (1981); about 100 original illustrations are at MA. – Some <em>letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 657; Barnhart 3: 261; Blunt p. 303; BM 4:
1905, 8: 1179; Clokie p. 242; Colmeiro penins. p. 64, 184-185, 379-381; DSB 12: 326-328
(extensive inf. by R. McVaugh; b. 11 Dec 1751; d. 4 Oct 1808); Hortus 3: 1204 (d.
1809); IF 730, suppl. 2: 338; IH 1 (ed. 2): 51, 92, (ed. 3): 62, 117, (ed. 6): 364, (ed. 7):
342, 2: (files); Langman p. 513, 695 (see also subject index); Lasègue p. 205-206, 304,
322, 348, 504; NI 1: 159, 3: 7; PR alph.; Rehder 1: 332; TL-1/1224-1225; TL-2/977, see
J.M. Mociño, J.A. Pavon); Tucker 1: 646; Zander ed. 10, p. 716, ed. 11, p. 817.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Alvarez Lopez, E., Anal. Inst. bot. Cavanilles 10(2): 1-79. 1951, 11: 39-341.
	1952; Bol. R. Soc. Esp. Hist. nat. 48: 259-274. 1950 (on botanical results of the earlier

	Arch. Minist. Asunt. ext. (very detailed description of the Expedición, with repro-
	duction of several mss. texts).

	ont servi de types d'espèces dans le système ou le Prodromus, Genève 1874, 6 p., 297

<sm>REVIEW OF BOTANICAL RESULTS EXPEDITION</sm>: see R. McVaugh, <em>Botanical results of the Sessé
&amp; Mociño expedition</em> (<em>1787-1803</em>), i. <em>Summary of excursions and travels, in</em> Contr. Univ. Mich.
Herb. 11(3): 97-195. 1977, ii. <em>The Icones Florae Mexicanae, in</em> id. 14: 99-140. 1980. – For a
general discussion of the scientific aspects see J.H. Wilson (1962); for a description of the
botanical aspects of the expedition see H.W. Rickett (1947).

<sm>HANDWRITING</sm>: Candollea 33: 385-386. 1978.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Sessea</em> Ruiz et Pavon (1794); <em>Sesseopsis</em> Hassler (1917).

11.755. <em>Plantae Nouae</em> [<em>sic</em>] <em>Hispaniae</em>. Nutu, ope et auspicio benignissimi regis Caroli iv,
adùc usque collectae, et Linneano systemate ordinate, quarum tercentae aut plures a
nemine unquam editae videntur et rariores iconibus ad vivum repraesentantur. Aucto-
ribus Martino Sesse et Josepho Mariano Moçiño. Mexici [Mexico] (apud Ignatium
Escalante ...) 1887 [-1890]. Qu. (<em>Pl. nov. Hisp.</em>).

<em>Co-author</em>: José Mariano Moçiño (1757-1820), see TL-2/3: 529-530.
<em>Publ</em>.: 1887-1890 in 9 parts as appendices to La Naturaleza, ser. 2, vol. 1, p. [i*-viii*],
	[i]-xiii, [1]-184. <em>Copies</em>: FI, HH, MO, USDA; IDC 6121.
	1: 1-16. 1887.
	2: 17-40. 1888.
	3: 41-64. 1888.
	4: 65-88. 1888.
	5: 89-112. 1889.
	6: 113-136. 1890.
	7: 137-160. 1890.
	8: 161-184, [i]-viii. 1890.
	9: ix-xiii. 1890.
	[p. i*-viii* were probably publ. 1887].
<em>Ed. 2</em>: 1893 (Nat. Nov. Jun 1894), p. [i]-viii, [ix], [1]-175, [i]-xiii. <em>Copies</em>: B-S, MO, NY,
	PH, U. – <em>Plantas de Nueva España</em> coleccionadas por mandato y bajo los auspicios del
	benignísimo rey Cárlos iv, y ordenadas conforme al sistema de Linneo. Comprende
	mas de treuentes que nunca habian sido descritas algunas muy raras figuradas en
	dibujos tornados del natural [no authors name]. Segunda edicion ... México (Oficina
	tipográfica de la secretaria de Fomento ... 1893. Qu.
<em>Ed. 2, other issue</em>: 1893, p. [i]-viii, [ix] [1]-175, [i]-xiii. <em>Copies</em>: FI, MO, USDA. – Differs
	only in t.p. (in Latin): <em>Plantae novae hispaniae</em> ... [as in ed, 1] ... Mociño. Edition
	secunda. México (Oficina tip. de la Secretaria de Fomento ...) 1893.
<em>Ref</em>.: McVaugh, R., Contr. Univ. Mich. Herb. 11(3): 112-117. 1977.
	Roth, E., Bot. Centralbl. Beih. 4(5): 365-366. 1894 (lists genera treated in alphabet-
	ical order).

11.756. <em>Flora mexicana</em>. Autoribus Martinus Sessé et Josephus Mariannus Moçiño. Mexici
[México] (apud Ignatius Escalante ...) 1887 [i-e. 1891-1897]. Qu. (<em>Fl. mexic</em>).

<em>Co-author</em>: José Mariano Mociño (1757-1820), see TL-2/3: 529-530.
<em>Publ</em>.: in 10 parts which appeared as supplements to the issues of "La Naturaleza". The
	precise dates have not yet been established but Manitz (1982) mentions the existence

	of a copy of the journal with original covers which make it possible to list precise

	30 Sep 1894.

Setchell, William Albert (1864-1943), American botanist (algologist), plant geo-
grapher and botanical historian; student of D.C. Eaton and W.G. Farlow; Morgan
Fellow, Harvard 1887-1890; Dr. phil. Harvard 1890; assistant at Yale University 1891-
1895; professor of botany at the University of California, Berkeley from 1895-1934;
travelled widely: Santa Cruz Mts. Calif. 1896; Alaska and Bering Sea 1899, around the
world 1903-1904, 1926-1927; Tutuila, Samoa 1920; Tahiti 1922; Hawaii 1924; Java
1929; Alaska 1931, 1932. (<em>Setch</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: UC. – Correspondence and field notes also at UC. – Setchell
built up the outstanding algological herbarium and library at UC in close cooperation
with N.L. Gardner. – Other material (excl. of exsicc): BISH, BM, C, E, F, G, GH, H,
K, L, M (lich.), MEL, MIN, US, YU.
<em>Exsiccatae</em>: with Frank Shipley Collins (1848-1920) and Isaac Holden (1832-1903), <em>Phy-
cotheca boreali-americana</em>, a collection of dried specimens of the algae of North America,
fasc. 1-46, nos. 1-2300 (in all 200.000 specimens), fasc. A-E, nos. 1-125. Maiden Mass.
1895-1919. See Sayre (1969) for details, especially exact dates. An index (mimeogra-
phed) was published by Fahey &amp; Doty, "An Alphabetical index to the Phycotheca
boreali-americana", in 1955. – 80 copies issued. Sets at BM, DBN, FH, GB, M,
MANCH, MICH, MSC, NY, PC. Contributed also to V. Wittrock and O. Nordstedt,
<em>Algae aquae dulcis exsiccatae</em>. – <em>Letters</em> (198 cards etc.) to W.G. Farlow at FH; other letters
at G.
<em>Information</em> on <em>and reviews</em> of the <em>Phycotheca</em>: (1)F.S. Collins, W.A. Setchell and I. Holden,
Bull. Torrey bot. Club 21: 490. 1894, note dated Syracuse, N.Y. July 12, 1894; "The
undersigned have made preparations for the issuing of sets of dried specimens of the
North American Algae, both of the fresh and of the salt waters, for the aid of in-
vestigators ... Contributions of sets of 80 specimens each are solicited".
(2) Hedwigia 34: (67). 1895: ".. beabsichtigen eine Phycotheca Boreali-Americana

PAGE: 529
HEADING: SETCHELL

herauszugeben. Jedes Fascikel wird 50 Arten enthalten und 5 Dollars kosten. Subscript-
ion ... Frank S. Collins, ..."
(3) Bot. Gaz. 20(3): 126. Mar 1895 "... announce the issue ... The fascicles will be
issued this winter of which the first has already appeared ... The edition is limited to
eighty copies ..."
(4) Reviews of <em>fasc. 1</em> and <em>2</em> by Humphrey (Baltimore, MD), Bot. Centralbl. 63: 106-
107. 1895, 64: 161-162. 1895.
(5) Full listing of contents <em>fasc. 1-17</em> in Hedwigia 34: (35)-(36). 1895(1), 34: (99).
1895(2), 35: (30). 1896(3), 35: (91). 1896(4), 36: (74)-(75). 1897(5), 36: (99). 1897(6),
37: (27). 1898(7), 37: (83). 1898(8), 37: (198)-(199). 1898(9), 38: (111)-(112). 1899(11),
38: (240)-(241). 1899(12), 41: (48). 1902(17).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 262 (b. 15 Apr 1864, d. 5 Apr 1943); BJI 1:
54, 2: 163; BL 1: 127, 129, 318; BM 4: 1905, 8: 1179; Bossert p. 361; CSP 18: 703; De
Toni 4: liii; DSB 12: 328-329 (by J. Ewan; bibl.); Ewan 2: 198; Hawksworth p. 186;
Hirsch p. 271; IH 1 (ed. 2): 22, (ed. 3): 25, (ed. 6): 364, (ed. 7): 342; Kelly p. 211, 257;
Lenley p. 366; LS 24685-24687, 39177-39180, suppl. 25324-25325; MW p. 445; Nordt-
stedt suppl. 18; NW p. 57; PH 444; SIA 192, 201, 220, 223, 233, 7097 (1050102; HI
107); SK 8: lxxxviii; Stevenson p. 1257; TL-2/see F.S. Collins, N.L. Gardner, H.E.
Parks; Tucker 3: 277; Urban-Berl. p. 269.

Verdoorn, F., ed., Chron. bot. 1: 283. 1935, 2: 34, 299. 1936, 3: 27, 112, 266, 267, 370.
	1937, 4: 85, 184, 266. 1938, 5: 302, 359. 1939.
Wittrock, V.B., Acta Horti Berg. 3(2): 180, <em>pl. 36.</em> 1902 (portr.), 3(3): 201. 1905.
Wulff, E., Intr. hist. pl. geogr. 129, 136, 200. 1943.

PAGE: 530
HEADING: SETCHELL

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Setchell's unpublished outline for his history of botany course was
used by H.S. Reed in his <em>Short history of the plant sciences</em>, Waltham, Mass. 1942 (fide
Ewan, D.S.B.).
(2) Founder and editor of Univ. Calif. Publ. Bot., vol. 1, 1902-1903, editor through vol.
17. 1932-1934.

<sm>FESTSCHRIFT</sm>: T.H. Goodspeed, ed., <em>Essays in geobotany</em> in honor of William Albert
Setchell, Berkeley 1936 (biogr. introd. by ed. p. xi-xxiv, also list of principal journeys
and expeditions), xxv, 319 p., portr. – Other contributions by O.W. Arrhenius, E.B.
Babcock, R.W. Chaney, F.E. Clements, W.S. Cooper, L. Diels, F.E. Fritsch, D.R.
Hoogland, E.D. Merrill, E. Rübel, C. Skottsberg, followed by a bibliography on p. 313-
319.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Setchellanthus</em> T.S. Brandegee (1909); <em>Setchellia</em> Magnus (1896); <em>Setchelliella</em> G.
De Toni (1936); <em>Setchelliogaster</em> Pouzar (1958).

<em>Publ</em>.: 11 Mai 1937, cover-t.p., [193]-243, <em>pl. 23-29. Copies</em>: BR, FH, MO, NY, U, US. –
	Issued as and to be cited from Univ. Calif. Publ. Bot. 19(6): 195-244, <em>pl. 23-29.</em> 11 Mai
	1937.

11.805. <em>Iridophycus in the Northern Hemisphere</em> ... [Reprinted from the Proceedings of the
National Academy of Sciences vol. 23, no. 3, pp. 169-174. March 1937]. Oct. 

<em>Co-author</em>: Nathaniel Lyon Gardner (1864-1937).
<em>Publ</em>.: Mar 1937, p. [169]-174. <em>Copy</em>: G. – Reprinted and to be cited from <em>Proc. Natl.
Acad. Sci.</em> as indicated above.

Seubert, Moritz August (1818-1878), German (Baden) botanist at Karlsruhe; studied
medicine at Heidelberg and natural sciences at Bonn; Dr. phil. Bonn 1841; habil. ib.
1843; professor of botany and zoology and director of the natural history museum of the
Karlsruhe Polytechnic; Hofrath (Baden) 1877. (<em>Seub</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: HEID (types Baden Musci fide Alph. de Candolle/Döll), FI, L,
M (lich.), W, WAG. – The <em>Flora azorica</em> is based on C.F. Hochstetter collections (q.v.),
specimens in many herbaria. – <em>Letters</em> to D.F.L. von Schlechtendal at HAL; to F.A.W.
Miquel at U; other letters at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 34: 51-52 (E. Wunschmann); AG 3: 169; Backer p.
661; Barnhart 3: 262 (b. 2 Jun 1818, d. 6 Apr 1878); BFM 569; BL 1: 86, 318; BM 4:
1904-1905; CSP 5: 66, 8: 939, 11: 398; Futak-Domin p. 96; GR p. 139; Herder p. 478
[index]; IH 2: (files); Jackson p. 54, 57, 299, 301, 352; Lenley p. 366; LS 24691-24692;
Morren ed. 2, p. 11; NI 1837, 2248; PR 8633-8641, ed. 1: 9600; Rehder 5: 795; RS p.
142; TL-2/see C.F. Hochstetter, J.A. Kneucker, K.A.E. Prantl; Tucker 1: 646; Zander
ed. 10, p. 716.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bonplandia 1: 209, 223. 1853, 6(2): 52. 1858 (cogn. Leopoldina
	Bellard), 10: 318. 1862; Bot. Not. 1879: 31 (d.); Bot. Zeit. 2: 304. 1844 (habil. Bonn),
	5: 448. 1847 (distr. pl. Vinzent, Texas), 36: 256. 1878 (d.); Bull. Soc. bot. France 25
	(bibl.): 44-45. 1878 (obit. not.); Gartenflora 12: 173. 1863 (director of the Polytechnic
	at Karlsruhe); J. Bot. 16: 160. 1878 (obit. not.); Leopoldina 14: 49, 100-101. 1878
	(obit. from Karlsruher Zeit. 1878, no. 88); Magy. növen. lap. 17(2): 80. 1878 (d.).

Seurat, Léon Gaston (1872-?), French zoologist and botanist. (<em>Seurat</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: L, P.

et Orientale, ...)] s.d. 

<em>Publ</em>.: p. [1]-28. <em>Copy</em>: USDA.

Severini, Giuseppe (1878-1918), Italian mycologist and phytopathologist; studied
agricultural sciences at the Regio Istituto superiore, Perugia; Laur. sci. 1902; botanical
assistant ib. 1902-1906; at the University of Roma 1906-1908; Dr. phil. 1908; again at
Perugia as botanical assistant 1908-1914; on active service 1914-1918. (<em>Severini</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: PAD, PERU.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 262 (b. 17 Jun 1898, d. 17 Apr 1918); LS
39181-39186, 41726.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Pantanelli, E., Ann. Bot., Roma 15(1): 53-56. 1920 (obit., portr., bibl.).

Seward, Albert Charles (1863-1941), British paleobotanist; lecturer (later fellow) St.
John's College Cambridge 1890; professor of botany Cambridge 1906-1936; also Master
of Downing College 1915-1936; FRS 1898; knighted 1936; after retirement working in
London (Brit. Mus. Nat. Hist.) and Oxford. (<em>Seward</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Seward "collected very little until late in his life" (T.M. Harris).
The collections studied by Seward are mostly at Cambridge (palaeobot.); some material
from West Greenland at CGE. – Archival mat. see Bridson (1980). – <em>Letters</em> to W.G.
Farlow at FH; other letters at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Andrews p. 331-332; Barnhart 3: 262 (b. 9 Oct 1863, d.
11 Apr 1941); BJI 2: 163; BM 4: 1906-1907, 8: 1180; Bossert p. 361; CSP 18: 707-708;
Desmond p. 550-551; De Toni 4: liii; DNB 1941-1950: 771-773; DSB 12: 339-340 (T.M.
Harris); Hirsch p. 272; Lenley p. 366; Moebius p. 382; MW p. 445; NW p. 57; PH 239;
Rehder 2: 8; TL-2/see 7583, M.A. Pocock, A.C. Seward; Tucker 1: 646, 3: 277.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Andrews, H.N., The fossil hunters 110-114. 1980 (portr.).
Anon., Bot. Centralbl. 75: 96. 1898 (FRS), 102: 592. 1906 (prof. bot. Cambr.); Bot.

Seydler, Friedrich Wilhelm (1811-1897), German (East-Prussian) botanist; at the
teacher's college of Klein Dexen 1829-1831; teacher at schools in Gr.-Kuhren and Heili-
genbeil 1831, from 1861 inspector at the "Seeligerschen Erziehungsanstalt" Braunsberg;
one of the founders of the Preuss. bot. Verein. (<em>Seydler</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: KBG (destr.).

Seymour, Arthur [Bliss] (1859-1933), American botanist; MS Univ. Illinois 1886;
assistant to W.G. Farlow at Harvard 1883-1885; at the University of Wisconson 1885-
1886; permanently appointed to the staff of the Cryptogamic Herbarium, Harvard
1886, especially engaged on the Harvard mycological indexes. (<em>Seym</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: ILL, WIS (in herb. F.C. Seymour). – Further material at BPI,
CAS, CS, CUP, DAO, DUKE, FH, GH, IA, ILL, ILLS, K, L, M, MICH, MISSA,
MO, NCU, PH, SD, WELC, WRSL.
<em>Exsiccatae</em>: (1) see J. Stevenson (1971) p. 372-383, especially for the major series, issued
with Franklin Sumner Earle (1856-1929), <em>Economic fungi</em>, fasc. 1-11, nos. 1-550, 1 Jan
1890-7 Jun 1899 with suppl. A-C (12, 31, 150 nos.) 5 Apr 1898-12 Jun 1903. – Sets at
ARIZ, BM, BPI, COLO, CUP, DAOM, E, FH, GA, IA, ILL, ISC, KANU, KSC,
MASS, MICH, MIN, MONT, MSC, MTMG, MU, NCU, NDA, NEB, NHES, NYS,
OC, PUR, RM, RSA, SCHN, SDC, TRTC, UC, UMO, USC, UT, WIS, WSP. For
text and dates see below.
(2) For <em>Lichenes boreali-americani</em>, with Clara Eaton Cummings (1855-1906) and Thomas
Albert Williams (1865-1900), see C.E. Cummings: TL-2/1: 571 and Sayre (1969) p.
120.(3) Seymour contributed also to C. Roumeguère (q.v.) <em>Fungi selecti exsiccati</em>.
<em>Letters</em> at G.

HEADING: SEYMOUR, A.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Seymouria</em> R. Sweet (1824) was named for Mrs. Seymour of Woburn,
Bedfordshire, England, a grower of geraniums.

11.835. <em>Economic fungi</em> a series of specimens designed chiefly to illustrate the fungus
diseases of useful and noxious plants ... edited and published by A.B. Seymour and F.S.
Earle. Cambridge, Mass. 1890-1905. (<em>Econ. fung.</em>).

<em>Co-editor</em>: Franklin Sumner Earle (1856-1929); the <em>Ustilaginaceae</em> (C 1-C 100) edited by
	George Perkins Clinton (1867-1937).
<em>Publ</em>.: 1 Jan 1890-12 Jun 1905; text accompanying the set of exsiccatae mentioned under
	"Herbarium and Types".
	<em>1</em> (nos. 1-50): 1 Jan 1890, p. [1-3].
	<em>2</em> (nos. 51-100): 1 Jan 1891, p. [1-3]. – Parasites on grasses and grass-like plants.
	<em>3/4</em> (nos. 101-200): 1 Sep 1892, p. [1-3]. – Parasites on forest trees and other woody
	plants indigenous or cultivated for ornament.
	<em>5</em> (nos. 201-250): 1 Feb 1893, p. [1-3]. – Chiefly Uredineae parasitic on woody plants
	including Gymnosporangia with their aecidial stages.
	<em>6/8</em> (nos. 251-400): 1 Mai 1893, p. [1-4]. – Parasites on weeds ... with the cooperation
	of Byron D. [David] Halsted [1852-1918] and with the assistance of Harriet L.
	[Lathrop] Merrow [b. 1858] and Josephine Skehan.
	<em>9</em> (nos. 401-450): 1 Jul 1895, p. [1-3]. – Parasites on garden vegetables and fruit trees
	... assisted by Flora W. [Wambaugh] Patterson [1847-1928].
	<em>10</em> (nos. 451-500): 15 Oct 1897, p. [1-3]. – Chiefly parasites of ornamental herbaceous
	plants ... assisted by Jennie F. [Frances] Conant [b. 1864].
	<em>11</em> (nos. 501-550): 7 Jun 1899, p. [1-3]. – Assisted by Jennie F. Conant.
<em>Economic fungi supplement</em> including species of scientific rather than of economic interest
	(nos. A 1-10, B 1-30) 5 Apr 1898, p. [1-3]. – assisted by Jennie F. Conant.

Seym</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: MO (coll. after 1953), WIS (incl. the A.B. Seymour herb.); other

Seynes, Jules de (1833-1912), French botanist (mycologist); Dr. méd. Montpellier
1860; Dr. sci. nat. Paris 1863; aggr. Paris 1865; from then on connected with the Faculté
de médicine, Paris. (<em>De Seyn</em>.).

	International Commission on botanical nomenclature which is to convene in Vienna
	1905; appointment of J. Briquet as co-ordinator. Action resulting from a decision
	taken on 2 Oct 1900 at the Paris International Botanical Congress (first Congress).
	Signed by de Seynes as president of the Paris Congrès; cosignatories are the presidents
	and secretaries of the sessions, the secretary-general of the Congress (E. Perrot) and
	the treasurer (H. Hua). – With this pamphlet the 20th century nomenclature or-
	ganisation was founded.

Shafer, John Adolf (1863-1918), American botanist, pharmacist and plant collector;
Dr. pharm. h.c. Univ. W. Pennsylvania 1904; curator of botany Carnegie Museum,
Pittsburgh 1897-1903; collected in Cuba with N.L. Britton 1903; museum custodian
New York Botanical Garden 1904-1910; collected in Montserrat 1907 and Cuba 1909,
1910, 1911, 1912; with Britton in the West Indies 1913, at Vieques (Puerto Rico) 1914;
collecting Cactaceae for Britton and Rose in South America 1916-1917. (<em>Shafer</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: NY (25.000); early collections (2.500) also in CM; other material
at A, AMES, B (mainly destr.), BM, C, DPU, F, GH, HAC, HABE, K, L, MICH,
MO, NY, P, PH, U, US.
<em>Field books</em> for the Cuban expeditions (except for 1903) are at NY; other field notes at
	CM.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 264 (b. 23 Feb 1863, d. 1 Feb 1918); BL 1:
158, 212, 318; BM 8: 1181; Bossert p. 361; Hortus 3: 1204; Lenley p. 366; TL-2/783;
Tucker 1: 646; Urban-Berl. p. 397; Zander ed. 10, p. 716, ed. 11, p. 817.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Britton, N.L., J. New York Bot. Gard. 19: 97-99. 1918 (obit.).
Cattell, J.M., Amer. men sci. ed. 1: 287. 1906, ed. 2: 420. 1910.

Jennings, O.E., Trillia 5: 3-7. 1919 (obit.).
Kallunki, J.A., Brittonia 32(3): 397-420. 1980 (Cuban plant collections of J.A. Shafer,
	N.L. Britton and P. Wilson).

Lowden, R.M., Taxon, Index pers. names vols. 1-30. 661. 1985.
Stieber, M.T., Huntia 4: 162. 1982 (field notes).

Shaler, Nathaniel Southgate (1841-1906), American geologist; student of L. Agassiz;
D.Sc. Lawrence Scientific School, Cambridge 1865; instructor in zoology and geology
ib. 1868-1872; professor of paleontology Harvard 1869-1888; professor of geology ib.
1888-1906; director of the second Kentucky Geological Survey 1873-1879; geologist U.S.
Geol. Survey 1886-1900. (<em>Shaler</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

Shannon, William Cummings (1851-1905), American physician and plant collector;
MD Bellevue Medical Coll. 1874; assistant surgeon U.S. army 1875-1895; maj. surgeon
1895-1898; in retirement from 1898. (<em>Shannon</em>).

Shantz, Homer LeRoy (1876-1958), American botanist, agronomist and soil tech-
nologist; Dr. phil. Univ. Nebraska 1905; instructor in botany, Colorado Coll. 1901-1902;
id. School of Agric, Nebraska 1903-1904, Missouri State Univ. 1905-1906, Louisiana
State Univ. 1907; with the Bureau of Plant Industry, USDA 1908-1926; head of the
department of botany Univ. Illinois, Urbana 1926-1928; president of the University of
Arizona 1928-1936; travelled in Africa 1919-1920 (Smithsonian African Exp.), 1924 and
1958. (<em>Shantz</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: US. – Duplicates in FHO, G, K, LCU, NY, RM, TEX. Collec-
ted in Africa 1919, 1924, 1934. – <em>Letters</em> to W.G. Farlow at FH.

6): 364, (ed. 7): 342; Kelly p. 213; Langman p. 696; NW p. 57; PH 444; SIA 227;
Tucker 1: 646-647, 779, 3: 278.

Sharp, Aaron John ["Jack"] (1904-x), American botanist; MS Univ. Oklahoma 1929;
Dr. phil. Ohio State Univ. 1938; instructor in botany, University of Tennessee 1929-
1937; professor of botany ib. 1937-1965; alumni distinguished service professor 1965-x;
curator of the herbarium 1949-1967. (<em>Sharp</em>).

longer extant. – <em>Field notes</em> at TENN; <em>letters</em> at G.

Shaw, Henry (1800-1889), English-born merchant and benefactor; emigrated to the
United States in 1819; engaged in hardware business at St. Louis until 1840; in retire-
ment laying out a garden ("Shaw's garden"), which became the Missouri Botanical
Garden in 1858 and founding Shaw's School of Botany at George Washington Univers-
ity. (<em>H. Shaw</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Shaw is not known to have made a herbarium himself, but the
herbarium of the Missouri Botanical Garden has become one of the world's major her-
baria. – <em>Diaries and manuscripts</em>: MO. <em>Letters</em> at G, GH, GM, K. – Jackson (1901) lists 30
specimens of Agave as having come from Henry Shaw, St. Louis 1855.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 266 (b. 24 Jul 1800, d. 25 Aug 1889); BB p.
273; BM 8: 1184; Bossert p. 363; Desmond p. 552; ME 1: 229; SO 2798; Tucker 1: 647,
3: 278. 1933.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anderson, E. &amp; D. Brockhoff, Missouri Bot. Gard. Bull. 55(6): 1-16. 1967.
Anon., Amer. Orch. Soc. Bull. 1(3): 78-81. 1932 (biogr. not., portr.); Bull. Torrey bot.
	Club 12: 118. 1885 (inauguration Shaw School of botany); Missouri Bot. Gard. Bull.
	30: 100-112, portr. opp. p. 193. 1942, 49: 85. 1961 (portr.); Natl. cycl. Amer. biogr. 9:
	233. 1899; The merchant's exchange of Saint Louis to Henry Shaw. Testimonial of
	Respect and gratitude adopted Dec. 19, 1878. St. Louis 1879, 24 p.
Bailey, L.H., Stand. cycl. hort. 3: 1595-1596. 1915.
Bryan, J.A., Henry Shaw, botanist-benefactor and George Ingham Barnett, architect.
	St. Louis, Mo, 63 p.).

	(biogr., portr.).

Shaw, John (1837-1890), Scottish geologist and bryologist; educated at Free Church
Training College, Glasgow ca. 1857-1860; teacher at this college until 1867; headmaster
of the Colesberg Collegiate School, South Africa 1867-1874; headmaster of the South
African College School, Cape Town 1874-1876; professor of physical science at the
South African College 1876. (<em>J. Shaw</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Flowering plants (396) at K; musci in B (mainly destr.), BM, H,
MANCH and NMW, but herbarium lost. – <em>Letters</em> in Wilson corr. BM.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: BB p. 273; CSP 8: 944, 11: 405, 12: 677, 18: 721(?);
Desmond p. 553; Lenley p. 367; Morren ed. 2, p. 32, ed. 10, p. 114; SBC p. 132.

	not.).

	323).
Shaw, James, Letter to Miss M.D. Gunn 13 Nov 1979 (b. Isle of Arran, Scotland 1837;
	Dr. phil. h.c. from a German University, possibly Leipzig).

Shaw, Walter Robert (1871-?), American botanist and pharmacognosist; Dr. phil.
Stanford 1897; worked in Bonn (with E. Strasburger) 1897-1898; professor of botany
and entomology, Oklahoma Agricultural Experiment Station 1901-1905; professor of
botany, College of Liberal Arts, Univ. Philippines, Manila 1906-1922. (<em>W. Shaw</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: PNH; some further material at A. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

Shear, Cornelius Lott (1865-1956), American botanist (agrostologist and mycologist);
MA Univ. Nebraska 1901; Dr. phil. George Washington Univ. 1906; with the United
states Department of Agriculture 1898-1901 as agrostologist, from 1901-1935 as mycolo-
gist in the Bureau of Plant Industry; from 1935-1950 in retirement and still active at
USDA. (<em>Shear</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BPI. – Other material (often possibly exsicc.) at A, CUP,
DAOM, F, GH, H, MASS, MICH, MO, MSC, NY (grasses, fungi), PAD, RM (fl. pl.),
S, US (grasses, fl. pl., orig.), W.
<em>Exsiccatae</em>: <em>New York fungi</em> cent. 1-3, nos. 1-200 and 300-400 [sic], 1893-1896, see Stev-
enson 1971. Sets at B (mainly destr.), BPI, CUP, DAOM, F, FH, IA, ILL, KSC,
MASS, MICH, MSC, NEB, NY, NYS, OC, OS, RUTPP, SCHN, SOC, UC, UT,
WIS, WVA.
<em>Correspondence</em> with B.O. Dodge at NY; with W.G. Farlow at FH; other letters at G and
GH.

Sheldon, Edmund Perry, (1869-1913), American botanist; B.S. University of Min-
nesota 1894; instructor in botany ib. 1894-1896; botanical explorer and forester in Por-
tland from 1897; studied law later in life; admitted to the bar in California 1910, ad-
mitted as attorney in Oregon 1911. (<em>E. Sheld.</em>).

Sheldon, John Lewis (1865-1947), American botanist and phytopathologist; public-
school teacher in Connecticut 1885-1890; instructor at the Mt. Hermon School 1892-
1894; B.S. Ohio Northern University ca. 1894; again teaching in Connecticut public
schools 1895-1898; at a state normal school in Nebraska 1899-1900; instructor in botany
at the University of Nebraska 1900-1903; Dr. phil. Univ. Nebraska 1903; professor of
bacteriology West Virginia University 1903; professor of botany and bacteriology ib.
1907; from 1913-1917 professor of botany; collaborator USDA 1902-1904, 1905-1922.
(<em>J. Sheld.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: WVA. – Further material at BPI, CUP, GH, MICH, NEBC,
NY. – <em>Field notes</em>: WVA.

1204; Kelly p. 213-214; Lenley p. 367; LS 24817-24826, 39217-39223, 41728; Stevenson
p. 1258.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: John Shepherd's nephew, Henry Shepherd (c. 1783-1858) succeeded him as
curator of the Liverpool Botanic Garden (1836-1854). He was one of the first to grow
ferns from spores (Trans. Hort. Soc. London 3: 338-341. 1823). For further data see e.g.
Desmond p. 554. Henry Shepherd's herbarium is also at LIV.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Shepherdia</em> Nuttall (1818, <em>nom. cons.</em>).

HEADING: SHERARD

Shepherd, Thomas (1779-1835), Scottish nurseryman; emigrated to Sydney,
Australia, where he established Darling Nursery in 1827; lectured on horticulture and
landscape gardening. (<em>Th. Sheph.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 269 (d. 30 Aug 1835); Desmond p. 554; HR.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Ferguson, J.A., Bibl. Australia 7: 277. 1969.
Maiden, J.H., J. Proc. R. Soc. N.S.W. 42: 118. 1908.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Thomas William Shepherd (1824-1884), son of Thomas Shepherd, became pro-
prietor of the Darling Nursery at Sydney after his father's death. He collected in N.S.W.
and published popular botanical articles.

Sherard, William (1659-1728), British botanist; studied law at Oxford (St. John's
College, B.C.L. 1683), botany in Paris (under J.P. Tournefort, 1686-1688) and Leiden
(with P. Hermann 1688-1689); in Ireland 1690-1694; D. C.L. Oxford 1694; consul at
Smyrna 1702-1716; collecting in Greece and Asia minor; founded a chair of botany at
Oxford of which J.J. Dillenius was the first occupant. (<em>Sherard</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: OXF, with his library and manuscripts. – Other material in E,
P-JU and in the Sloane herbarium (BM, see Dandy 1958), L; a copy of J. Ray, Hist. <em>pl</em>.
vols. 1, 2, annotated by Sherard is also at BM. – <em>Letters</em> (5 vols.) at Royal Society,
London (catalogue A.H. Church, s.d., 4 p.); other letters at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Ainsworth p. 52, 54, 246; Backer p. 531; Barnhart 3: 269
(b. 30 Mar 1659, d. 12 Aug 1728); BB p. 274; BM 4: 1914 (18: 67-68); Bossert p. 364;
Clokie p. 17-30, 58-81, 243; DNB 52: 67-68; Dryander 3: 37, 548; DSB 12: 394 (18: 67);
Frank 3 (Anh.): 96; Hegi 6(1): 197; Henrey 2: 740 [index]; IH 1 (ed. 6): 364, (ed. 7):
342; Jackson p. 421; Lasègue p. 21, 324, 424, 430, 503; ME 3: 339; Moebius p. 405; NI
alph., 3: 62; PR (alph.) 9425, ed. 1: 4395; Rehder 3: 527; SK 4: lxx-viii, lxxx, lxxxi; TL-
1/296, 502, see index; TL-2/2685, see indexes; Tucker 1: 27, 647.

Sherbakoff, Constantine Demetry [Dmitriev] (1878-1965), Russian-born American
phytopathologist; at the college of forestry St. Petersburg 1901-1907; to U.S.A. 1907;
Dr. phil. Cornell 1915; plant phytopathologist at the Florida Experiment Station 1914-
1920; at the Plant Pathology Department and Tennessee Agricultural Experiment
Station, Univ. Tennessee 1920-1950. (<em>Sherb</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: CUP.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 269 (b. 24 Mai 1878); Bossert p. 364; Hirsch
p. 273; Lenley p. 367; Stevenson p. 1258.

Sherff, Earl Edward (1886-1966), American botanist; Dr. phil. Univ. Chicago 1916;
high school teacher at various colleges in Michigan 1907-1912; instructor of botany at
Chicago Teachers College 1923; head of the dept. of science ib. 1929-1951; longtime
honorary research associate in systematic botany at the Field Museum, Chicago, Ill.
(<em>Sherff</em>).

Shibata, Keita (1878-1949), Japanese botanist and biochemist; Dr. phil. Tokyo 1899;
Dr. Sci. 1904; professor of botany at Hokkaido University, Sapporo, 1908-1910; studied
with Pfeffer at Leipzig 1910-1911; lecturer in plant-biochemistry and physiology at
Tokyo University 1910, e.o. professor of botany ib. 1912; ord. professor 1918-1938;
director of the Iwata Institute for Plant biochemistry 1938-1949. (<em>Shib</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

279; Zander ed. 10, p. 716, ed. 11, p. 817.

Shinners, Lloyd [Herbert] (1918-1971), Canadian born American botanist from 1912
in the United States; Dr. phil. Univ. Wisconsin 1943; botanist with the Milwaukee
County Park Board 1944-1945; research assistant at Southern Methodist University;
director of the herbarium ib., full professor from 1960; specialist on N. American
Compositae. (<em>Shinners</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: SMU (over 25.000); library and manuscripts also at SMU. –
Other material at DAO, DPU, GB, GH, MIL (orig.), MO, NY, OKLA, RM, US, WIS
(orig.). <em>Manuscripts</em> and <em>field notes</em> at SMU.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 271; Bossert p. 365; IH 1 (ed. 1): 30, (ed. 2):
46, (ed. 3): 55, (ed. 4): 59, (ed. 5): 54, (ed. 6): 364, (ed. 7): 342; Langman p. 699;
Lenley p. 369; PH 209; Roon p. 103; SIA 227, 7273; Zander ed. 10, p. 716, ed. 11, p.
817.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Amer. men sci. ed. 9: 1027. 1955, ed. 10: 3709. 1961, ed. 11. 4884. 1967;
	Michigan Bot. 10: 95. 1971 (obit. not.); Taxon 20: 396. 1971 (d.).

studied at Christ's College, Cambridge, fellow 1887, master 1910-1927; demonstrator
comparative anatomy Univ. Cambridge 1886; lecturer 1894, reader in zoology 1908-
1920. (<em>Shipley</em>).

Shirley, John F. (1849-1922), British-born naturalist and educationist; B.Sc. Univ.
London; school teacher in Birmingham; to Queensland 1878; headmaster at Roma,
Qld. 1878; inspector of schools 1879, senior inspector 1909; principal of the Teacher's
Training College, Brisbane 1914-1919; Dr. Sci. Univ. Sydney 1912. (<em>Shirley</em>).

Short, Charles Wilkins (1794-1863), American botanist and physician; Dr. med.
Univ. Pennsylvania 1815; practiced at Lexington and Hopkinsville, Kentucky 1816-
1825; professor of materia medica and medical botany Transylvania University,
Lexington, Kentucky, 1825; dean of the medical dept. ib. 1828-1837; dean of the

PAGE: 569
HEADING: SHORT

Louisville Medical Institute, 1838-1849; in retirement at his estate "Hayfield" south of
Louisville. (<em>Short</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: PH (15.000; acq. 1864); further material at BM(406), CGE,
CINC, CM, DWC, E, F, GH, H, K, KNOX, KY, M, MANCH, MICH, MO, NY,
OXF, P, TCD (lich.), UC, US, W, WIS. – <em>Letters</em> at G and GH.

1863); BM 4: 1916; Bossert p. 365; DAB 17: 127-128; Herder p. 77; IH 1 (ed. 7): 342, 2:
(files); Jackson p. 6, 218, 363; Lasègue p. 349; Lenley p. 469 (corr. Torrey); ME 1: 229,
3: 654; PH 364, 567; PR 8654; Rehder 5: 797; SIA 221; Tucker 1: 145, 648-649, 3: 279.

Showalter, Amos Martin (1891-1968), American cytologist, geneticist and hepatico-
logist; Dr. phil. Univ. Wisconsin 1922; assistant for botany, Univ. Wisconsin 1919-1922;
exchange fellow Relief Belgium Educ. Found. 1922-1924; Natl. Res. Council Fellow
1924-1927; assistant professor of botany Washington University, St. Louis 1928-1930;
associate professor of biology, Bridgewater College, Va., 1931, regular professor 1932; at
Harrisburg State Teachers College (Madison College) 1934-1960. (<em>Showalter</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Some material at NY.

HEADING: SHREVE

	from Cellule 38: 295-348, <em>pl. 1-5.</em> 1928.

Shreve, Forrest (1878-1950), American botanist and ecologist; AB Johns Hopkins
Univ. 1901; Dr. phil. ib. 1905; instructor bot. Cold Spring Harbor 1904-1905; at the
Cinchona, Jamaica Botanical station 1905-1906; associate professor of botany at
Goucher College, Maryland, 1906-1908; with the Tucson, Arizona Desert Laboratory of
the Carnegie Institution of Washington 1909-1947; in charge of the desert investigations
of the Carnegie Institution 1928-1932; from 1932 head of the Tucson laboratory and
working especially on the floristics of the Sonoran desert. (<em>Shreve</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: ARIZ (ca. 30.000); other material in AMES, ASUF, CM, DS, F,
GH, MICH, MIN, MO, NY, PH, RSA, UC, US, WELC. – <em>Note books</em> Jamaica 1905-
1906 in NY; other field notes at ARIZ; <em>letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 273 (b. 8 Jul 1878, d. 19 Jul 1950); BJI 2:
164; BL 1: 186, 318; BM 8: 1188; Bossert p. 365; Hortus 3: 1204; IH 1(ed. 6): 364, (ed.
7): 342; 2: (files); Langman p. 700; Lenley p. 368; NW p. 57; PH 209, 450, 939; SIA
221, 225, 7277, (HI 107); Tucker 1: 649, 3: 280.

Shull, Charles Albert (1879-1962), American botanist (plant physiologist); Dr. phil.
Chicago 1915 (B.S. 1905); assistant professor of botany at Transylvania University,
Kentucky 1906-1908; professor of biology and geology ib. 1908-1912; assistant professor
of botany Kansas Univ. 1912-1915; assoc. prof. ib. 1915-1918; professor of plant physi-
ology and head of the botany department University of Kentucky 1918-1921; associate
professor of plant physiology Univ. Chicago 1921-1925; professor of plant physiology ib.
1925-1944. (<em>C. Shull</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Some material at NY.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: (b. 19 Jan 1879, d. 22 Sep 1962); Hortus 3:
1204.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., New York Herald Tribune 24 Sep 1962, p. 24 (cutting at NY); New
	York Times 24 Sep 1962; Who's who Amer. 10-32, 1918-1963; Who was who Amer.
	6: 375. 1977.
Browne, E.T., Trans. Kentucky Acad. Sci. 25: 78. 1965 (Shull at Transylvania Coll.,
	Kentucky).
Bullock, A.A., Bibl. S. Afr. bot. 106. 1978.
Cattell, J.M. et al., Amer. Sci. ed. 3: 625. 1921, ed. 4: 893. 1927, ed. 5: 1017. 1933, ed. 6:
	1294. 1938, ed. 7: 1623. 1944, ed. 8: 2271. 1949, ed. 9(2): 1030. 1955.
Loomis, W.E. &amp; C.E. Hartt, Plant Physiol. 39(2): 137-138. 1964 (obit., portr.).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Founder and editor-in-chief Plant Physiology 1-19, 1926-1944.

<sm>FESTSCHRIFT</sm>: Vol. 20, 1945, of Plant Physiology is dedicated to C.A. Shull.

Shull, George Harrison (1874-1954), American botanist and geneticist; Dr. phil.
Chicago 1904; assistant Bureau Forestry USDA 1901; id. U.S. Natl. Mus. 1902; bot.
expert USDA 1902-1904; assistant plant physiology Univ. Chicago 1903-1904; botanical
investigator Carnegie Institution, Station for Experimental Evolution, Cold Spring
Harbor, Long Island 1904-1915 (discovered and analysed the phenomenon of hybrid
vigor in maize breeding); professor of botany and genetics, Princeton Univ. 1915-1942.
(<em>Shall</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: US; further material at MO and NY. – <em>Field notes</em> at US, <em>letters</em> to
W.G. Farlow at FH; other letters at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 274 (b. 15 Apr 1874, d. 29 Sep 1954); Biol.-
Dokum. 16: 8653; BJI 2: 164; BM 4: 1919, 8: 1198; Bossert p. 365; Hirsch p. 274; IH 2:
(files); Lenley p. 368; PH 59, 309, 450, 939; SIA 221, 225; TL-2/5163, 5164; Tucker 1:
649.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bot. Centralbl. 95: 448. 1904 (to Cold Spring Harbor 1 Mai 1904);
	Hedwigia 41: (143). 1902 (app. ass. U.S. natl. Herb.); Natl. Cycl. Amer. Biogr. A:

	Sep 1954; Österr. bot. Z. 65: 359. 1915 (to Princeton); Time 64: 113. 1954 (obit.

Shultz [Schultz], Benjamin (1772-1814), American physician; Dr. med. Univ.
Pennsylvania 1795; engaged in medicinal experimentation on a balsam farm, in
Hereford Twp., Berks Co. (Northampton Co.), Pa. until ca. 1806; subsequently at or
near Middelberg, Snyder Co., Pa. (<em>Shultz</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

HEADING: SHUTTLEWORTH

Shuttleworth, Robert James (1810-1874), British botanist and conchologist; studied
medicine in Genève and Edinburgh, 1830-1832; lived in Bern, Switzerland 1833-1866
and Hyères, France 1866-1874, building up an important herbarium. (<em>Shuttleworth</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BM (170.000 incl. herb. J.J. Roemer); other material attributed
to Shuttleworth mostly came from his herbarium duplicates; Shuttleworth himself col-
lected relatively few plants (e.g. in Ireland 1831, Switzerland and S. France). Material
(in part ex herb.) in: AK, BERN, CGE, DBN, DPU, E, EBH, FI, FRS, G, K, KIEL, L,
MANCH, NEU, NMW, OXF, PH, U, W. <em>Letters</em> at G, K and U.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 1: 272; Barnhart 3: 274 (b. Feb 1810, d. 19 Apr
1874); BB p. 275; Biol.-Dokum. 16: 8653; BM 4: 1919; Bossert p. 366; Clokie p. 243;
Desmond p. 557; De Toni 1: cxv; DNB 18: 176-177; Hortus 3: 1204; Jackson p. 158;
Lasègue p. 347; ME 2: 268; Nordstedt p. 29; PFC 1: liii; PH 73, 98; PR 8385, J.K.
Schmidt; Rehder 1: 434; Saccardo 1: 153-154, 2: 101; TL-1/see index; TL-3125, see
H.K. Beyrich, J.J. Roemer, F. Rugel; Tucker 1: 649.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Anon., Flora 18(2): 573-574. 1895 (S. acquires herbaria
	Scheuchzer/J.J. Roemer, brief sketch of his own herb.), 27(1): 175. 1844 (S. rd Rugel
	plants from Florida); J. Bot. 13: 254. 1875 (on a mss. Flora of the Rivièra), 15: 128.
	1877 (herb. S. acquired by BM); Trans. bot. soc. Edinburgh 12: 203-204. 1874 (obit.
	not.).

	Blodgett's plants).

Sibree, James (1836-1929), British missionary and naturalist; educated at Hull
Collegiate College; surveyor Board of Health 1859-1863; architect of memorial churches
in Madagascar 1863-1867; trained for congregational ministry, Birmingham 1868-1870;
missionary in Madagascar with the London Missionary Society until 1915. (<em>Sibree</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 271; BM 4: 1920, 8: 1190; Desmond p. 558

	172: 279-281. 1948; Who's who London 1903-1929; Who was who, London 3: 1234.
	1929-1940.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Antananarivo annual and Madagascar Magazine, edited by J. Sibree
... nos. 1-23, 1875-1899.

11.932. <em>The great African Island</em> Chapters on Madagascar. A popular account of recent
researches in the physical geography, geology, and exploration of the country; and its
natural history and botany; and in the origin and divisions, customs and language and
practices of the different tribes. Together with illustrations of scripture and early church
history from native statistics and missionary experience ... London (Trübner &amp; Co., ...)

Sibthorp, Humphrey Waldo (1713-1797), British botanist; MA Oxford 1737, MD
1745; professor of botany Oxford 1747-1783; father of John Sibthorp; correspondent of
Linnaeus. (<em>H. Sibth.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: OXF; Some further material in LINN; manuscripts at OXF. –
<em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 275; BB p. 275; Bossert p. 366; Clokie p. 36-
37, 243 (few specimens); Dawson p. 752; Desmond p. 558 (d. 12 Aug 1797); DNB 52:
189; Henrey 2: 72, 158, 256, 271, 637-638.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Allen, D.E., The naturalist in Britain 16, 17. 1976.
Berkeley, E. and D.S., Dr. John Mitchell 133. 1974.
Bridson, G.D.R. et al., Nat. hist. mss. res. Brit. isl. 436 [index]. 1980.

Druce, G.C., Fl. Oxfordshire xc. 1927.

Rix, M., The art of the botanist 89, 92. 1981.
Smith, E., Life Joseph Banks 7, 8. 1911.
Smith, J.E., <em>in</em> Rees Cycl. 32: Sibthorpia 1819 ("he is said to have delivered but a single
	lecture in all that time [40 yrs], which was not a successful one, nor do we know of
having enriched the science with any publication ... However, imperfect his claims to
botanical celebrity, his son has conferred more honour on the above name than either
of them could derive from it ...").

<sm>HANDWRITING</sm>: Candollea 33: 389-390. 1978.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Sibthorpia</em> Linnaeus (1753).

Sibthorp, John (1758-1796), British botanist; MA Oxford 1780, MD 1784; studied
with A.L. de Jussieu at Paris 1781-1782 and with A. Broussonet at Montpellier 1782-
1783; professor of botany and director of the Botanical Garden Oxford 1784-1796 as
successor to his father H.W. Sibthorp; in Götingen 1784-1785, worked with N.J. von
Jacquin 1785; travelled in Greece with Ferdinand Bauer 1786-1787; with Francis
Borone in Turkey and the Peloponnese 1794-1795. (<em>Sibth</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: OXF (herb., mss.); duplicates in BM, UPS (herb. Thunberg).
<em>Letters</em> in BM (Bloomsbury and NH), HU, LINN; letters to John Hawkins in West
Sussex Record Office, Chichester; other manuscripts at Lincolnshire Record Office,
London. – John Sibthorp collected plants on two trips to the Mediterranean. On his first
trip (1786-1787), Sibthorp was accompanied by Ferdinand Bauer, whom he had en-
gaged in Vienna. The second trip was made 1794-1795. Sibthorp started work on a
<em>Flora graeca</em>, but died soon after his return from Greece. He left a will providing funds
for the publication of an illustrated <em>Flora graeca</em> in 10 folio volumes (with 100 plates
each) and an unillustrated <em>Prodromus</em> to be compiled with the help of his manuscripts,
drawings and specimens by a "competent botanist". Sir Joseph Banks arranged for
James Edward Smith to be appointed to this position. Smith carried out the work and
published the <em>Flora graeca</em> as well as the <em>Prodromus</em>. The original material (manuscripts,
specimens, but not the drawings) is at OXF.

PAGE: 578
HEADING: SIBTHORP, J.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 2(1): 22, 5(2): 93, 702, 6(2): 938, 12(3): 57;
Barnhart 3: 275 (b. 28 Oct 1758, d. 8 Feb 1796); BB p. 275; Blunt p. 116, 191, 195-197,
264; BM 4: 1920; Bossert p. 366; Clokie p. 38-42, 244; Dawson p. 752-754; DNB 18: 189-
190; Dryander 3: 137; DU 282; Frank 3 (Anh.): 96-97; GF p. 76; GR p. 380, cat. p. 71;
Hegi 5(2): 1130; Henrey 3: 113-114 (nos. 1318-1320), and see indexes; Herder p. 205,
206, 412; Hortus 3: 1204; IH 1 (ed 2): 92, (ed. 3): 117, (ed. 6): 364, (ed. 7): 342; Jackson
p. 258, 312; Kelly p. 214; Lasègue p. 276, 324, 331, 353, 406, 502, 530, 531; LS 24868;

<em>Note</em>: For further information see Greene (1887), Lady Smith (1832), Stearn
	(1967/1976) and Henrey (2: 113-114). – Only 25-30 copies were issued of the original
	issue (see Henrey); however, further copies (ca. 40?) with the original text and a large
	number of the plates reprinted on paper water-marked 1845, were issued by Henry
	G. Bohn. For notes on this reprint see Flora 28: 576. 1845 and Henrey. – The en-
	graved title pages have the title <em>Flora graeca sibthorpiana</em>. – G.A. Pritzel reviewed the
	book in Gersdorff, Leipziger Repert. 33: 258-261. 1847 and in Bot. Zeit. 5: 794-796.
	1847.
<em>Facsimile ed</em>.: announced, but not published, by Acad. Verl.-Ges. Graz.
<em>Proposals for publishing the Flora Graeciae</em> of the late John Sibthorp, ... compiled from the
	mss. notes of the author, by James Edward Smith, ... London s.d., p. [1-2]. <em>Copy</em>:
	DBN.

Sickenberger, Ernst (1831-1895), German (Baden) botanist and pharmacist; studied
at Heidelberg University 1852-1853; pharm. exam. Stuttgart 1854; practicing pharma-
cist in Kirchgarten 1858-1865; in Freiburg i. Br. 1865-1872, as owner of a liquor store
and (1872) in charge of the botanical garden; owner of a pharmacy in Lörrach 1873-
1876; from 1876-1895 in Cairo in charge of the German pharmacy; exploring Egypt
1881-1885, professor of pharmacology (later chemistry) from 1889, member of the
Egyptian Institute from 1890. (<em>Sickenb</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Z; some lichens at M; further material at B (mainly destr.),
CAIH, CAIM, DS, E, L, WAG. – Sickenberger's German herbarium was offered for
sale in 1876 (Gebhard 1876). – <em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 275 (d. 8 Dec 1895); BM 4: 1921; CSP 18:
738; IH (ed. 7): 342; Rehder 1: 489; Tucker 1: 649, 3: 280; Urban-Berl. p. 324.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Allg. bot. Z. 2(2): 32. 1896 (d.); Bot. Centralbl. 65: 288. 19 Feb 1896
	(d.); Bot. Monatschr. 15: 209-210. 1897 (sale of herb. Dr. Schill. Freiburg containing
	the Sickenberg herb.); Nat. Nov. 18: 70. 1896 (d.).
Ascherson, P., Fl. Provinz Brandenburg 1:14. 1864; Österr. bot. Z. 46: 80. 1896 (obit.
	not.).

	from the "Revue d'Egypte". (<em>Copy</em> DS, from Engler collection).

Hein, W.H. &amp; H.D. Schwarz, Deut. Apoth. Biogr.2: 627-628. 1978 (biogr. details).

Sickmann, Johann Rudolph (1779-1849), German (Osnabrück)/Hannover) botanist;
ultimately assistant at the Botanical Garden, Hamburg. (<em>Sickmann</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: HBG, KIEL.

11.939. <em>Enumeratio stirpium phanerogamicarum circa Hamburgum</em> sponte crescentium auctore
J.R. Sickmann. Hamburgi (Typis Joannis Augusti Meissneri) 1836. Oct. (<em>Enum. stirp.

<em>Publ</em>.: 1836 (Flora rd before 6 Mar 1837 (20(1): 369), p. iv: 9 Mai 1836), p. [i-iv], [1]-
	80. <em>Copies</em>: B-S, G, HH, MO, NY. – A slip in the copy at G states "Ausgegeben im
	Monat März 1839. Diese Schrift ist früher nicht im Buchhandel gekommen". Even
	though the book may not have been for sale through the book-trade, copies were
	evidently distributed by the author in 1836/7 judging by e.g. the Notice in Flora
	1837. Hinrichs lists it as received 28 Apr-4 Mai 1839.
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., Flora 20 (Lit.) 6: 92-93. 28 Jul 1837 (rev.), Linnaea 11 (Lit.): 147-148.
	1836-1838 (rev.), 13 (Lit.): 165. 1839-1840 (note on availability in book trade).

Sidebotham, Joseph (1822-1884), British botanist, entomologist, astronomer and
calico printer; co-founder of the Manchester Field Naturalist's Society; partner of the
firm of the Strines Printing Company, Manchester, 1849-1876. (<em>Sideboth</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: MANCH; further material at CGE and OXF.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 275 (d. 30 Mai 1884); BB p. 275; BM 4:
1921; Clokie p. 244; CSP 5: 683, 8: 948, 11: 409, 18: 738; Dawson p. 559; De Toni 2:
cvii; Lenley p. 369; TL-2/939.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Entom. mon. Mag. 22: 46. 1886 (obit. not.); Mon. Not. R. astron. Soc.
	46: 194-196. 1886 (obit., gives more detail than other notices); Proc. Linn. Soc.,
	London 1883-1886: 107. 1886 (obit. not.); Proc. Manchester Lit. philos. Soc. 25: 244-
	247. 1886 (obit.); Trans. entom. Soc. London 1885: xlii (obit. not.).
G.D., Psyche, Cambridge 5: 36. 1808 (d.).
Dallmann, A.A. &amp; M.H. Wood, Trans. Liverpool bot. Soc. 1: 90. 1909 (bibl.).
Freeman, R.B., Brit. nat. hist. books 315. 1980.
J.C.M., J. Bot. 23: 319-320. 1885 (obit.).
Kent, D.H., Brit. herb. 78. 1957.

HEADING: SIDEBOTHAM

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Contributed <em>Algae filiformes</em> – <em>Algae silicatae</em> (with W.C.
Wiliamson), to R. Buxton, <em>Bot. Guide fl. pl.</em> 1849. TL-2/939.

Sieber, Franz Wilhelm (1789-1844), Bohemian botanist, traveller and plant collector;
travelled in Austria and Italy 1811-1812; studied medicine in Praha 1814-1816; travel-
led to Crete, Egypt and Palestine 1817-1818; travelled around the world 1822-1825,
collecting especially in S. Africa, Mauritius and Australia 1822-1824; from 1830-1844 in
a psychiatric asylum in Praha. (<em>Sieber</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: AWH (personal herbarium; acquired by C.L. von Reichenbach;
acquired with the latter's herbarium by H. Van Heurck in 1867; important other parts
of the Sieber collection were dispersed by sale; in addition many sets were sold by Sieber
during his active life time under various titles. The collections are in many herbaria with
important sets e.g. in H, M, PR and W; and further material in A, B (in part extant),
BERN, BHU, BM, BP, BR, C, CAL, CGE, CN, DBN, DS, E, FH, FI, G, G-DC, GE,
GH, GJO, GOET, H, HAL, HBG, JE, K, KIEL, L, LE, LV, LY, LZ (destr.), M,
MEL, MO, MPU, MW, NCY, NY, O, OXF, P, PH, PR, PRC, REG, ROST, S, U, W,
WAG, WRSL (incl. lich.).
<em>Exsiccatae</em>: F.C. Dietrich (1881), in addition to a detailed and sympathetic biographical
sketch, gives a list of 23 series of exsiccatae, q.v. The details of these exsiccatae are still
not yet known in detail; Dietrich was able to give a full list of the 645 plants contained
in the <em>Herbarium florae Novae Hollandiae</em>. Sieber's exsiccatae contained also material collec-
ted by others, who sent him their collections (or were sent out by him). Those were e.g.
Wenzel Bojer, Theodor Hilsenberg, Franz Kahaut, Joseph Schmidt, Franz Wrba, Carl
Zeyer, Andreas Zölliger. H.F. Van Heurck also distributed plants from Sieber collect-
ions after he had acquired his herbarium. – <em>Letters</em> at HAL (to D.F.L. von Schlech-
tendal), G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 2(1): 37, 5(2): 213, 281, 7: 178, 12(3): 275, 411;
Backer p. 532; Barnhart 3: 275 (b. 30 Mai 1789, d. 17 Dec 1844); Biol.-Dokum. 16:
8659; BM 4: 1922; Clokie p. 244; CSP 5: 684; Dawson p. 754; DTS 1: 282, 6(4): 198;
Frank 3 (Anh.): 97; Futak-Domin p. 537; Hegi 1: 350, 6(1): 380, 6(2): 1331; Herder p.
60; Hortus 3: 1204; HR; IH 1 (ed. 2): 17, (ed. 3): 18, (ed. 6): 364, (ed. 7): 342, 2: (files);
Jackson p. 313, 350; Klásterský p. 170; Lasègue p. 94-95, 583 (index); Maiwald p. 111-
114, 283 [index]; PFC 1: lvi; PR 8664-8667, ed. 1: 1376, 9615, 9625-9629, Rehder 5:
798; RS p. 142; Saccardo 1: 154, 2: 101; SBC p. 132; TL-2/835, see J.P.B. Delessert,
C.L. v. Reichenbach; Tucker 1: 649; WU 33: 227-237 (detailed biogr.); Urban-Berl. p.
269, 291, 314, 323, 377, 397-398, 415; Zander ed. 10, p. 717, ed. 11, p. 818.

<sm>NAME</sm>: Sometimes erroneously as "Franz Xaver Sieber". Franz Wilhelm Sieber should
not be confused with Friedrich Wilhelm Sieber who collected for J. v. Hoffmannsegg in
Brazil (Para) between 1801-1807, see e.g. I. Urban, Fl. bras. 1(1): 111-112. 1906, col-
lections e.g. in B-Willd., BR and HAL.

Siebert, August (1854-1923), German (Pommeranian) botanist and gardener; with
commercial garden firms at Erfurt and Wandsbeck-Hamburg; Obergärtner, subseq-
uently director of the "Palmengarten" in Frankfurt a. Main 1886-1923. (<em>Siebert</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

HEADING: SIEBOLD, C. T. E.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) <em>Vilmorin</em>"'<em>s Blumengärtnerei</em> Beschreibung, Kultur und

Siebold, Carl Theodor Ernst von (1804-1885), German (Würzburg) physiologist and
zoologist; studied in Göttingen and Berlin; regional physician at Heilsberg, Prussia 1831-
1835; director of the obstetric clinic in Danzig 1835-1840; professor of physiology and
comparative anatomy in Erlangen 1840-1845, idem in Freiburg i.Br. 1845-1850, id. in
Breslau 1850-1853; from 1853 in the same function in München, later also as professor of
zoology and director of the physiological institute; brother of P.F. v. Siebold. (<em>C.
Siebold</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 34: 186-188. 1892; Barnhart 3: 275 (b. 16 Feb
1804, d. 7 Apr 1885); Biol.-Dokum. 16: 8663; BM 4: 1922; CSP 5: 684-688, 8: 949-950,
11: 410-411, 12: 681, 18: 741; De Toni 1: cxv, 2: cvii; DSB 12: 420-422 (A. Geus);
Herder p. 122; Moebius p., 77, 82, 349; Nordstedt p. 29; PR 8668, ed. 1: 9630; Rehder
4: 487; TL-2/6535; Zander ed. 11, p. 817-818.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Ber. Senckenb. naturf. Ges. 1885: 7. (obit. not.); Bonplandia 6: 52-53.
