Rodgers, A.D., Liberty Hyde Bailey 249, 261-267, 272, 443. 1949.
Spillman, R., J. Heredity 39: 253-254. 1948 (further evidence of importance of pre-

Spix, Johann Baptist von (1781-1826), German (Bavarian) traveller and zoologist;
from 1811 curator of the zoological collections of the Bayerische Akademie der Wissens-
chaften; from 1817-1820 with C.F.P. von Martius in Brazil. (<em>Spix</em>).

Sporleder, Friedrich Wilhelm (1787-1875), German (Prussian-Saxony) botanist;
studied law and botany at Göttingen; government administrator at Wernigerode from
1815. (<em>Sporleder</em>).

Sprague, Mary Letitia ["Manna"], née Green (1886-1978), British botanist, nom-
enclaturist and botanical bibliographer; with the Royal Botanical Gardens, Kew, 1912-
1945, from 1912-1925 as temporary technical assistant for Index kewensis and Index
londinensis, from 1925 permanent assistant responsible for the Index kewensis supplem-
ents; married Thomas Archibald Sprague 1938. (<em>M.L. Sprague</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: K; further material at NMW. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

Green.

Morris, F.W.A., Proc. Cotteswold Natural. Field Club 37(4): 18. 1978.

Sprague, Thomas Archibald (1877-1958), British botanist; B.Sc. Edinburgh 1898, D.
Sc. ib. 1927; at the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew 1900-1945, deputy keeper of the
herbarium 1930-1945; travelled and collected with H.W. Dowding in Venezuela and
Columbia 1898-1899, in the Canary Islands 1913; rapporteur-général for botanical
nomenclature 1935-1947. (<em>Sprague</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: K. – Further material at GH, MANCH, MEDEL, NMW, OXF,
US. – <em>Manuscripts</em> at K (incl. reminiscenses of his early times at K). <em>Letters</em> at G, GH.

12.651. International Botanical Congress Cambridge (England), 1930 <em>Nomenclature pro-
posals by British botanists</em>. London (printed under the authority of his Majesty's Stationary
Office ...) 1929. Oct. (<em>Nom. Prop. Brit. Bot.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Aug 1929 (printer's mark on p. 3: Aug 1929; listed by J. Briquet, Rec. syn. ii. 1930
	as having been received by 1 Sep 1929), p. [1]-203. <em>Copies</em>: FAS, U.
<em>Editors</em> (sub-committe on nomenclature, appointed by the Imperial botanical
	Conference, London 1924): J. Ramsbottom, A.J. Willmott, E.M. Wakefield and T.A.
	Sprague (convener). This sub-committee published an explanatory note in J.Bot. 67:
	338-339. Dec 1929 outlining the standing of the proposals. This note was separately
	distributed as a one-page pamphlet, Dec 1929.
<em>Standard species of Linnean</em> [sic] <em>genera of Phanerogamae</em> (1753-54). By A.S. Hitchcock and
	M.L. Green, on p. 111-195. This list constitutes a choice of lectotypes of Linnaean
	generic names which was in accordance with the Linnaean protologues as closely as
	possible. In cases of conflict with the earlier choice of such types by Britten and Brown
	(1913, see TL-2/778) the choices by Hitchcock or Green may have to be accepted.
	See our note in TL-2/1: 334; the Britton and Brown choices may sometimes have to
	be rejected (on the basis of automatic selection), but not always. In other cases they
	may be perfectly in accordance with the ICBN.
<em>Note</em>: For Sprague's own idea on nomenclature in 1929, aiming at a reconciliation of the
	"International Rules" and the "American Code", see e.g. his presentation at the
	Ithaca Botanical Congress (17 Aug 1926) in Proc. [Ithaca] Intern. Congr. Pl. Sci. 2:
	1422-1426. 1929. He summed up the results reached at Cambridge (1930) in Rep.
	Bot. Exch. Cl. Brit. Isl. 1932: 300-313.

12.652. <em>Principles and problems of plant nomenclature</em> ... Reprinted from Proceedings of the
International Congress of Plant Sciences ... 1929. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 1929, p. [1422]-1426. <em>Copy</em>: FAS. – Reprinted from Proc. Int. Congr. Pl. Sci. 2:
	[1422]-1426. 1929.

PAGE: 801
HEADING: SPRAGUE, T. A.

12.659. <em>Subsection for Nomenclature</em> reprint from: Proceedings Sixth International Botan-
ical Congress Amsterdam, 2-7 September, 1935 vol. I. p. 333-383. Leiden (E.J. Brill)
1936. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 1936, cover-t.p., p. [333]-383. <em>Copies</em>: FAS, U. – Reprinted and to be cited from
	<em>Proceedings</em> as noted on cover.
<em>Note</em>: The turbulent years after 1935 prevented Sprague and the Editorial Committee
	appointed at Amsterdam (H. Harms, B.P.G. Hochreutiner, T.A. Sprague) to publish
	the "Rules" as modified by the Amsterdam Congress. Sprague published a
	mimeographed "<em>International rules of botanical nomenclature supplement</em>, embodying the
	alterations made at Amsterdam in 1935" 27 unnumbered pages, p. [2] signed Chel-
	tenham, April 1948, for the Utrecht Conference on Botanical Nomenclature, 14-19
	Jun 1948. <em>Copies</em>: FAS, U. – See also ICBN 1972 (Regnum vegetabile 82) p. 395-396
	under no. 6, for a republication of this document in Chron. bot. 12(1/2): 65-88. 1950.
	In the meantime W.H. Camp, H.W. Rickett and C.A. Weatherby had published an
	unofficial version of the "Rules", also embodying the Amsterdam changes, in Brit-
	tonia 6(1): 1-120. 1947 (reprinted by Chronica Botanica Co. 1948).

Geneeskunde ... 1938. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 1 Oct 1938, cover-t.p., p. [3]-4. <em>Copy</em>: FAS. – Reprinted and to be cited from Ned.
	Tijdschr. Geneesk. 82(40): [3]-4. 1938.

Sprengel, Anton (1803-1851), German (Prussian-Saxony) botanist; Dr. phil. Halle
1825; habil. ib. 1828; lecturer at the University of Halle from 1829; ultimately volunteer
in the Schleswig-Holstein war of 1851; son of K.P.J. Sprengel. (<em>A. Spreng.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: See K.J.P. Sprengel. – Some material from Halle sent by him to
BR, K and LG. – A handwritten catalogue of the University Herbarium ca. 1828, by A.
Sprengel, is at HAL. – <em>Letters</em> to D.F.L. von Schlechtendal and others at HAL.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Andrews p. 334; Barnhart 3: 312 (b. 13 Sep 1803, d. 26
Jan 1851); BM 5: 1994; Herder p. 353; Hortus 3: 1204; Jackson p. 494; KR p. 663;
Moebius p. 380; PH 364; PR 5430, 8854-8855, ed. 1: 6009, 9829; Quenstedt p. 408;
Rehder 1: 267, 382; SO 617; TL-1/1255, 1266; Tucker 1: 664.

Sprengel, Christian Konrad (1750-1816), German (Brandenburg/Prussian) botanist
and high school teacher; uncle of Kurt Sprengel; studied theology and philosophy at
Halle; teacher "at the Friedrichs-Hospital School, Berlin 1774, from 1780 rector of the

PAGE: 805
HEADING: SPRENGEL, C. K.

Great Lutheran City School at Spandau, teaching natural sciences and languages;
pioneer flower biologist. (<em>CK. Spreng.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Some material still extant in B-Willd. (D.E. Meyer 1954).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 53: 293-296; AG 2(1): 429; Barnhart 3: 312 (b. 21
Sep 1750, d. 7 Apr 1816); BL 2: 169; BM 5: 1994; Bossert p. 379; Dryander 3: 395; DSB
12: 587-591 (many secondary refs.); Frank 3 (Anh.): 99; Herder p. 123; Jackson p. 98;
Moebius p. 344, 456 [index]; MW suppl. p. 331; NI 1883; PR 8856-8857, ed. 1: 9830;
Rehder 1: 236; TL-1/1256, 1400; TL-2/see J.W. von Goethe.

HEADING: SPRENGEL, C. K.

Sprengel, Kurt [Polycarp Joachim] (1766-1833), German (Prussian) botanist and
physician; studied medicine at Halle 1785-1787; Dr. med. ib. 1787; lecturer in forensic
medicine and history of medicine at Halle, also practicing medicine 1787; extraordinary
professor of medicine 1787-1795; ordinary professor id. 1795-17975 professor of botany
1797-1833. (<em>Spreng.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Kurt Sprengel's considerable and rich herbarium (21.806
species) came first to his son Anton. After the latter's death, in 1851, it was sold in parts.
"Sprengel's herbarium, valuable to some public collection on account of the number of
ill-described and wrongly-named specimens which the author of the 16th edition of the
"Systema vegetabilium" has made, has been entirely dismembered and sold in small
portions to different individuals and institutions." (Seemann). A certain number of
families and genera were sold to specialists, so e.g. the Compositae to Schultz-Bipontinus
(now through the herbier Cosson at P in the herbier général). The Umbelliferae and
Caryophyllaceae went to W, the Cyperaceae (through Boeckeler) to B, the Filices via
Kunze to LZ (now destroyed, the grasses to Karl Müller, the Labiatae and Verbenaceae
to J.A. Schmidt in Heidelberg, the Orobanchaceae to Fr. Schultz in Bitsch, the
Meliaceae, Anonaceae, Melastomataceae, Bombacaceae, Ternstroemiaceae to Sonder
(now MEL), the Amaryllidaceae to Schnizlein), the Lichenes to Meisner (BAS or NY).
Even after this rigorous impoverishment a considerable portion remained and was ac-
quired in 1853 by Karl Müller in Halle. The Müller-Sprengel herbarium (12.000
species) was bought by Berlin (B) in 1890, and is now no longer extant. A certain
number of specimens, however, (240) is in the Willdenow herbarium and the Pter-
idophytes have also been preserved. Further material is at BP, FI, G, GOET (some
lich.), H-Ach (lich.), L (some musci and algae), LD (200, herb. Retzius), LE, PH, PR.
According to Urban (1891) the part of the Sprengel herbarium acquired by B in 1890
contained material from Balbis, Baumgarten, Bertero, Besser, Defile, Detharding,
Dewey, Forster, Gussone, Lamarck, Ledebour, Moris, Nuttall, Pollini, Rottler, Schiede
&amp; Deppe, Schott, Sellow, Sieber, Torrey, Weihe and Zèyher. – <em>Letters</em> e.g. at G, HAL.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 35: 296-299 (E. Wunschmann); AG 6(1): 531;
Backer p. 545; Barnhart 3: 312 (b. 3 Aug 1766, d. 15 Mar 1833); BM 5: 1994-1995, 8:
1233; Bret. p. 277; CSP 5: 783-784, 12: 6957; Dawson p. 779; De Toni 1: cxviii; DSB 12:
591-592 (mainly medical); DTS 1: 286, 6(4): 198-199; Frank 3 (Anh.): 99; GR p. 48, <em>pl</em>.
[<em>17</em>], cat. 72; Hawksworth p. 186; Hegi 4(2): 788, 5(2): 1087; Herder p. 479 (index);
Hortus 3: 1204; IF p. 732; IH 1 (ed. 6): 364, (ed. 7): 343, 2: (files); Jackson p. 2, 37, 114,
148; KR p. 663; Krempelh. 2: 4, 138-145; Langman p. 715; Lasègue p. 48, 526; Lenley
p. 469 (Torrey corr.); LS 25614-25622; Maiwald p. 27, 96, 147, 196; MD p. 225-227;
Moebius p. 164, 456; MW p. 465; Nordstedt p. 29; PR 8860-8880 and see indexes, ed. 1:
9832-9856 (id.); Rehder 5: 817-818; RS p. 143; Saccardo 1: 157, 2: 203; SBC p. 132; SK
1: cxvii, 4: 45; SO 327, 451, 451a, 452, 616, 991a; Stevenson p. 1259; TL-1/1257-1267
and see indexes; TL-2/511, 992, 1462, 3454, 3914, 4693, 4760, and see indexes; Tucker
1: 664-665; Urban-Berl. p. 119, 314, 400, 415; Zander ed. 10, p. 720, ed. u, p. 821.

Reise</em> durch einen Theil von Toscana. Aus dem Italienischen übersetzt von Gerasimus
Constantini von Gregorini", Halle (bey Johann Jakob Gebauer) 1797. <em>Copy</em>: LZ (Univ.

Altona (bey Johann Friedrich Hammerich) 1822, 2 parts, 1: [i-viii], [1]-358 and [i, iii],

1854 ("sehr flüchtig und sehr frei", quality dubious).

1830).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Curtia</em> Chamisso et D.F.L. von Schlechtendal (1826); <em>Sprengelia</em> J.A. Schuhes
(1809).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: (1) Kurt Sprengel was the son of the Berlin teacher, theologian and natural
scientist Joachim Friedrich Sprengel whose half-brother was Christian Konrad Sprengel
(1750-1816). They were sons of Ernst Victor Sprengel (1686-1759) from different mar-
riages (15 children in all, C.K. Sprengel being the youngest). Anton Sprengel (1803-
1851) was a son of Kurt Sprengel; another son, Wilhelm Sprengel (1792-1828), de-
fended a botanical dissertation of which the text was provided by the promotor (his
father) and provided illustrations for various publications of K. Sprengel.
(2) Joachim Friedrich Sprengel, Kurt Sprengel's father, wrote a <em>Vorstellung der Kräuter-
kunde in Gedächtnisstafeln</em>, Greifswald 1754. Qu. (n.v.).
(3) Karl (Carl) Sprengel (1787 or 1787-1859), director of the agricultural college at
Regenswalde, Pommerania (d. late Apr 1859), wrote "<em>Meine Erfahrungen im Gebiete der
allgemeinen und speziellen Pflanzen-Cultur</em>, 2 vols., Leipzig (Baumgärtner) 1847-1850, 1:
1847, p. [i]-xii, [1]-345, [346], 2: 1850, p. [i]-xii, [1]-348. <em>Copy</em>: USDA.
(4) For a planned <em>Vollständige Geschichte der Farrenkräuter</em> see Sprengel in H.A. Schrader, J.
Bot. 1801(1): 425-431. This was to be a fully illustrated monograph of the Pteridophyta
from "Equisetum to Isoetes". The book was too expensive in war-time and was never
realized (G. Kraus 2: 48. 1894).

<sm>HANDWRITING</sm>: Webbia 32(1): 15. 1977 (no. 30).

12.678. Curtii Sprengel <em>Mantissa prima florae halensis</em>, addita novarum plantarum cen-
turia. Halae [Halle] (apud C. Kümmelium) 1807. Oct. (<em>Mant. prim. fl. hal</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 4 Jul 1807 (SY p. 31; TL-1), p. [i], [1]-58. <em>Copies</em>: BR, G, H, HH, M, MO, NY(2),
	UC, US(2), USDA; IDC 5749. The text of the <em>first</em> part, p. [1]-26 contains the
	<em>Observationes botanicae in floram Halensem</em>, Halle 11 Apr 1807, by C.L. Jungk, see TL-
	2/3454. This text was used by Jungk as thesis, but its contents must be ascribed to
	Sprengel. We saw no copy of the original dissertation. For a review see H. Schrader,
	Neu. J. Bot. 3: 194-198. 1809.
	The text of the <em>second</em> part, p. 27-58 contains the <em>Plantarum novarum ex herbario Spren-
	gelii centuriam</em> which was published earlier separately as a dissertation by J.F.T.
	Biehler, see TL-2/511, see e.g. M.L. Fernald, Rhodora 47: 197-198. 1945, under the
	half-title <em>Novarum plantarum ex herbario meo centuria</em>. We saw no copy of the original
	dissertation.

	<em>Copy</em>: B-S. – 2713 species mentioned.

12.681. Caroli Linnaei <em>Philosophia botanica</em>, in qua explicantur Fundamenta botanica
cum definitionibus partium, exemplis terminorum, observationibus rariorum, adjectis

12.684. Curtii Sprengel ... <em>Dissertatio de Germanis</em>, rei herbariae patribus. [Denkschr. k.

<em>Publ</em>.: 1812, in Denkschr. Akad. Wiss. München 1811-1812: 185-216. 1812 (sic: issue
	Denkschriften dated 1812). – Germany is stated to have been the birthplace of botany
	through the fathers of botany; lists "new plants" of the "fathers".

<em>Other Sprengel publications on Umbelliferae</em>:

	<em>1 pl</em>. 1813.

	1814.

	121-132, <em>pl</em>. 5. 1814. – 29 genera.
(4) <em>In Umbelliferas nonnullas animadversiones</em>, Mem. Soc. natural. Moscou 5: 3-13. 1817.
(5) <em>Species Umbelliferarum minus cognitae illustratae</em>, Halle 1818, see below.
(6) <em>Symbolae criticae ad synonymiam Umbellijerarum</em>, Denkschr. k. bayr. bot. Ges.
	Regensburg 1: 75-103. 1815, 2: 49-54. 1818.
(7) <em>Umbelliferae, in</em> Roemer et Schuhes, Syst. veg. 6: 315-628. Aug-Dec 1820. – Sprengel
	refers to this contribution in a letter to A.P. de Candolle of 15 Mai 1820 as his
	"Synopsis Umbelliferarum" which will be sent as soon as it is ready.

	de Candolle, <em>Théorie élém. bot.</em> 1813; see pur entry TL-2/992 for de Candolle's reaction
	to this publication: "... un livre vraiment absurde".
<em>English translation</em>: 1821, <em>Elements of the philosophy of plants</em>: containing the principles of
	scientific botany; nomenclature, theory of classification, phytography; anatomy,
	chemistry, physiology, geography, and diseases of plants: with a history of the science,
	and practical illustrations ..." Edinburgh (printed for William Blackwood and T.
	Cadell, Strand, London) 1821. Oct., p. [i]-xxxiii, [xxxiv, err.], [1]-486, <em>pl. 1-8</em> (uncol.
	W.H. Lizars). <em>Copies</em>: G, HH, MICH, NY, PH, U (Inst. Gesch. Natuurw.); see also
	sub TL-2/992.
<em>Facsimile ed. Engl. transl.</em>: 1978, New York (Arno Press), ISBN 0-405-10719-6.
<em>Note</em>: See G. Kraus (2: 45. 1894) for a note on A.P. de Candolle's reaction to this one-
	sided initiative by Sprengel. A review of the English translation will be found in
	Monthly Review ser. 2. 96(2): 180-195. Oct. 1821.

	mainly medical papers.

Spribille, Franz Joseph (1841-1921), German (Silesian) botanist; studied theology
and classical philology at Breslau 1861-1866; in various positions in the Silesian school
system from 1868; teacher at the gymnasia at Schrimm and Inowrazlaw until 1907;
professor's title 1897; in retirement in Breslau 1908-1921. (<em>Sprib</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Some material in B (mainly destr.) (e.g. <em>Rosa</em>), BR, and GOET.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 312 (b. 29 Jan 1841, d. 13 Jan 1921); BFM
186, 187; Futak-Domin p. 558; IH 2: (files); LS 25624; Rehder 5: 818; Tucker 1: 665;
Urban-Berl. p. 400.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Allg. bot. Z. 3: 56. 1897 (prof. title); Bot. Monatschr. 15: 60. 1897 (prof.
	title); Nat. Nov. 19: 156. 1897 (app. Inowrazlaw); Verh. bot. Ver. Brandenburg 63:
	124. 1922 (d.).
Harms, H., Verh. bot. Ver. Brandenburg 64: 148-149. 1922 (obit.).
Pax, F., Bibl. schles. Bot. 23, 46, 47, 72, 149. 1929.
Wagenitz, G., Index coll. princ. herb. Gott. 1982.

12.702. Königliches Gymnasium zu Inowrazlaw. xx. Zu der den 20. März Vormittags
11 Uhr stattfindenden Vorfeier des Geburtstags Sr. Majestät des Kaisers und Königs ...
ladet ergebenst ein das Lehrer-Collegium. Inhalt I. <em>Flora von Schrimm</em> nebst einem
Beitrag zur Flora von Inowrazlaw ... 2. Schulnachrichten ... Inowrazlaw (Druck von
H. Olawski) Progr. Nr. 136. 1883. Qu. (<em>Fl. Schrimm</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 2-19 Mar 1883 (p. 21: 2 Mar 1883; "Feier" 20 Mar 1883; Nat. Nov. Mai(1) 1883;
	Bot. Centralbl. 9-13 Jul 1883; Bot. Zeit. 29 Jun 1883), p. [i], [1]-21 (followed by
	Schulnachrichten). <em>Copies</em>: B, HH.

12.703. Königliches Gymnasium zu Inowrazlaw. " <em>Verzeichniss der in den Kreisen Inowraz-
law und Strelno bisher beobachteten Gefässpflanzen nebst Standortsangaben</em>" ... Wissenschaftliche
Beilage des Programms Ostern 1888. Inowrazlaw (Druck von H. Olowski). Beilage zu
Progr.-Nr. 142. 1888. Qu. (<em>Verz. Inowrazlaw Gefässpfl</em>.).

<em>1</em>: Mar-Apr 1888 (p. 41: Mar 1888; Easter program; Bot. Zeit. 31 Aug 1888; Bot.
	Centralbl. 17-21 Sep 1888; Nat. Nov. Aug(2) 1888), p. [i], [1]-41.
<em>2</em>: Mar-Apr 1889 (p. 21: Mar 1889; Easter program; Bot. Centralbl. 22 Oct 1889), p. [i],
	[1]-21. – 1889, Beilage zu Progr. Nr. 144.

PAGE: 815
HEADING: SPRING

<em>Copies</em>: B, HH, MO.

Spring, Anton Friedrich [Antoine Frédéric] (1814-1872), German (Bavarian) born
botanist and physician; studied medicine and botany at the University of München; Dr.
phil. ib. 1835, Dr. med. 1836; curator at the München botanical garden 1835-1836;
temporarily practicing medicine at München 1836-1837; continued his studies at Paris;
professor of physiology and anatomy, later of pathology and internal medicine at the
University of Liège 1839-1872. (<em>Spring</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: LG; further material at BR.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 545; Barnhart 3: 312 (b. 8 Apr 1814, d. 17 Jan
1872); BM 5: 1995; Bossert p. 379; CSP 5: 784-785, 8: 992; Frank 3 (Anh.): 99; Herder
p. 133, 142, 144, 223, 273; Hortus 3: 1204; IH 1 (ed. 6): 364, (ed. 7): 343; Jackson p. 41,
149; Lasègue p. 293; LS 25625-25625a; Moebius p. 126, 127; MW p. 466; PR 5902,
6272, 8882-8883, ed. 1: 9858; TL-1/867; TL-2/1969, 6107; Zander ed. 10, p. 720, ed. 11,
p. 821.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Aerztl. Intell.-Bl. 19(6): 62-63. 1872 (obit.); Bot. Not. 1873: 28 (d.); Bot.
	Zeit. 10: 646. 1852 (decoration), 30: 168. 1872 (d.); Bull. Soc. bot. France 18 (bibl.):
	42. 1872 (d.); Flora 23(2): 592. 1840 (app. Liège), 38: 699. 1855 (foreign member
	Bay. Akad. Wiss.); J. Bot. 10: 96. 1872 (d.); Leopoldina 7812): 92. 1872 (obit.);
	Österr. bot. Z. 22: 137. 1872(d.); S.B. mat.-phys. Cl. Akad. Wiss. München 2: 100-
	101. 1872.
Badré, F., Lejeunia 109: 1-14. 1983 (portr., nomencl. types in his herb.).
Candolle, Alph. de, Phytographie 452. 1880 (herb. LG).
Crépin, F., Guide bot. Belgique 244, 245, 477, 478. 1878.
De Seyn, E., Dict. biogr. Sci. lettr. arts Belg. 2: 932. 1936.

<em>Preliminary publications</em>: (1) 1841, 1843, "<em>Enumeratio Lycopodinearum</em>, quas in ejusdem

	21 Mar, 193-205. 7 Apr, 209-224. 14 Apr 1838. – Extract: Ann. Sci. nat. Bot. ser. 2.
	11: 218-237. Apr 1839.

12.706. <em>Des champignons qui se développent dans les oeufs de poule</em> ... Académie royale de
Belgique (Extr. du tome xix, no. 4, des Bulletins) [Bruxelles 1852]. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 1852, p. [1]-19. <em>1 pl</em>. (col. lith.). <em>Copy</em>: FH. – Reprinted and to be cited from Bull.
	Acad. Sci. Bruxelles 19(4): 555-573. 1852.

Spruce, Richard (1817-1893), British botanist and plant collector; schoolmaster at
Haxby and (1839-1844) the Collegiate School of York; from 1844 dedicating himself
exclusively to botany; collected in the Pyrenees 1845-1846; collecting in South America
1849-1864; from 1864 in London, Hurstpierpoint, Welburn (1867-1876) and, ultimately
in Coneysthorpe (Yorks.) (1876-1893); Dr. phil. Leopoldina 1864.
(<em>Spruce</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Main S. American collections at K; duplicates at AWH, B, BEL,
BH, BM, BP, BR, C, CAL, CAS, CGE, CHR, DBN, DS, E, F, FH, FI (incl. Europ.), G,
GH, GLAM, GOET, H, L, LD, LE, LINN (Brit. pl.), M, MANCH, MG, MICH, NY
(incl. mosses Pyrenees through Duss), OXF, P, PC, PH, RB, S, TCD, US, W, YRK
(Brit. pl.). – Many of S.'s Venezuelan collections have been cited from Brazil since this is
stated on the labels. – <em>Letters</em> at BM, FH, G, GH, H, K, NY. Diary (1841-1863) at
LINN. Botanical manuscripts by Spruce at Kew include: <em>Plantae amazonicae</em> (2 vols.),
<em>Plantae andinae</em> (2 vols, numerical register to his flowering plants and ferns; often with
descriptions), a volume of mss. ("i") with short botanical notes; a further volume of mss.
("ii") containing his original journal 1851-1855; a memorandum book containing the
journal from Tarapoto to Banos and notes on bryophytes; letters from W.J. Hooker, G.
Bentham, J.D. Hooker, W. Mitten, J. Miers, Destringe and E. Bescherelle; introductory
notes on Hepaticae; the correspondence with W. Borrer on European bryophytes (Bull.
misc. Inf. Kew 1908: 464). – Some field notes also at NY.
<em>Exsiccatae</em>: (1) <em>Hepaticae pyrenaicae</em>, quas in Pyrenaeis centralibus occidentalibusque, nec
non in agro syrtico, a.d. 1845-6, nos. 1-77, London 1847. Sets at BM, G, K, NY, PC.
(2) <em>Musci pyrenaicae</em>. quos in Pyrenaeis centralibus occidentalibusque, nec non in ago
syrtico, a.d. 1845-6 decerpsit. Rich. Spruce. Fascis i; nos. 1-160, ii: nos. 161-331. London
1847. Sets id. – For further details on (1) and (2) see Sayre 1971.
(3) <em>Hepaticae spruceanae amazonicae et andinae</em>, annis 1849-1860 lectae. Malton, 1892, distri-
buted in irregular sets. <em>Review</em>: L.M. Underwood, Bot. Gaz. 18: 112-113. Mar 1893.
Further details: Sayre 1975.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 545; Barnhart 3: 312 (b. 10 Sep 1817, d. 28
Dec 1893); BB p. 285; BJI 1: 55; BM 5: 1995; Bossert p. 379; Clokie p. 247; CSP 5: 785,
8: 993. 11: 469, 12: 697, 18: 890-891; Desmond p. 578; DNB 53: 431-432 (18: 839-840);
DSB 12: 594 (R.G.C. Desmond); GR p. 415; Herder p. 267, 291; Hortus 3: 1204; IH 1
(ed. 2): 17, 41, 64, 68, 79, (ed. 3): 221, (ed. 6): 364, (ed. 7): 343; Jackson p. 377; Lenley
p. 381; LS 25625; Plesch p. 415; PR 8884; Rehder 5: 818; SBC p. 132; SO 3515a; TL-
2/9813, see H. Ibbotson, G.E. Massee; Tucker 1: 665; Urban-Berl. p. 314, 400.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Accounts from the field of Spruce's travels and collections were given in W.J.
Hooker's botanical journals and other journals as follows:
(1) <em>Plants of the Pyrénées</em>, London J. Bot. 4: 197-199. 1845, 5: 10-11. 1846.
(2) <em>Notes on the botany of the Pyrénées</em>, London J. Bot. 5: 134-142, 345-350, 417-429, 535-
548. 1846.
(3) <em>The musci and hepaticae of the Pyrenees</em>. Ann. Mag. nat. Hist. ser. 2. 3: 81-106, 269-293,
358-380, 478-503. 1849, 4: 104-120. 1849; Trans. Edinb. bot. Soc. 3: 103-216. 1850.
(4) <em>Announcements and news of S. Amer. journey</em>: J. Bot. Kew Gard. Misc. 1: 20-21, 344-347.
1849, 2: 29, 158, 351-352. 1850, 7: 31. 1855, 8: 379. 1856, 9: 310-311. 1857.

305-312. 1852, 6: 94. 1854.
(6) <em>Letters to G. Bentham</em> from the Amazon, J. Bot. Kew Gard. Misc. 4: 278-285, 305-312.
1852.
(7) <em>Journal of a voyage up the Amazon</em> and the Rio Negro, J. Bot. Kew Gard. Misc. 5: 187-
192, 207-215. 1853, 6: 33;42, 107-111. 1854, 7: 1-8. 1855.
(8) <em>Botanical objects communicated to the Kew Museum</em>, from the Amazon River in 1851-1853,

12.719. <em>Notes of a botanist on the Amazon &amp; Andes</em> being records of travel on the Amazon
and its tributaries, the Trombetas, Rio Negro, Uaupés, Casiquiari, Pacimoni, Huallaga,
and Pastasa; as also to the cataracts of the Orinoco, along the Eastern side of the Andes
of Peru and Ecuador, and the shores of the Pacific, during the years 1849-1864 DY
Richard Spruce, ... edited and condensed by Alfred Russell Wallace, ... with a bio-
graphical introduction portrait, seventy-one illustrations and seven maps ... London
(Macmillan and co., Limited ...) 1908, 2 vols. (<em>Notes bot. Amazon</em>).

<em>Editor</em>: Alfred Russell Wallace (1822-1913).
<em>1</em>: 1908 (Nat. Nov. Jan(1) 1909), p. [i-ii], portr., p. [iii]-lii, 1-518, maps, figs. 1-49 in
	text.

<em>Facsimile ed</em>.: 1970, Johnson Reprint Corporation, New York and London; with a new

	Oliver, F.W., Bot. Centralbl. 110: 403-404. 20 Apr 1909 (rev.).

Spruner, Wilhelm von (1805-1874), German (Bavarian) pharmacist and plant collec-
tor; studied in a München pharmacy and at the University of Erlangen; assistant mili-
tary pharmacist (later in charge of the military pharmacy in Athens) in the Greek army
1834-1843; military pharmacist in the Bavarian army 1844-1858, ultimately as
"Oberapotheker ii. Klasse", in retirement in München. (<em>Sprun</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Spruner's personal herbarium was acquired in 1879 by H.
Dingier at Aschaffenburg; it came with Dingler's herbarium to B (almost entirely de-
stroyed 1943). Duplicates from Greece (1840-1843) at BR, C, CAS, DBN, E, G, GOET,
KIEL, L, LE, LZ (destr.), M, W. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 2(2): 381, 3: 452, 6(2): 940; Barnhart 3: 313 (b. 28
Aug 1805, d. 30 Mai 1874); Biol.-Dokum. 17: 8824-8825; Hortus 3: 1204; Lasègue p.
337, 408; Urban-Berl. p. 400; Zander ed. 10, p. 720, ed. 11, p. 821.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Flora 22(Int. Bl.): 24. 1839 (Greek plants for exchange), 27: 175 (re-
	turns to München), 718 (promoted from Ingolstadt to Würzburg, Militär-
	Apothekergehülfe erster Klasse). 1844, 30: 655. 1847 (Unterapotheker ii. Klasse
	Germersheim).

Boissier, E., Fl. orient. 1: xiii. 1867.

Spruner, W. v., Flora 25: 636-639. 1843 (letter to Tommasini on a botanical trip to the

Wagenitz, G., Index coll. princ. herb. Gott. 160. 1982.

etymology was given.

Squier, Ephraim George (1821-1888), American archeologist, ethnologist, diplomat

and editor; journal editor at Albany, Hartford and Chilicothe 1841-1848; chargé

Stacey, John William (1871-1943), American businessman and botanist (caricologist);
studied medicine and botany at the University of Michigan; bookseller at The
Emporiom, San Francisco 1914, founder of the firm of J.W. Stacey, Inc., dealers in
medicai and scientific books 1923; research associate of the California Academy of
Sciences. (<em>Stacey</em>).

Stache, [Karl Heinrich Hector] Guido (1833-1921), German (Silesian) geologist and
palaeontologist; Dr. phil. Breslau 1855; from 1857-1902 with the Geologische Reich-

Stackhouse, John (1742-1819), British botanist and botanical artist; gentleman of
private means dedicating himself mainly to botany on his Pendarves estates 1763-1804;
from 1804 in retirement at Bath. (<em>Stackh</em>.).

Stahl, Augustin (1842-1917), Puerto Rican botanist, of German-Dutch parents;
studied medicine at Würzburg 1861-1864; Dr. med. id. 1864; Puerto Rican government

PAGE: 828
HEADING: STAHL, A.

physician 1864-1865; practicing physician at Bayamón, P.R. from 1865, dedicating him-
self to botany in his spare time. (<em>A. Stahl</em>).

<em>Letters</em> at G.

Stahl, [Christian] Ernst (1848-1919), Alsatian botanist; student of W. Schimper at
Strassburg (gymnasium) and of Millardet (ib., University), of A. de Bary at Halle 1871-
1872, and with the same in Strassburg 1872-1873; Dr. phil. ib. 1873; assistant at the
botanical institute 1874-1877; habil. Würzburg 1877; ordinary professor of botany at
Jena 1881-1919; in Java (Buitenzorg) 1889-1890, and Mexico 1894. (<em>Stahl</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Some material at BR, L, M (lich.). – <em>Letters</em> to W.G. Farlow at
FH; other letters at G.

p. 24; Rehder 5: 819; SK 1: 497-498; TL-2/see Renner; Tucker 1: 665, 3: 292.

Stahlecker, Eugen (1867-?), German (Württemberg) botanist and high school teacher

12.745. <em>Untersuchungen über Thallusbildung und Thallusbau</em> in ihren Beziehungen zum

Stakman, Elvin Charles (1885-1979), American mycologist, palynologist and phyto-
pathologist; studied at the University of Minnesota; B.A. ib. 1906; with Minnesota
public schools 1906-1909; instructor in plant pathology Univ. Minnesota 1909; Dr. phil.
ib. 1913; asst. professor ib. 1913-1916, assoc. professor 1916-1918; regular professor
1918-1953; head of the section of plant pathology, Univ. Minnesota and pathologist at
the office of cereal investigations, U.S.D.A. at St. Paul. Minnesota 1940-1953; emeritus
professor 1953-1979; specialist on cereal rusts and smuts. (<em>Stakman</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: MPPD; some further material at IAC. – <em>Letters</em> at G, HU.

Stampfer, Cölestin (1823-1895), Austrian botanist; Benedictine clergyman and high

Standley, Paul Carpenter (1884-1963), American botanist; M.Sc. New Mexico State
College 1908; assistant ib. 1908-1909; botanist at the U.S. National Museum, Smith-
sonian Institution 1909-1928; id. with the Field Museum of Natural History, Chicago
1928-1950; with the Escuela agrícola Panamericana 1950-1956; in retirement at Teguc-
igalpa 1957-1963; prolific botanist, collector and student of the New World floras,
botanical explorer of Central and Western North America. (<em>Standl</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: F and US (types indicated in publications); duplicates at A,

PAGE: 832
HEADING: STANDLEY

AMES, BH, BPI, BR, C, CR, CUP, DS, E, EAP, ENAG, F, G, GH, GRI, K, L, M,
MAD, MICH, MO, NMC, NY, PH, POM, S, U, W. – <em>Field notes</em> at F and US. <em>Letters</em> at
G and HU.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 315 (b. 21 Mar 1884); BJI 2: 169; BL 1: 319
(index); BM 5: 2001, 8: 1235-1236; Bossert p. 380; Ewan ed. 1: 64, 312, 326, 341, ed. 2:

Stange, Johann Carl Thomas (1792-1854), German (Prussian-Saxony) botanist and

PAGE: 838
HEADING: STANGE

high school teacher; studied theology and philology at Halle a. S.; teacher at the Fried-
richs Gymnasium, Frankfurt a. Oder. (<em>Stange</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown. Stange is known to have made a herbarium (O.
Stange 1862);

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 316 (b. 30 Jun 1792, d. 30 Oct 1954); PR
8901, ed. 1: 9866; Rehder 1: 380.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Ascherson, P., Fl. Provinz Brandenburg 1: 14. 1864.
Lowden, R.M., Taxon, index pers. names vols. 1-30: 695. 1985.
Stange, O., Verh. bot. Ver. Brandenburg 3/4: 370-372. 1862 (d. 3 Oct 1854).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Stangea</em> Graebner (1906) honors the family of Graebner's wife.

12.797. Ankündigung der öffentlichen Prüfung, so wie der zu haltenden Stiftungsrede
und anderer Schulfeierlichkeiten, welche Freitag den 22sten und Sonnabend den 23sten
März in dem hiesigen Friedrichs-Gymnasium statt finden werden, und zu welchen alle
Gönner und Freunde des Schulwesens hiermit ergebenst einladet Dr. Ernst Friedrich
Poppo, Director des Gymnasiums. Inhalt I. <em>Index plantarum phanerogamarum, quae in agro
Francofurtano nascuntur</em> vom Oberlehrer Stange. 2. Schulnachrichten vom Direktor.
Frankfurt a/O. (Gedruckt bei Trowitzsch &amp; Sohn, ...) 1839. Qu. (<em>Index pl. phan.
Francofurt.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Mar 1839, p. [i]-xxv [<em>index</em>], 1 [verso of xxv]-9 [Schulnachrichten]. <em>Copies</em>: B-S (2,
	of which one complete).

Stanger, William (1811-1854), British physician, geologist and surveyor; M.D.
Edinburgh; practicing physician in London; on the Niger Expedition of H. Trotter
1841; in South Africa 1843-1854; surveyor general in Natal from 1845-1854. (<em>Stanger</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BM, K; further material in E, MO. <em>Correspondence</em> with W. J.
Hooker at K.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 316 (d. 14 Mar 1854); BB p. 286; BM 5:
2001; Desmond p. 579; PR (alph.).

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Amer. J. Sci. ser. 2. 20: 392-393. 1855; Bot. Not. 1855: 159 (d. 21 Mar
	1854); Bot. Zeit. 12: 727. 1854 (d. 21 Mar 1854); Flora 37: 704. 1854 (d.); Österr.
	bot. W. 4: 366. 1854.; Quart. J. geol. Soc. 1855: xlii-xliii.
Bayer, A.W., S. Afr. J. Sci. 67: 401-411. 1971.
Boase, F., Modern Engl. biogr. 3: 704. 1965.
Bridson, G.D.R. et al., Nat. hist. mss. res. Great Britain 435.2. 1980.
Clark, J., Africana Notes and News 20(2): 51-53. 1972.
Gunn, M. &amp; L.E. Codd, Bot. expl. S. Afr. 71, 331-332. 1981 (portr., on <em>Stangeria</em>).
Leverton, Dict. S. Afr. biogr. 2: 702 (n.v.).
Smith, J., London J. Bot. 6: 88. 1854.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Stangeria</em> T. Moore (1853).

Stansbury, Howard (1806-1863), American explorer; in corps of civil engineers sur-
veying the Great Lakes area until 1838, from then on officer in the corps of topograph-
ical engineers; in command of an expedition to explore and survey the Great Salt Lake
region 1849-1850; ultimately at Madison, Wisc. (<em>Stansb</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Material at NY. <em>Correspondence</em> with J. Torrey at NY.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 316 (b. 8 Feb 1806, d. 17 Apr 1863); BM 5:
2002; DAB 17: 516; Ewan ed. 1: 220, 312-313; Herder p. 60; Hortus 3: 1204; ME 3: 114-
116; PR 8903; Rehder 1: 322; Tucker 1: 666.

PAGE: 839
HEADING: STAPF

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Amer. ann. Cycl. 1863: 703-704. 1864 (summary of his exploration and

McKelvey, S.D., Bot. expl. Trans.-Miss. West xvri, 673, 678, 1077-1086, 1139. 1955.
Reveal, J., <em>in</em> A. Cronquist et al., Intermountain flora 1: 49-51. 1972.

Wilson, J.G. &amp; J. Fiske, Appi. Cycl. Amer. Biogr. 5: 647. 1888.

12.798. <em>An expedition to the valley of the Great Salt Lake of Utah</em>: including a description of its
geography, natural history, and minerals, and an analysis of its waters: with an authen-
tic account of the Mormon settlement. Illustrated by numerous beautiful plates, from
drawings taken on the spot. Also, a reconnaissance of a new route through the Rocky
Mountains, and two large and accurate maps of that region ... Philadelphia (Lippin-
cott, Grambo &amp; Co.) 1852. Oct. (<em>Exped. Great Salt Lake</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1853 (p. [2]: 19 Apr 1852), frontisp., p. [1]-487, <em>57 pl</em>., 3 maps. <em>Copy</em>: MO. –

	no. 3); for further details see Sabin, J. et al. (1932-1933), ME 3: 114-116 and F.V.
	Coville, Bull. Torrey bot. Club 23: 137-139. 1896 who describes three editions of the
	report.

Stansfield, Abraham (1802-1880), British nurseryman at Ecclesholme and Vale
Gardens, Todmorden. (<em>Stansf</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Formerly at TDN and TOD; not traced (Kent 1957; Kent &amp;
Allen 1984).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 316 (b. 12 Jan 1802, d. 15 Aug 1880); BB p.
286; BL 2: 252, 279, 719; Desmond p. 580; Jackson p. 152.

Stapf, Otto (1857-1933), Austrian botanist; Dr. phil. Wien 1908; assistant with Kerner
von Marilaun, Wien 1882-1889; in Persia 1885; habil. Univ. Wien 1887; assistant at the
Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew 1890, principal assistant 1899, keeper of the herbarium
1909-1922, botanical secretary of the Linnean Society 1908-1916; in retirement at Kew
as editor of the <em>Botanical Magazine</em> 1922-1933 and of the <em>Index londinensis</em>; died on a
summer trip to Austria. (<em>Stapf</em>.)

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: K and WU; duplicates A, C, E, IBF, LI, M (lich.), MO, NMW,
P. – <em>Letters</em> and <em>mss</em>. at K; further letters at G, GH.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 546; Barnhart 3: 317; Biol.-Dokum. 17: 8861;
BJI 1: 55, 2: 170; BL 1: 32, 41, 61, 104, 319; Blunt p. 183, 187, 188, 226; BM 8: 1237;

PAGE: 840
HEADING: STAPF

1933); DTS 1: 287; Hortus 3: 1204; IH 1 (ed. 7): 343; Langman p. 719; Lenley p. 382;
LS 25670-25671; Morren ed. 10, p. 29; MW p. 466-470 (many other items not cited in
other bibl.); NI 1886; NW p. 58; Rehder 5: 820; Saccardo 1: 158, 2: 104; SK 1: cxxiii, 4:

12.800. <em>Die botanischen Ergebnisse der Polak'schen Expedition nach Persien</em> im Jahre 1882.
Plantae collectae a dre J.E. Polak et Th. Pichler von Dr. Otto Stapf ... Wien (aus der
kaiserlich-königlichen Hof- und Staatsdruckerei ...) 1885-1886, 2 parts. Qu. <em>Collectors</em>: J.E. Polak (d. 1891), Thomas Pichler (1828-1903).

<em>Authors</em>: R. v. Wettstein, C. Fehlner, E. Hackel, C. Richter, G. Beck, A. Heimerl, O.
	Stapf, J. Freyn, E. Woloszak, H. Braun, A. Zimmeter. – Types WU.
<em>1</em>: 1885 (Bot. Jahrb. 30 Oct 1885; Nat. Nov. Sep(2) 1885; Bot. Centralbl. 28 Sep-20 Oct
	1885; G copy rd Aug 1886; ÖbZ 1 Mai 1886), p. [i-iii], [1]-71. – Reprinted and to be
	cited from Denkschr. math.-nat. Cl. kais. Akad. Wiss., Wien 50(1): 1-72. 1885.
<em>2</em>: 1886 (Bot. Zeit. 24 Sep 1886; Nat. Nov. Sep(2) 1886), p. [1]-77, [79]. – Id. 51(2):
	271-346. 1886.
<em>Copies</em>: B, G(2), HH, M, NY.
<em>Note</em>: J.E. Polak was physician to the Iranian shah Nasr-Edin, 1851-1860; he subseq-
	uently sponsored a number of expeditions to Iran, the first of which, with Th. Pichler
	and F. Wähner, took place 1881-1882; the second by O. Stapf, 1885. – Eponymy:
	<em>Polakia</em> Stapf.
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., Bot. Centralbl. 48: 239-240. 1891 (on death of J.E. Polak).
	Roth, E., Bot. Centralbl. 30: 206-209. 1887 (rev.).

Starbäck, Karl (1863-1931), Swedish botanist and politician; Dr. phil. Uppsala 1894;
lecturer in botany Uppsala 1895-1896; high school teacher for natural history and
chemistry at Gävle 1902-1928; member of the Swedish Parliament 1902-1914 and 1921-
1924; pioneer of the Swedish nature protection movement (golden medal 1923). (<em>Starb</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: S; other material at B (mainly destr.); CUP, L, UPS. – Contri-
buted to T. Vestergren, <em>Micromycetes rariores ... Scandinavia</em>, q.v. – <em>Letters</em> to W.G. Farlow
at FH; other letters at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 317; BM 5: 2003; Bossert p. 380; GR p. 482,
cat. p. 72; Hawksworth p. 186; Kelly p. 218; Kleppa p. 115; KR p. 663 (bibl., b. 26 Dec
1863); LS 25672-25694; SO 2731; Stevenson p. 1259; Urban-Berl. p. 382.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bot. Not. 1889: 28 (stipend), 1895: 134 ("docent" Uppsala), 1918: 139
	(Linnean medal); Österr. bot. Z. 45: 288. 1895 (lecturer ["docent"] at Uppsala).
Fries, R.E., Short hist. bot. Sweden 63. 1950.
Grönberg, G., Sveriges Natur 23: 138-140. 1932 (biogr., portr., bibl. nat. prot.).
Lindman, S., Sv. män kvinn. 7: 180. 1954 (biogr. portr.).
Svedelius, N., Sv. bot. Tidskr. 34(3): 210-211. 1940.
Wittrock, V.B., Acta Horti Berg. 3(2): 71. 1903, 3(3): 53. <em>pl. 108.</em> 1905.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Starbaeckia</em> Rehm ex Starbäck (1890); <em>Starbaeckia</em> (P.A. Saccardo et P. Sydow)
H. Sydow et P. Sydow (1919).

Starcs, Karlis (1897-1953), Latvian botanist; Mag. rev. nat. Latvian Univ., Riga
1936; botanist at the Bio-entomological station of the Latvian Dept. of Agriculture 1919,
soon afterwards (ca. 1922) until 1944 botanist at the Latvian Institute of Plant Protect-
ion; displaced 1944, at Weimar 1945; with the UNRRA Univ. at München 1946-1949;
in D.P. camps in Bavaria 1945-1950; from 1950-1953 in the United States as gardener in
Indianapolis. (<em>Starcs</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: RIG, Botanical Garden Latvian Univ. and Baltic Plant Protect-
ion Station Riga (in all ca. 100.000 specimens); a Taraxacum collection (3000) from
Latvia at S; duplicate collections of fungi: B (extant), BM, BP, BPI, BUT, CUP, E, H,
K, KANU, LD, M (crypt.), MICH, TRTC, UPS. – Duplicates of <em>Taraxacum</em> at L,
lichens in herb. H. Sandstede q.v. <em>Exsiccatae</em> (/) <em>Betulaceae exsiccatae</em>, fasc, i, nos. 1-25.
1931. Riga. (2) <em>Diseases of Latvian cultivated plants</em>, with A. Kirulis, ed. M. Eglitis, fasc. 1-

PAGE: 845
HEADING: STARING

3, 1937-1944. – Starcs contributed to J. Smarods, <em>Fungi latvici exsiccati</em>, Riga; V. Lits-
chauer, <em>Fungi selecti exsiccati europaei</em>, 1931-1935; F. Petrak, <em>Fungi exsiccati</em>; <em>Cryptogamae
exsiccatae</em> (Mus. Sci. nat. Vindob.), Wien; Zillig, <em>Ustilagineen Europas</em>; E. Eichhorn, <em>Ure-
dineen Europas</em>. – Starcs material from Latvia (Lettland) was also distributed through the
<em>Berliner botanische Tauschverein</em>.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 317, 318 (Starzs); Biol.-Dokum. 17: 8866;
Hirsch p. 285; MW p. 470; Tucker 3: 293.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Österr. bot. Z. 80: 80. 1931 (on <em>Betulaceae exs</em>.).
Hertel, H., Mitt. Bot. München 16: 438-439. 1980 (crypt. coll. 1945-1950 in Bavaria).
Mühlenbach, V., Curriculum vitae and bibliography of K.S., mss. TL-2/files, submitted
	1979 (b. 18 Mai 1897, d. 2 Feb 1953).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: We are grateful to Dr. Viktor Mühlenbach, St. Louis, for the extensive informat-
ion on Starcs on which this entry is based. We have a list of 35 publications up to 1944;
during the difficult years 1944-1953 Starcs added to his herbarium in Germany and the
United States, but we have no record of publications of that period. Starcs' name is
sometimes also spelled Starzs.

12.818. <em>Latvijas pavasarangu noteicejs</em> ... Cesis un Riga (O. Jepes apgadiba [2-7: ...
izdevnieciba]), 1924-1927, 7 parts. (<em>Latv. pavasar. not.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: A spring flora of Latvia, in 7 parts. <em>Copies</em>: HH, USDA. – Published in the series
	Populari-zinatniski raksti, iv(1-7).
	<em>1</em>: 1924, p. [i-ii], [1]-80.
	<em>2</em>: 1925, p. [i-ii], 81-160.
	<em>3</em>: 1925 (Nat. Nov. Mar 1926), p. [1]-ii, 161-240.
	<em>4</em>: 1926 (Nat. Nov. Jun 1927), p. [i-ii], 241-320.
	<em>5</em>: 1927, p. [i-ii], 321-400.
	<em>6</em>: 1927, p. [i-ii], 401-496.
	<em>7</em>: 1927 (preface 12 Mai 1927; Nat. Nov. Jul 1927), p. [i*-ix*], [i]-xcv, [xcvii].

12.819. <em>Koku un krumu notieicejs</em> ... Riga (Mezu Departamenta Izdevums) 1925. Oct. (<em>Koku krümu not</em>.).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1925 (p. vi: 14 Sep 1925), p. [i]-lxx, [lxxi], [1]-444. <em>Copies</em>: HH, USDA. – A
	handbook of Latvian trees and shrubs.

12.820. <em>Über die Verbreitung</em> und Formenkreise <em>der Gymnospermen und Monocotyledonen
Lettlands</em> (Par Latvijas Kallsekju un vlendiglapaino augu izplatibu un formam. Acta
Horti botanici Universitatis latviensis v, 1930. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 15 Mai 1931 (date on cover reprint; author sent a copy to Linkola on 4 Jun 1931 ;
	Nat. Nov. Sep 1932), cover-t.p., p. [9]-59, [60]. <em>Copy</em>: H. – Reprinted and to be cited
	from Act. Hort. bot. Univ. Latv. 5: 9-60. 1930 (ed. 15 Mai 1931).

Staring, Winand Carel Hugo (1808-1877), Dutch geologist and agronomist; Dr. phil.
Leiden 1833; scientist of private means, founder of Dutch geology; secretary of the
Dutch State Committee for geology from 1852-1855. (<em>Staring</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: WAG (fide JW 3: 370).

Stark, Peter (1888-1932), German (Baden) botanist; Dr. phil. Freiburg i. Br. 1911;
assistant botanist ib. 1912-1913 (with Oltmanns); with L. Jost in Strassburg 1914; with
W. Pfeffer in Leipzig 1915-1921; habil. Leipzig 1917; extraordinary professor of forest
botany Freiburg i. Br. 1921-1926; successor to F. Pax as professor of botany at Breslau,
specially dedicating himself to palaeobotanical and palynological studies 1926-1928; suc-
cessor to M. Möbius at Frankfurt a.M. 1928-1932. (<em>P. Stark</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

Staub, Moriz [Móricz, Moritz] (1842-1904), Hungarian botanist (of Swiss-Austrian
parentage), schoolteacher in Budapest 1858-1868; studied natural sciences in Budapest
(with L. Jurányi), Berlin and Bonn 1869-1870; professor of natural history at the royal
teacher's college of Budapest 1872-1904; mainly specialized in phaenology and
palaeobotany. (<em>Staub</em>).

Staunton, Sir George Leonard (1737-1801), English physician and diplomat; pract-
iced in the West-Indies 1762-1770, in Grenada 1772-1779; secretary to Lord Macartney
in Madras 1781-1784 and in China 1792-1794; collected plants in China. (<em>Staunton</em>).

300, 346, 435, 503; MW p. 470; Rehder 1: 458; SK 1: 498; TL-2/see C. Abel; Tucker 1:
666.

Stearn, William Thomas (1911-x), British botanist; apprentice antiquarian booksel-
ler Cambridge 1929-1932; librarian Royal Horticultural Society 1933-1941, 1946-1952;
with Royal Air Force in Britain, India and Birma 1941-1946; botanist British Museum
(Nat. Hist.) 1952-1976; founder member of the Society for the Bibliography of Natural
History; D.Sc.h.c. Leiden 1960; Hon. Sc.D. Cambridge 1967; Dr. phil. h.c. Uppsala
1972; Linnean gold medal 1976; commander of the Royal Order of the Northern Star
1980, etc. etc.; outstanding botanical historian and bibliographer, a modern Linnaeus;
through his continued support and stimulation godfather of TL-2. (<em>Stearn</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BM. – Other material at BH, CGE, K, NY, OXF, W. <em>Exsiccatae</em>:
J.S.L. Gilmour &amp; W.T. Stearn, <em>Herbarium florae cantabrigiense</em> and <em>Sertum cantabrigiense

<sm>MAIN BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm>: Biol. J. Linn. Soc. 8(4): 299-318. 1976 (with index). – Stearn's
contributions to the bibliography and in general the correct interpretation and history
of classical taxonomic publications, from Carl Linnaeus to Agnes Arber, are of the
greatest importance to modern taxonomy. Under "Composite works" we cite the main
reissues of classical works, mosty with detailed and very pertinent introductions. Of the
book publications after 1939 we refer to Stearn's <em>Botanical Latin</em> of 1966 (xiv, 566 p.; see
e.g. F. Markgraf, Bot. Jahrb. 85: 25-32. 1966 and F.A. Stafleu, Taxon 15: 235-237.
1966).

Steenis, Cornells Gijsbert Gerrit Jan van (1901-x). Dutch botanist; Dr. phil.
Utrecht 1927; botanist Buitenzorg (Bogor) 1927-1946; repatriated 1946; director and
general editor of the Flora Malesiana Foundation 1950; professor of tropical botany
Amsterdam 1951, id. of floristics of the Malesian flora, Leiden 1953; director of the
Leiden Rijksherbarium 1962-1972; in retirement ib. 1971 ; chief moving spirit of the
Flora malesiana. (<em>Steenis</em>).

Steenstrup, Johannes Japetus Smith (1813-1897), Danish botanist and zoologist;
travelled to Iceland 1839-1840; lecturer in botany at Sorø Akademi 1841-1845; professor
of zoology at Copenhagen University 1845-1885. (<em>Steenstr</em>.).

Steere, William Campbell (1907-x), American botanist; Dr. phil. Univ. Mich. 1932;
instructor in botany Univ. Mich. 1931-1936, asst. prof. 1936-1942, assoc. prof. 1942-
1946, full prof. 1946-1950; chairman Botany Dept. 1947-1950; prof. Biol. Stanford Univ.
1950-1958, with National Science Foundation 1954-1955; Dean Graduate Div.,
Stanford Univ., 1955-1958; director New York Botanical Garden 1958-1968, exec. dir.
1968-1970, president 1970-1972, president emeritus 1973-x; leading bryologist and spec-
ialist on arctic and tropical American bryology; Dr. sci. h.c. Univ. Montreal 1959, id.
Michigan 1962, idem Alaska 1982. (<em>Steere</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: NY (from 1958), NY-DS (1950-1958), MICH (to 1950). Other
material at ALA, BM, F, FH, GH, H, K, LA, LCU, MEDEL, MO, NY (before 1958),

PAGE: 864
HEADING: STEERE

NY, PH, QK, S, US. <em>Exsiccatae</em>: Bryophyta arctica exsiccata, fasc, 1 (nos. 1-50), 1975-x
(fasc. 1-2 with K.A. Holmen). Sets e.g. at C, H, NY. <em>Correspondence</em> at NY; other <em>letters</em> at
G, GH, HU, SIA. <em>Field notes</em>: MICH, NY, US (Cinchona project).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Andrews p. 335; Barnhart 3: 320 (b. 4 Nov 1907); BFM

Steetz, Joachim (1804-1862), German (Hamburg) botanist; studied pharmacy at
Halle 1825-1826, and Würzburg 1826-1829; Dr. med. Würzburg 1829; physician at the
hospital of the Holy Spirit, Hamburg 1830-1862; from 1849 lecturer at the Hamburg
botanical garden. (<em>Steetz</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Orchid herb. in W (herb. Reichenbach); other material at BR,
C, HBG, K, LD (Plantae preissianae set), M, MEL, PH, W. This material consists
(mostly) of plants collected by others, acquired and distributed by Steetz. – <em>Letters</em> to
D.F.L. von Schlechtendal at HAL; other letters at G, GH.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 320 (b. 12 Nov 1804, d. 24 Mar 1862); Biol.-
Dokum. 17: 8881; BM 5: 2007-2008; CSP 5: 806, 8: 1003; Herder p. 231, 307, 331, 334,

PAGE: 866
HEADING: STEETZ

Steiner, Maximilian (1904-x), Austrian botanist (lichenologist and physiologist); Dr.
phil. Wien 1926; assistant at the plant physiological institute of the University ib. 1926-
1929; biologist I.G. Farben, Ludwigshafen 1930-1931; assistant Technische Hochschule
Stuttgart 1932; habil. ib. 1935; lecturer ib. 1936; assistant Botanisches Institut Göttingen
1939; from 1940 professor of botany at Bonn. (<em>M. Steiner</em>).

Steinheil, Adolph [Adolphe] (1810-1839), Alsatian botanist; studied pharmacy,
chemistry and botany at Strasbourg and Paris; military pharmacist and surgeon in
various places in France; id. in Algeria 1830-1834; id. in Strasbourg 1835-1838; traveller
for the Muséum d'Histoire naturelle 1839; died at sea between Martinique and
Venezuela. (<em>Steinh</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: P; further material at B (mainly destr.), BR, FI, W.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 322 (b. Dec 1810, d. 28 Mai 1839); Biol.-
Dokum. 17: 8921; BM 5: 2011 ; CSP 5: 814-815; GR p. 352; Hortus 3: 1204; Krempelh.
1: 169, 521; Lasègue p. 38, 170, 314, 315, 504; LS 25765; PR 8925-8927, ed. 1: 7070,
9887-9889; Rehder 5: 822; Urban-Berl. p. 400; Zander ed. 10, p. 721, ed. 11, p. 822.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bot. Not. 1840: 80; Flora 22: 560. 1839 (d.).
Candolle, Alph. de, Phytographie 452. 1880 (Alg. pl. at P).
Cosson, E., Comp. fl. atl. 1: 92-93. 1881.
Maire, R., Progr. connaiss. bot. Algérie 21-22. 1931.
Cosson, E. &amp; Durieu de Maisonneuve, M.C., Exp. sci. Algérie Bot. 2: xlv-xlvi. 1868.
Decaisne, J., Ann. Sci. nat., Bot. ser. 2. 12: 109-118. 1839 (obit.).
Sitzmann, É., Dict. biogr. homm. cél. Alsace 2: 823-824. s.d.
Urban, I., Symb. antill. 3(1): 132-133. 1902.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Steinheilia</em> Decaisne (1838).

Steininger, Hans (1856-1891), Austrian botanist and school teacher from Garsten nr
Steyr; teacher at Unterlaussa and Reichraming. (<em>Steininger</em>).

Steinmann, [Johann Heinrich Conrad Gottfried] Gustav (1856-1929), German
palaeontologist and geologist; Dr. phil. München 1877; assistant (1877) and lecturer
(1880) in Strasbourg; extraord. prof. geology Jena 1885; ord. prof. ib. Freiburg i. Br.
1886; prof. geology and palaeontology Bonn 1906-1929. (<em>Steinmann</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Andrews p. 335; Barnhart 3: 323 (b. 9 Apr 1856); BM 1:
469, 5: 2011-2012; CSP 18: 935; Quenstedt p. 412 (d. 7 Oct 1929).

	108. 1921 (bibl.).

	2534-2535. 1940 (bibl.).

Steinvorth, Heinrich (1817-1905), German (Hannoverian) botanist and high school
teacher at the Johanneum, Lüneburg; later in retirement at Hannover. (<em>Steinvorth</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: HAN.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 323; BM 5: 2012; Christiansen p. 320
[index]; IH 2: (files); LS 25768, 32889; Morren ed. 10, p. 14; PR 8928; Rehder 1: 382,
5: 823.

	(90). 1905 (d. 24 Nov 1905).
Fischer-Benzon, R.J.D. v., <em>in</em> P. Prahl, Krit. Fl. Schlesw.-Holst. 2: 56. 1890.
Koppe, F., Abh. naturw. Ver. Bremen 36: 240, 256. 1964.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Johannes Steinvorth wrote, with R. von Fischer-Benzon as senior author, <em>Ueber die
Flora der Umgegend von Hadersleben</em> ... Hadersleben 1873, see P. Ascherson, Bot. Zeit. 31:
443-444. 1873. See also R.J.D. Fischer-Benzon in P. Prahl, Krit. Fl. Schl.-Holst. 2(1).
56-57. 1890.

Stelfox, Arthur Wilson (1883-1972), Irish architect and naturalist; at the National
Museum Dublin 1920-1948. (<em>Stelfox</em>).

Stellati, Vincenzo (1780-1852), Italian (Napoli) botanist and physician; practicing
physician at Napoli, also professor of materia medica at the University and director of
its botanical garden. (<em>Stellati</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 323 (d. 8 Mar 1852); BM 5: 2013; Bossert p.
382; CSP 5: 818; Herder p. 73; PR 8929, ed. 1: 9894; Rehder 1: 85; Saccardo 1: 158, 2:
104.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Balsamo, F., Bull. Orto bot. Napoli 3: 47. 1913 (portr., biogr. not.).
Wittrock, V.B., Acta Horti Berg. 3(2): 166. 1983, 3(3): 180. 1905.

Steller [Stöller], Georg Wilhelm (1709-1746), German (Franconian) explorer, geo-
grapher and biologist; studied medicine in Halle 1731-1734; physician in the Russian
army 1734, assistant to Johann Amman at the Academy of Sciences, St. Petersburg
1737; on the second Bering Expedition 1738-1742, with V. Bering in Kamchatka 1740,
and on the St. Peter to Alaska 1741 ; worked in Petropavlovsk 1742-1744, died on the
journey back to St. Petersburg. (<em>Steiler</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: LE, including manuscripts. Botanical collections from Alaska
lost. Some lichens from Kamtchatka at GOET and M. – Some of his collections (30) are
at LINN, other specimens at BM, H.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 3: 116; Backer p. 548; Barnhart 3: 323 (b. 10 Mar
1709, d. 14 Nov 1749); BM 5: 2013, 8: 1244; Dryander 3: 557; DSB 13: 28-29 (S.
Lindroth); Frank 3 (Anh.): 100; Hegi 5(2): 726; Herder p. 60; IH 2: (files); Lasègue p.
322, 357, 411, 503; MW suppl. p. 333; PR 8930, ed. 1: 9895; Rehder 1: 454; TL-2/see
J.G. Gmelin, F. Ruysch; TR 1354-1364 (lists also mss.).

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Alden and Ifft, Occ. Papers Calif. Acad. Sci. 20: 4-7. 1943.
Anon., Bonplandia 6: 55-56. 1858 (on letters Steiler to J.G. Gmelin).
Borodin, J., Trav. Mus. bot. Acad. Sci. St. Petersburg 4: 113-114. 1908 (on explorat-
	ions; eponymy).
Coats, A.M., Plant hunters 50-51. 1969.
Candolle, Alph. de, Phytographie 452. 1880 (coll. at LE).
Crowley, W.R., Morton Arbor. Quart. 12(3): 43. 1976.
Ewan, J., Regn. veg. 71: 38, 50, 54. 1970 (coll. Alaska; in Essays in Biohistory).
Ford, Covey, Where the sea breaks its back. The epic story of the pioneer naturalist and
	the discovery of Alaska. Boston-Toronto 1966, 206 p.
Fries, T.M., Bref Skrifv. Linné 1(2): 32. 1908, 1(3): 188, 196. 1909, 1(5): 227. 1911,
	1(6): 258. 1912.
Herder, F. v., Bot. Jahrb. 9: 452-453. 1888 (notes on travels and bot. coll.).
Hünefeld, H., <em>in</em> Fränkische Lebensbilder 7: 209-221. 1977 (bibl., mss., major
	treatment).
Hultén, E., Fl. Kamchatka 8. 1927 (on coll. at LE); Bot. Not. 1940: 289-290, 295-296.

Jackson, B.D., Proc. Linn. Soc. 134 (suppl.): 20. 1922 (30 specimens at LINN).

12.955. Georg Wilhelm Stellers ... <em>Beschreibung von dem Lande Kamtschatka</em> dessen Ein-
wohnern, deren Sitten, Nahmen, Lebensart und verschiedenen Gewohnheiten herausge-
geben von J.B.S. ... Frankfurt und Leipzig (bey Johann Georg Fleischer) 1774. Oct. (<em>Beschr. Kamtschatka</em>).

<em>Editor</em> and author of biography of Steller (p. [1]-24): J.B. Scherer.
<em>Publ</em>.: 1774 (NZgS 27 Nov 1775), p. [i-viii], [1]-24, [1-4], [1]-384, [1]-71, [72], <em>15 pl.
	Copies</em>: H-UB, HH, NSUB. – For a complete collation and notes see Lada-Mocarski

Stenhammar, Christian (1783-1866), Swedish botanist (lichenologist), clergyman,
politician and polyhistor; Dr. phil. Uppsala 1801; ordained 1813; Dr. theol. 1845, high

PAGE: 884
HEADING: STENHAMMAR

school teacher history and geography at Linköping (1822) 1823-1830; from 1836 vicar
at Häradshammar and Jonsberg in Östergötland; member of the Swedish Parliament
1834-1851. (<em>Stenh</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: S, UPS (non-Swedish material at Linköping). – Other material
(mostly sets of exsiccatae) at B (mainly destr.), BM, BPI, BR, CAN, COLO, FH, L, LD,
M, NA, NY, PC, TO, UPS (impt. coll.), WRSL. <em>Exsiccatae</em>: (<em>1</em>) <em>Lichenes Sueciae exsiccati</em>
fasc. 5-6, nos. 121-180. 1825; fasc. 10, nos. 271-300. 1833; 14, nos. 391-420. 1833. (fasc.
1-4, 7-9, 13 by E. Fries; fasc. 12 by Th.M. Fries).
(2) <em>Lichenes sueciae exsiccati</em>. Editio altera, fasc. 1-8. nos. 1-240, 40 sets issued, 1856-1865.
Sets at e.g. BM, FH, H, K, L, LD, M, MICH, MSC, NY, O, PC, UPS, W. – Sten-
hammar received a state subvention of 600 Rth. for the continuation of this work in
1859 (Flora 42: 95. 1859); see also Bot. Not. 1857: 69, 1863: 62, 1865: 167.
For further details on the exsiccatae and associated publications see KR p. 666-667, nos.
4, 5, 7, 8 and Sayre (1969). – A note in Hedwigia 8: 24 (1869) states that S.'s lichen
herbarium is at S. – <em>Letters</em> to D.F.L. von Schlechtendal at HAL; other letters at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 323 (b. 18 Oct 1783, d. 10 Jan 1866); BM 2:
625; CSP 5: 819, 8: 1010; Frank 3 (Anh.): 100; GR p. 482, <em>pl</em>. [<em>39</em>], cat. p. 72;

Step, Edward (1855-1931), British naturalist; popular writer on botany, entomology
and conchology; employee of various publishing firms. (<em>Step</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 324 (b. 11 Nov 1855, d. 11 Nov 1931); BL 2:
222, 224, 720; BM 5: 2015, 8: 1244; Desmond p. 582 (d. 8 Nov 1831); KR 668-669; LS
39539-39540, 41753; Rehder 5: 823; TL-2/601, 8275; Tucker 1: 667.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Adkin, The Entomologist 64: 287-288. 1931 (obit.), North Western Natural.
	7(1): 41-42. 1932 (obit.).
Anon., Bot. Exch. Cl. Brit. Isl. Rep. 1931: 631; Brit. Mus. gen. cat. print. books 229:
	520-523. 1964 (extensive list of books; published also under the pseudonym James
	Weston); J. Bot. 69: 315. 1981 (d.); Nature 128: 863. 1931 (obit. not.); Proc. S.
	London entom. nat. Hist. Soc. 1931: 34-35. 1932 (obit., portr.); Who's who, London
	1899-1932.

	history books).

Stephan, [Christian] Friedrich (1 757-1814), German (Saxonian) botanist and physi-
cian; studied in Leipzig and Leiden; to St. Petersburg 1792; military physician in the
Crimea 1783; professor of botany and chemistry at Moscow 1786; director of the Fores-
try Institute St. Petersburg from 1811. (<em>Stephan</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: LE; other material in B-W, H (Chr. Steven), MW.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 5(1): 539; Barnhart 3: 324 (d. 17 Dec 1814); BM 5:
2015; Dryander 3: 648; GR p. 141; Herder p. 201, 315; Hortus 3: 1204; LS 25800; MW
p. 471; PR 8938-8941, ed. 1: 9902-9904; SO 746b; TR 1365-1369; Tucker 1: 667;
Zander ed. 10, p. 721, ed. 11, p. 822.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Lipschitz, S., Fl. URSS fontes nos. 1006-1008. 1975.
Shetler, S.G., The Komarov Botanical Institute 28, 196. 1967.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Stephania</em> Willdenow (1799).

12.987. <em>Icones plantarum mosquensium</em> ad historiam plantarum sponte circa Mosquam cres-

<em>1</em>: 1795, cover-t.p., [1-2], <em>pl. 1-10</em>.

12.988. <em>Nomina plantarum</em> quas alit <em>ager mosquensis</em> et hortus privatus ... Petropoli (typis

<em>Publ</em>.: 1804, p. [1]-61. <em>Copies</em>: NSUB, P. – Names only.

Stephani, Franz (1842-1927), German (Berlin) botanist (hepaticologist), from 1859-
1863 and 1867-1868 employee, from 1868-1869 director of a woollen yarn spinning mill
at Dessau, travelling in Europe 1863-1864; in New York for further professional training
1864-1866; merchant in Waldkirchen (Erzgebirge, Saxonia) 1869-1880; director of a
wholesale toys store in Leipzig 1880-1884; from 1884-1907 with the publishing house
Julius Klinghardt, Leipzig, from 1889 as confidential clerk; from 1907 in retirement at
Leipzig, at Oetsch nr Leipzig 1910-1927. (<em>Steph</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Original herbarium (ca. 11.000 specimens) at G, but a collection
of 11.920 "duplicates" (actually with many unicates) had previously been sold to BM;
duplicates at B (mainly destr.), BP, FH, G, K, M (many isotypes), MPU, NY, PR,
PRC, W, WELT.
<em>Icones hepaticarum</em>, a set of 12.329 pencil drawings of hepatics studied by S. at G (see
Bonner 1958). – Copies of these drawings were made by Stephani's daughter (up to 20

PAGE: 890
HEADING: STEPHANI

sets) and sold to other institutions. Such sets are e.g. at BM, CINC, FH (9.093), M,
MELU, PC, S, WIS. – See Geissler (1982) for the significance of these drawings for the
typification of S.'s taxa, and for further details. S.'s correspondence is also at G. – 35
<em>letters</em> to V.F. Brotherus at H-UB, 36 letters to F. Renauld at PC, letters to W.G. Farlow
at FH; other letters at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 324 (b. 15 Apr 1842, d. 23 Feb 1927); Biol.-
Dokum. 17: 8945; BJI 1: 56, 171; BM 8: 1244; Bossert p. 382; CSP 11: 491, 12: 703, 18:
944-945; Herder p. 261; IH 1 (ed. 2): 53, (ed. 3): 65, (ed. 6): 364; Jackson p. 296; KR p.
669; NI 1890; SBC p. 132; TL-2/1592, 2867, 7591, 8502, 8726, 8915, 8987, see W.
Colenso, J.B.W. Lindenberg, A. Rehmann; Urban-Berl. p. 314.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bryologist 25: 111. 1923 (Icones hepaticarum for sale); Hedwigia 67:
	(163). 1927 (d.); J. Bot. 33: 256. 1895 (BM will acquire half the Stephani herbarium,
	"of half, that is to say, of all his specimens which will bear splitting. [By contract
	Stephani had to leave his original herbarium to G as a compensation for the publicat-
	ion of the <em>Species hepaticarum</em>]); Rev. bryol. 40: 32. 1913 (can no longer use a micro-
	scope; request not to send further material).
Baehni, C., Mus. Genève 13(8)11. 1956 (on Icon. hepat.).
Beauverd, G., Bull. Soc. bot. Genève ser. 2. 19(2): 334-343. 1928 (obit., discussion of
	publ.).
Bonner, C.E.B., Verh. Schweiz. naturf. Ges. 138: 135-137. 1958 (<em>Icones</em> acquired by G).
Geissler, P., Candollea 37(1): 203-217. 1982 (bibl.).
Kitagawa, V., Shida to Koke 5(3): 37-41. 1971 (Japanese).
Koponen, T., <em>in</em> Bryophyte systematics 164. 1979 (corr. Brotherus).
Lowden, R.M., Taxon, Index pers. names vols. 1-30. 701. 1985.
Murray, G., Hist. coll. BM(NH) 1: 184. 1904 (11.920 hepatics, being a series of co-types
	... purchased 1895, 1896).
Reimers, H., Hedwigia 68: 347-350. 1929 (obit., portr.).
Sayre, G., Bryologist 80: 518. 1977 (coll., sets of drawings).
Schmid, B. &amp; C. Thesing, Biol.-Kalend. 1: 320. 1914.
Schuster, R.M., Hep. Anthoc. N. Amer. 1: 102-105. 1966 (bibl.).
Urban, I., Symb. ant. 1: 159. 1898.
Zijlstra, G., Taxon 31: 718-722. 1982 (use of Sprucean subgeneric names in Lejeunea
	1888-1893).

<sm>MAIN BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm>: P. Geissler, Candollea 37(1): 203-217. 1982.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Stephani contributed <em>Hepaticae</em> to numerous composite works. They
are listed in the bibliography by Geissler (1982). We mention only some of the most
important items published in bibliographically independent items.
(1) [Hepaticae], <em>in</em> E. Delaware et al., <em>Florule de l'Ile Miquelon</em>, Lyon 1888, p. 64-66.
(2) [Hepaticae], <em>in</em> A. Geheeb, <em>Neu. Beitr. Moosfl. Neu-Guinea</em> 1889, (Bibl. bot. 13), p. 12.
(3) <em>Die Lebermoose des Kilimandscharo-Gebietes, in</em> H.H. Meyer, <em>Ostafrikanische Gletscherfahr-
ten</em>, Anhang 5: 1-2. Leipzig 1891.
(4) With G. Lindau, <em>Hepaticae, in</em> A. Engler, <em>Die Pflanzenwelt Ostafrikas</em> 5(c): 62-66. 1895.
(5) Hepaticae, <em>in</em> E. Bescherelle, <em>Muscinées in</em> E.J. de Cordemoy, <em>Fl. Réunion</em> 2-16. 1895.
(6) [Hepaticae, identifications in] F. Renauld, <em>Prodr.fl. bryol. Madagascar</em> 279-290. 1897.
(7) <em>Lebermoose aus dem Umanakdistrict, in</em> Bot. Erg. Ges. Erdk. Grönlandexp. A: 62. 1897.
(8) <em>Hepatics, in</em> [W.P. Hiern], <em>Cat. Afr. pl. Welwitsch</em> 2: 310-321. 1901.
(9) <em>Hepaticae novae Dussianae, in</em> I. Urban, Symb. ant. 2: 469-472. 1 Oct 1901, 3(2): 275-
279. 15 Aug 1902.
(10) With V. Schiffner, <em>Hepaticae, in</em> K. Schumann &amp; K. Lauterbach, <em>Fl. deut. Schutzgeb.
Südsee</em> 69-79. 1901.
(11) [Hepaticae, ident. in] A. Duss, <em>Fl. crypt. Antilles franç</em>. [129]-169. 1904.
(12) <em>Lebermoose, Hepaticae, in</em> H. Meyer, <em>In den Hoch-Anden von Ecuador</em>, Berlin 1907, p. 516-
517.
(13) <em>Hepaticae, in</em> C. Chilton, <em>Subantarct. Isl. New Zealand</em> 2: 532-534. 1909.
(14) <em>Hepaticae von Neu-Caledonien, in</em> F. Sarasin &amp; J. Roux, <em>Nova Caledonia, B. Botanik</em> 1(1,
3): 17-19. 1914, 1(2): 110 1920.

13.000. <em>Species hepaticarum</em>. Eine Darstellung ihrer Morphologie und Beschreibung ihrer
Gattungen wie aller Bekannten in Monographien unter Berücksichtigung ihrer geg-
enseitigen Verwandtschaft und geographischen Verbreitung ... Genève et Bale (Georg
&amp; Cie, ...) Lyon (même maison) [1898-] 1900. 6 vols. Oct. (<em>Sp. hepat</em>.).

<em>1</em>: 5 Apr 1898-25 Jun 1906 (see table below), p. [i-iii], [1]-413. – Reprinted with inde-
	pendent pagination from Bull. Herb. Boissier.

Sterbeeck, Frans [Franciscus] van (1630-1693), Flemish (Antwerp-born) clergyman
and botanist; priest at Hoogstraten (de Kempen, Belgium); ord. 1655; chaplain at

13.012. <em>Theatrum fungorum</em> oft het tooneel der Campernoelien waer inne vertoont wort de
gedaente, ken-teeckens, natuere, crachten, voetsel, deught ende ondeught; mitsgaders
het voorsichtigh schoonmaken ende bereyden van allerhande Fungien; en blijck-
teeckenen van de gene die vergiftighe gegeten hebben, met de gheneesmiddelen tot
soodanigh ongeval dienende: beneffens eene naukeurige beschrijvinghe vande Aerd-
buylen, Papas, Tarratouffli, Artichiocken onder d'aerde, ende dierghelijcken ghewas-
schen. Waer by ghevoegt is een cort tractaet vande hinderlijcke Cruyden van dit landt,
als wilde Petercelie, ende andere, met de teghen middelen teghen soodanigh vergif. Alles
met neerstigheyt, lanck-duerige ondervindinghe, ende ijverigh ondersoecken vande
Schriften der ervarenste cruyt-kenders vergaedert ende beschreven door Franciscus van
Sterbeeck priester. Verciert met veele beeiden van alle ghedaenten van Campernoelien
ende andere cruyden, dienende tot dit werck: alles naer het leven in coper ghesneden.
t'Antwerpen (Bij Joseph Jacobs, ...) 1675. Qu. (<em>Theatr. fang</em>.).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1675, frontisp., portr., p. [i-xxxviii], 1-396, [397-415, indexes], [416, err.], <em>pl. 1-36.
	Copies</em>: BR, G, MO, NY, Stevenson; IDC 5288.
<em>Ed. 2</em>: 1712, as ed. 1 with new t.p., front., portr., p. [i-xxxii], 1-396, [397-415, indexes],
	[416, err.], <em>pl. 1-36</em>. – "Den tweeden Druk verbetert". t'Antwerpen (by Franciscus
	Huyssens, ...) 1712. Qu. <em>Copies</em>: BR, G, Stevenson.
<em>Note</em>: on the origin of Sterbeecks illustrations of fungi see Britzelmayr (1894, 1895),
	Istvánffi (1895) and Clusius – Codex 1900, (TL-2/3198) and Van Bambeke (1907).

13.013. <em>Citricultura</em> oft regeringhe der uythemsche boomen te weten oranien, citroenen,
limoenen, granaten, laurieren en andere. Waer in beschreven is de gedaente ende ken-
nisse der boomen, met hunne bloemen, bladeren en vruchten: van ieder geslacht in het
besonder. Als oock van den Ranck-appel, oprechten Laurier van America, den Caneel-
boom: ende besonderlijck van den Verboden Adams oft Paradys-appel. Daer beneffens
de natuere, kracht, en ghebruyck, haer deught en ondeught van ieder vrucht en plant.
Wae by oock grondigh gheleert wordt het zaeyen, mesten, planten, oculeren, inten,
afsuyghen, inlegghen, besnoeyen, en begieten. Oock de kennisse van het treuren ofte
sieckten der Boome1, ende haere behulp-middelen. Met alle ghene dese boomen (so wel
in den winter, als in den somer) tot welstandt zijn versoeckende. Ende dat alles naer den
eysch van ons Nederlandts climaet. By lanckdurighe ondervindinghge in het licht
ghegheven ende met kopere platen verciert ... t'Antwerpen (By Joseph Jacops, ...)
1682. Qu. (<em>Citricultura</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1682 (approb. 26 Feb 1882), p. [i-xl], 1-296, [297-320, indexes], (321, approb.],
	<em>pl. 1-14</em> (uncol. copp.) (and 2 in preface mat.). <em>Copies</em>: G, MO, NY.
<em>Ed. 2</em>: 1712, p. [i-xl], 1-296, [297-320, indexes], <em>pl. 1-14</em> (and 1 in preface mat.). <em>Copy</em>:
	BR. – "Den tweeden druck verbetert" t'Antwerpen (by Franciscus Huyssens, ...)
	1712. Qu.

Sterler, Alois (1787-1831), German (Bavarian) botanist. (<em>Sterler</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

Stern, [Sir] Frederick Claude (1884-1967), British banker, soldier, horticulturist and
botanist; treasurer Linnean Society 1941-1958; chairman John Innes Horticultural
Institution 1947-1961. (<em>F.C. Stern</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BM and K; <em>letters</em> and mss. at K.

	(description of his garden at Highdown); Gard. Chron. 1932(1): 340 (portr.),

Stern, Kurt (1892-x), German (Silesian) botanist; studied law in Berlin and natural
sciences in Breslau and München; Dr. phil. München 1914; student of K. v. Goebel. (<em>K.
Stern</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

Sternberg, Kaspar [Caspar] Maria (Graf) von (1761-1838), Bohemian botanist;
studied theology privately and in Rome; Theologus absolutus 1782; prebendary, from
1788 canon at the court of the prince-bishop of Regensburg and, from 1791, also canon
at the court at Freising 1791-1810; from 1810 head of the family estate at Radnice
devoting himself to management, botany and to the promotion of the natural sciences in
Bohemia; co-founder of the Bohemian Natural Museum, president of the museum 1822-
1838; outstanding palaeobotanist. (<em>Sternb</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: PR (all botanical, geological and palaeobotanical collections);
other material at K (Saxifraga). – <em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 5(2): 436, 651, 6(1): 303, 12(2): 244; Andrews p. 84
(ed. 1), 335 (ed. 2); Backer p. 550; Barnhart 3: 326 (b. 6 Jan 1761, d. 20 Dec 1838);
Biol.-Dokum. 17: 8953-8954; BM 5: 2017; Bossert p. 382; CSP 5: 824-826, 6: 758, 8:
1013; DSB 13: 43-44; DTS 1: 290-291; Frank 3 (Anh.): 100; Futak-Domin p. 564-565,
693; GF p. 77; GR p. 460; Hegi 2: 319, 4(2): 1050; Herder p. 479 [index]; Hortus 3:
1204; IH 1 (ed. 2): 100, (ed. 3): 126, (ed. 6): 364, 2: (files); Jackson p. 13, 143, 176;
Kanitz p. 117; Klástersý p. 182-183 (further biogr. refs.); Lasègue p. 333; Maiwald p.
85-89, 283 [index]; Moebius p. 128, 376, 379; MW p. 472; NI 1896-1897; PH 567;
Plesch p. 417; PR 1218, 5993, 8951-8959, 9026, 9632, ed. 1: 1359, 7702, 9911-9920,
9979; Quenstedt p. 414; Rehder 1: 78, 325, 376, 433, 5: 824; RS p. 143; Saccardo 1: 158,
2: 104; SBC p. 132; SO add. 821a; Sotheby 722; TL-1/1171, 1269-1270; TL-2/191, 826,
8293; WU 38: 252-266; Zander ed. 10, p. 721, ed. 11, p. 822-823.

<em>Heft 7-8</em>: 1 Sep-7 Oct 1838 (Flora 7 Jan 1839; Hinrichs 7-13 Oct 1838), p. [81]-220, <em>pl</em>.
	<em>27</em>(<em>A</em>)-<em>68</em>(<em>A-B</em>). – Cover: Prag (Druck und Papier von Gottlieb Haase Söhne) 1838.
	Most genera on p. 108-207 are attributed to K.B. Presi.
<em>Skizzen zur vergleichenden Phytotomie</em> vor- und jetztweltlicher Pflanzen-Stämme, von A.C.I.
	Corda, ... s.d. [1838], p. [i*], [i]-lxxxi [as"lxxi"], published Sep-Oct 1838, together
	with Heft 7-8.
<em>French ed</em>.: 1820-1826. 4 cahiers. Came out somewhat later than the German original.
	The first cahier, though dated 1820, must even so be considered as having been
	published after the German original, notwithstanding the circumstance that the latter
	has the conventional date 31 Dec 1820. – Translation by François Gabriel de Bray
	(1765-1832). <em>Copies</em>: BR, MO, NY, PH.
	<em>General t.p.</em>: 1826, p. [i], <em>Essai d'un exposé géognostico-botanique de la flore du monde primitif</em>
	... par le comte Gaspard Sternberg, ... traduit de l'Allemand par le comte de
	Bray, ... Ratisbonae [Regensburg] (imprimé chez la veuve de Christophe Ernest
	Brenck) 1826.
	<em>Cahier 1</em>: 1820 (to be considered as published after 31 Dec 1820), p. [i-ii], [1]-26, <em>pl. 1-
	13.</em> – has a t.p. of its own. Leipsic et Prague (au Musée germanique ...) 1820.
	<em>Cahier 2</em>: 1822, p. [i], [1]-37, <em>pl. 14-26.</em>
	<em>Cahier 3</em>: 1824, p. [i], [1]-44, [45. err.] <em>pl. 27-39.</em>
	<em>Cahier 4</em>: 1826, p. [i*], [i]-xli, [Tentamen], [1]-53, [54, err.], <em>pl. 40-59, A-E.</em>
<em>Correction sheet German edition</em>: the Teyler copy has a loose one page sheet "Berichtigung"
	stating that the text for plates 5-8 does not agee with the plates themselves. The text
	given for <em>pl</em>. 5 refers <em>to pl. 6</em> (with changes), idem <em>6</em> for <em>7</em>; the text for <em>plate 7</em> refers to <em>pl.
	8, the text given for pl. 8 refers to pl. 5</em> (with changes). This sheet was issued with Flora
	17(1), 1834. The text of the French edition refers to the correct plates.
<em>Notes in Flora</em> on the publication of the <em>Vers. Fl. Vorwelt</em>: 3(1): 369. 28 Jun 1820 (first Heft
	published; this is now irrelevant because of the conventional date assigned by ICBN),
	5(1): 321-329. 7 Jun 1822 (review Heft 2), 6(1): 48. 1823 (the fossils described in the
	Flora are in the Bohemian National Museum, Praha), Flora 8(2), Beil. 3: 33-34. Ante
	14 Dec 1825 (rev. Heft 4, includes Tentamen, index iconum, and general t.p. for Heft
	1-4); 10(1): 321-335. 7 Jun 1827 and 337-346. 14 Jun 1827 (rev.), 10(2): 671. 14 Nov
	1827 (Essai rd by REG Oct-Nov. 1827), 16(2): 670-671. 14 Nov 1833 (rev. Heft 5-6),
	22(1): 16. 7 Jan 1839 (Heft 7-8 publ.), 23(1): 94. 14 Feb 1840 (Heft 7-8 rd.).
<em>Analytical description</em>: G. Schmid, Goethe u.d. Naturw. 1900, nos. 407-408.

Sterne, Carus [pseudonym for Ernst Ludwig Krause] (1839-1903), German self-taught
natural scientist and popularizing author; strong proponent of the ideas of Charles
Darwin and Ernst Häckel. (<em>Sterne</em>; <em>E.L. Krause</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: See also our entry under E.L. Krause in TL-2/2: 666.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 319; BM 2: 1024; CSP 18: 950; Jackson p.
484; Kleppa p. 35, 72, 206, 209, 225; Langman p. 722; LS 25815; PR 4862; Rehder 5:
473.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Brit. Mus. gen. cat. print. book 229: 778. 1964; Cat. gen. livr. impr.
	Bibl. natl. 83: 464-465. 1925 (sub E.L. Krause); Insektenbörse 20: 306. 1903 (obit.
	not.).
Hantzsch, V., <em>in</em> A. Bettelheim, ed., Biogr. Jahrb. deut. Nekrol. 8: 305-307. 1905 (obit.,
	mentions main works; listed under Krause; see also p. 64*).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Editor, with Otto Caspari, Gustav Jäger and in collaboration with
Charles Darwin and E. Haeckel, of <em>Kosmos</em>, Zeitschrift für einheitliche Weltanschauung
auf Grund der Entwicklungslehre ... herausgegeben von ... E. Krause, Leipzig 1877-
1881, vols. 1-8; continued as <em>Kosmos</em> Zeitschrift für Entwicklungslehre und einheitliche
Weltanschauung. Stuttgart 1881-1883, vols. 9-13.

13.027. <em>Die botanische Systematik</em> in ihrem Verhältniss zur Morphologie. Kritische
Vergleichung der wichtigsten älteren Pflanzensysteme, nebst Vorschlägen zu einem nat-
ürlichen Pflanzensysteme nach morphologischen Grundsätzen, den Fachgelehrten zur
Beurteilung vorgelegt von Ernst Krause. Weimar (Bernhard Friedrich Voigt) 1866. Oct. (<em>Bot. Syst.</em>).

Sterneck, Jakob [Daublebsky] von (1864-1941), Bohemian botanist and entomologist;
with R. v. Wettstein in Prague 1892-1895; district commissioner in Eger (Cheb),
Trautenau, and, ultimately at Drahowitz nr Karlsbad. (<em>Sterneck</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: PRC; other material at C, E, GB, MANCH, PACA, W. –
Contributed to E. Bauer, <em>Bryotheca bohemica</em>. – Issued, with several collaborators.
<em>Herbarium des Egerlandes</em>, 540 nos., 1905. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

Sterner, [Karl] Rikard (1891-1956), Swedish botanist; Dr. phil. Uppsala 1923;
teacher at various high schools from 1923, at Vänersborg from 1926, at Göteborg from
1930. (<em>Sterner</em>).
